Review/Theater; Sobol's 'Ghetto,' a Holocaust Drama With Music

Question Box
LEAD:  Hubbell vs.
Spahn  Q. Did Warren Spahn ever win a game against Carl Hubbell?
A.
By the time Spahn started winning games in the National League, and he won 363 of them, Hubbell was starting his second year of retirement after notching 253 victories, all in the National League.
The two Hall of Fame left-handers had one season in common, 1942, when Hubbell's career was in its twilight and Spahn's was dawning.


A Rocket With Finesse
LEAD: Twenty years ago, Rod (the Rocket) Laver became the only tennis player to win the Grand Slam twice.
The left-hander, who first accomplished this amazing feat in 1962, repeated it in 1969 by using a variety of strokes - cross-court volleys, pinpoint lobs and soft drop shots -rarely seen in this day of the blistering forehands and two-handed backhands.

Sandlot to the Ballet Stage: Edward Villella Is Honored
LEAD: Edward Villella, one of the great American ballet stars, owes his career in dance to a baseball accident.
In 1946, when he was 10 years old, Mr.
Villella was knocked unconscious in a sandlot ball game in Bayside, Queens, where he grew up.
His mother wanted to keep him off the streets as a result, so when she enrolled her daughter in the School of American Ballet, she mentioned that she had a son at home.

Business Digest
LEAD:  The Media Business  WPP Group has begun an assault on another U.S. ad agency, making an unsolicited $730 million offer to buy the Ogilvy Group.
If the bid succeeds, it will create the world's second-largest advertising company, after Saatchi &amp; Saatchi, which like WPP is based in London.
A merger would join some of the best-known names in advertising and continue the wave of mergers that has transformed the ad and marketing-communications industries.

LEAD: Responding to increasing violence in the occupied territories between Palestinians and Jewish settlers, two Israeli Cabinet ministers demanded today that the settlers be allowed to shoot more freely in clashes with Arabs.


Selling Planes to China: High Stakes
LEAD: In competing to supply the vast Chinese appetite for new airplanes, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation have taken two basic approaches: selling and manufacturing.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-11  London and Bonn agreed to differ on NATO disarmament strategy and declared that they were looking to the alliance meeting at the end of May to restore a common front.
Page A1


In Washington, Just a Hint of the Alliance's Angst
LEAD: In London, Bonn, Paris and Rome, indeed right across Western Europe, politicians and large segments of the public are hotly debating the new rifts in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that West Germany has laid bare for all to see.


Hoch Wins on 5th Extra Hole
LEAD: Three weeks after he failed to win the Masters because he missed a 2-foot putt on the first playoff hole, Scott Hoch won the $1.25 million Las Vegas Invitational today by rolling in an 8-foot birdie putt on the fifth hole of a sudden-death playoff with Robert Wrenn.


Body of Young Woman Is Discovered in a Park
LEAD: A 19-year-old woman was found strangled in Fort Tryon Park in the Inwood section of Manhattan on Saturday morning, the police said.


'Concert Against AIDS'
LEAD: A Canadian chamber ensemble, the Tudor Singers of Montreal, is to join the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. in a benefit, ''In Concert Against AIDS.'' Funds raised will go to a group residence for AIDS patients, Bailey House of the AIDS Resource Center.
Tickets are $25 to $200.


School Reform, in Voters' Hands
LEAD: Should public officials, political leaders and employees of New York City's Board of Education be prohibited from serving on community school boards?
Just days before tomorrow's election of 288 local school board members, U.S.
District Judge Mark Costantino said no.


Chief to Leave Fireman's Fund
LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company said that William M. McCormick would resign as chairman, president and chief executive by the end of the year.
Jack Byrne, chairman of the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the holding company, will assume Mr.
McCormick's duties in an acting capacity.


Last Laugh to Chaplin
LEAD: To the Editor:


What, When and Where of the School-Board Vote
LEAD: Amid accusations of misdeeds and mismanagement on some New York City community school boards, city voters and parents of children in the public-school system will vote tomorrow for members of the 32 decentralized community school boards.
At stake are 288 seats, 9 on each local board.
The elections are the eighth since the system was decentralized in 1970 to provide community control of local schools.


Critic's Notebook; TV and the Public Figure: Drama vs. the Melodrama
LEAD: Television news did not emerge unscathed from the barrage of recriminations that followed the Senate's rejection of former Senator John G. Tower for Secretary of Defense this year.
Some partisans of the toppled former senator attributed his defeat to a political cabal gleefully abetted by the usual liberal cadre in the press and on the screen.


Sergio Leone, 67, Italian Director Who Revitalized Westerns, Dies
LEAD: Sergio Leone, the Italian director who revived western films in the 1960's and added distinction and style to a genre known as spaghetti westerns, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rome.
He was 67 years old.


Brett May Miss a Month
LEAD: George Brett tore a ligament in his right knee Saturday night and will be sidelined at least a month.

LEAD: Dr.
Ellen Mellow, a fellow in cardiology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday to Dr.
Robert J. Kaner, a pulmonary physician at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and a research associate at New York Hospital.
Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr.


Clemens Outpitched by Ryan
LEAD: Nolan Ryan won the first battle between the best fastball pitchers in Texas today, leading the Texas Rangers past Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox, 2-1, on Rafael Palmeiro's two-run homer in the eighth inning.


Drug Tests Face Test
LEAD: A drug-testing program for high school athletes in Woodstock, Vt. -the first such program in the state and, possibly, the nation - has been started despite controversy over its implementation.


Deborah Yourish Weds A. J. Porges
LEAD: At Temple Beth Shalom in Roslyn, L.I., Dr.
Deborah Miriam Yourish and Andrew Jay Porges, both graduates of the Cornell University Medical College and doctors at New York Hospital, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein.
The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Arthur J. Yourish of Lido Beach, L.I.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Evert Upset by 15-Year-Old: Monica Seles proved yesterday that she was better at playing tennis than figuring the odds.
Seles, 15 years old and unlisted in the world ranking because she has played only five professional events, won her first pro tournament, upsetting top-seeded Chris Evert, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament.


Beth Ruskin Weds an Editor
LEAD: Beth Jane Ruskin and Fred Michael Weiler were married yesterday at Agudath Shalom Synagogue in Stamford, Conn.
Rabbi Morris Gorelick performed the ceremony.


Black and Hispanic Officials Are Cool to 2-House Plan
LEAD: A range of black and Hispanic officials and community groups in New York City say they are not persuaded that proposals for a two-house city legislature would adequately increase opportunities for minorities to win seats or power in a reconstituted city government.


Arafat: Yes and No to Elections
LEAD: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has presented a plan for Israeli-supervised elections in the occupied territories.
The elections would produce Palestinian representatives who would negotiate with Israel on interim autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
He did not address what, if anything, might follow the interim arrangement.

LEAD: The flutist Paula Robison presided over a lively evening of Baroque chamber music in the Medieval Sculpture Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazines Go Beyond The Pop-Up
LEAD: MILLIONS of readers blinked twice when they opened Time magazine in September 1986 and watched the Transamerica tower rise from its pages.
Three years later, experts liken the insurer's ad to the Ford Model T -pioneering but technically unspectacular.


Walter Malley, 49, Editor at Buffalo News
LEAD: Walter Malley, deputy managing editor of The Buffalo News, was killed yesterday morning in an automobile accident in West Seneca, N.Y.
He was 49 years old and lived in Elma, N.Y.


Communist Rebels in Manila Kill Two of Aquino's Guards
LEAD: Communist guerrillas shot and killed two of President Corazon C. Aquino's security guards here today, the police said.


Strong Medicine for Weak S &amp; L's
LEAD: The savings and loan rescue taking shape in Congress improves on President Bush's original plan by making the owners and stockholders of savings and loan associations risk more of their own money and less of the public's.
But the House Banking Committee now threatens to weaken the plan with exemptions and a tacked-on subsidy scheme for low-cost housing.


Bass Cuts Mifflin Stake
LEAD: A group led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas investor, disclosed last week that it had whittled its stake in the Houghton Mifflin Company, the book publisher, to 1.1 percent, from 5.6 percent.
The Bass Group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold the stock because it appeared to be ''reasonably priced'' and added that the group still regards the company as ''one of the nation's leading publishers.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Washington created a living, functioning government.
He brought together men of genius - a team of giants, with strong and competing views.
He harnessed and directed their energies.
And he established a precedent for 40 Presidents to follow.''  - President Bush.  [ B2:2. ]

LEAD: Waving from an open Jeep, Domingo Laino smiled giddily as his balloon-festooned campaign caravan passed the Palace of Government here, command center for 35 years of the dictatorship of Gen.
Alfredo Stroessner.


The Bleakest Business Address in America
LEAD: This is the coldest, nastiest place in America to do business, a place where it can snow on the Fourth of July and where even now the only sign of spring is that snow by the roads is beginning to turn brown from dust.

LEAD: Lisa Pam Yarvis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs.
Martin R. Yarvis of Long Beach, L.I., was married in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday to Richard Jon Sobelsohn, a son of Mrs.
Arthur Gladstone of Shelter Island, L.I., and the late William Sobelsohn.
Rabbi Morris Feldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.


Investors Hop On Bulls' Bandwagon
LEAD: WHEN the latest upward explosion in stock prices began, the portfolio managers who run mutual funds were much more bullish than the investors in the funds.
But the investors seem to have gotten the bullish religion in April, fund managers say.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about steaks described the grading of Certified Angus beef incorrectly.
The beef is graded by the Government as either choice or prime and also conforms to specifications set by the American Angus Association, a private beef cattle registry.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Oil Means Comfort to Alaska Natives but Peril to Their Culture
LEAD: Oil, which recently brought disaster to southeastern Alaska, has brought something very different to the native peoples here, 850 miles to the north: comfort, convenience and the seeds of destruction of their way of life.


Farm Loan Agency Picks Its First Chief
LEAD: Henry D. Edelman, a first vice president specializing in government finance at Paine Webber Inc., has been named the first president and chief executive of a new Federal agency, the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Credit Card Shift to Chiat
LEAD: Facing intense competition from Visa and Mastercard, as well as from its own products, American Express switched its $25 million gold card account on Friday from McCann-Erickson to Chiat/Day, New York, and its unit, Perkins/Butler Direct Marketing.


Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
LEAD: This week's schedule of new Treasury issues is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills totaling $14 billion, followed by a $9 billion auction on Thursday of a new one-year bill.


...as Japan Questions American Commitment
LEAD: When the Control Data Corporation, one of two manufacturers of supercomputers in the United States, abruptly dropped out of the race to build the fastest machines in the world, the Japanese were both startled and a bit apprehensive.


In Kabul, Bitterness Toward the U.S. Is Emerging
LEAD: When foreigners entered the sunny courtyard of Baz Mohammed Mohmand's home on a hillside above Kabul today, there was a moment of agitation. ''It was one of their rockets!'' cried Sayed Ibrahim, Mr.
Mohmand's 22-year-old son-in-law, motioning toward visitors who had been introduced as coming from the United States.


Spree by Thomas Sinks the Celtics
LEAD: Isiah Thomas has a broken bone in his left hand that throbs every time someone hits it.
He has played cautiously for three weeks, picking his spots to score while letting teammates carry the load offensively.

LEAD: Sir John Boyd, a miner's son who fought off leftists to lead the powerful British union of engineering workers, died Sunday at his home in Eastbourne, south of London, the BBC said today.
He was 71.

Tornadoes Hit North Florida
LEAD: Tornadoes touched down across the Florida Panhandle today, but no one was hurt and there was little damage, the officials said.

O'Reilly Quits Post As Bruins' Coach
LEAD: Citing a desire to spend more time with his family, Terry O'Reilly resigned yesterday after more than two seasons as coach of the Boston Bruins.


Avalon Takeover
LEAD: The Avalon Corporation, an oil and gas exploration company, said it had agreed to a takeover by the Corona Corporation, a Canadian mining company, for about $104 million.
Avalon stockholders will receive $7.375 for each common and preferred share.
Its shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $6.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Critic's Notebook; Television and the Attack in Central Park
LEAD: With everyone casting about for explanations for last month's gang assault on a jogger in Central Park, attention has, as usual, turned to television, which often receives a share of the blame for dismaying social ailments, including crime, illiteracy and general sloth.
The blame-television-first reaction is instantaneous, like pressing the buzzer on a game show before the other contestants.


Grain Prices Up on Reports
LEAD: The prices of grain and soybean futures rose strongly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to long-range forecasts of below-average rainfall in several states that produce grain.


San Francisco Journal; Undercurrent of Ill Will Grows With Chinatown
LEAD: A visitor to this city's North Beach neighborhood could easily assume that the traditionally Italian community and its recently arrived Chinese neighbors have settled into the most harmonious blending of cultures since Marco Polo helped turn the Orient's noodles into Italy's spaghetti.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in SportsMonday this week about horse racing misidentified the race won by Bold Ruler.
It was the 1956 Futurity at Belmont Park, for 2-year-olds, not the Belmont Stakes, which he lost in 1957 as a 3-year-old.


School Elections
LEAD: New York City voters will go to the polls today to choose the members of the city's 32 community school boards.
Registered voters, as well as parents of students in the public school system who have registered as ''parent voters,'' are eligible to cast ballots.

LEAD: A cooling breeze across the New Orleans Fair Grounds ruffled the 10-foot-high, turquoise-and-peach feathered headdresses of the Original Yellow Jackets as they drummed and chanted about ''raisin' hell'' on Mardi Gras morning.
A short stroll away, Boogie Bill Webb was plunking out a sly, lowdown blues, ''Drinkin' and Stinkin'.

South Korea Slips on Road to Democracy
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Fall, Attention Shifts to the Legs
LEAD: Legs.
They are what's left to look at when the skirt vanishes.
When Karl Lagerfeld subtracted the skirt from his longer Chanel suits recently in Paris, he acknowledged what trendy young people are wearing in all the world's fashion capitals: jackets plus tights or skinny pants.


Berkeley Undergraduates to Take Courses on Ethnic Groups
LEAD: Students at the University of California at Berkeley, where no one ethnic group is a majority among undergraduates, will be required to take a comparative course on American ethnic groups to graduate beginning in 1991.

Treasury Delays Action On Fringe-Benefit Rule
LEAD: The Treasury said today that it would not enforce until Oct. 1 a new fringe-benefit regulation that the business community considers onerous, particularly for small companies.

LEAD: Exxon officials today released a revised plan for cleaning 364 miles of Alaskan coastline fouled by the nation's largest oil spill, but said their proposal requires a suspension of local environmental laws.

LEAD: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview broadcast Sunday that documentary evidence clears President Bush of accusations that he sought aid for the Nicaraguan rebels at a 1985 meeting with the President of Honduras.


Guide for Jungle of Computer Terminology
LEAD: ''TO click a mouse is to press one button very briefly (usually the leftmost button if there is more than one).
By contrast, see press.
See also double-click.''

Lobsters May Explain Aggression In Humans
LEAD: LOBSTERS are normally solitary creatures of the deep.
But when placed together in a tank they will fight continually until one emerges dominant.
The winner stands tall, on the tips of its legs, while the loser lies flat on its belly.

David Rothstein
LEAD: Dr.
David Rothstein, a general practitioner in Jackson Heights, Queens, for 50 years, died of bone cancer Friday at his home in Southbury, Conn.
He was 88 years old.

Sanctions Could Double the Price of Some Japanese Goods
LEAD: Japanese facsimile machines, telephone switchboards and cordless telephones are among the products that could face 100 percent duties, doubling their price in this country, under trade retaliation plans being formulated by the Bush Administration, trade officials said today.


Savings Bonds To Yield 7.81%
LEAD: United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.81 percent in the next six months, the highest rate of return in three years, the Government announced today.


Review/Pop; Songs of a Lebanese Star
LEAD: The singer Magida el-Roumi, one of Lebanon's biggest pop stars, came to Hunter College on Saturday night with a 19-piece orchestra and swarms of dancers.
Miss el-Roumi, dressed in formal evening clothes, wandered between near-European pop and Middle Eastern pop, turning phrases into a flutter of windblown notes or keeping them glued to a melody.


FSX: Icing on the Cake For General Dynamics
LEAD: Some jet fighters are faster.
Others can carry more weapons.
And some definitely are more modern in design.
But the General Dynamics Corporation is betting that its popular F-16 is going to go on and on.
Company executives believe that at least another 2,000 of the $15 million planes can be sold before the fighter becomes obsolete, making it one of military aviation's best sellers.


Gooden Is 5-0; Unfazed By Slip
LEAD: For six innings tonight, Dwight Gooden sailed through the Braves' anemic lineup, apparently oblivious to the rain-soaked turf that made the area around the pitching mound slippery and treacherous.


I.B.M. Schedules Announcement
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to announce today a series of products aimed at improving the performance of private telephone networks used by businesses, analysts said.
The computer giant, based in Armonk, N.Y., will introduce Callpath, which will offer businesses the ability to link computer data about customers with the private branch exchange telephone systems in their offices.

LEAD: There is a race track adage that says ''never knock a horse until he's been dead for 25 years'' because horses make fools of handicappers every day.

Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Narrow a Law on Free Legal Service
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that a current Federal law cannot be used to force lawyers to donate their services to the poor in civil cases.


Shearson to Buy Scherer
LEAD: A yearlong battle to force the sale of the R. P. Scherer Corporation ended today when the company agreed to be taken private by Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings and its merchant banking partners, who are supplying the financing for the $406.7 million buyout.

W. Paul Stillman is Dead at 91; Banker Led Newark Preservation
LEAD: W. Paul Stillman, a banker, insurance company executive and major force in the preservation of downtown Newark, died Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J.
He was 91 years old and lived in Fair Haven, N.J.

LEAD: New York City yesterday imposed the most stringent drought-emergency measures of an arid spring and also began drawing millions of gallons of water from the Hudson River to handle what could be the worst water shortage in the city's history.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Many Experiments, No Proof of Fusion  Physicists said many experiments have failed to validate a claim that nuclear fusion had been achieved in a jar of water.
Those unable to repeat the experiment included the California Institute of Technology and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
Science Times, page C1.

LEAD: President Bush's chief economist, Michael J. Boskin, warned today that ''bashing'' trade partners like Japan could lead to a trade war and a recession.

LEAD: With the city's emotions still raw two weeks after an attack on a jogger by a group of teen-agers in Central Park, about 200 New York City public-school students, teachers and officials gathered in the park yesterday to appeal for harmony in a ceremony of songs and speeches.

LEAD: THE problem with mice - the computer variety - is that they need a relatively uncluttered chunk of desk space in which to roam.
As the user pushes the soap bar-size mouse around the desktop, the cursor moves across the computer screen in a corresponding direction.

By Design; A Scarf, as a Skirt
LEAD: If you're good at wrapping packages, this will be a cinch.
In a jiffy, you can whip up your own version of this season's stylishly sexy sarong skirt.
All you need is a large scarf - preferably a pareo, roughly 57 inches by 72 inches - a full-length mirror and a little practice.

Chess
LEAD: It used to be that, if you were leading a tournament, you took an early draw in the last round to guarantee a tie for first place.
This was the counsel of Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, who dominated chess from 1948 until 1963.
His idea was that the last round was too nerve-racking, that anyone who went all-out for a victory would blunder and lose.


Richmond Top Rookie
LEAD: Mitch Richmond, who averaged 22 points in the 79 games he played for the Golden State Warriors in the regular season, was named the winner of the Eddie Gottlieb Trophy yesterday as the National Basketball Association's top rookie.
The 6-foot-5-inch Richmond, a first-round draft choice from Kansas State, helped the Warriors improve their record from 20-62 last season to 43-39 and a playoff berth this season.(

No Meeting for Rose
LEAD: Pete Rose, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, who is under investigation by the baseball commissioner's office, said he had no plans to meet with A. Bartlett Giamatti when the Reds come to New York tomorrow for a two-game series with the Mets.


Notes and Bonds Slip in Light Day
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in reaction to a report from the nation's purchasing managers that suggested the economy gained some strength in April.


How to Recapture School Dropouts
LEAD: New figures confirm that one in every four New York City public school students drops out of school, despite special programs.
Schools Chancellor Richard Green voices concern over the high rate and suggests the need to restructure the system profoundly.
That's a sobering conclusion but there is encouraging evidence, and a growing national consensus, that less radical approaches can do the job.

LEAD: P. J. Carlesimo ended speculation that he might take the head-coaching job at Kentucky by announcing today that he would remain at Seton Hall.

Eastern Plan On Asset Sale
LEAD: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had firm contracts or acceptable offers for about $1.1 billion worth of its assets, which it would sell in a plan to become a smaller carrier.


Making Things Worse
LEAD: Will the brutal attack on a jogger by youths rampaging through Central Park be an issue in the New York City mayoral primaries and election?
Almost certainly it will, to the city's detriment, though probably no mayor could have prevented this random crime - including the one to be elected in November, whatever he might promise in the interim.

Associates of Wright in Venture Defend Profitable Drilling Deal
LEAD: The participants in an oil well venture that produced a substantial profit for Speaker Jim Wright vehemently defended the arrangement today, charging that the House ethics committee's investigative report was full of distortions and errors.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Logic of Fahrenheit  Q.If the centigrade (or Celsius) and Kelvin temperature scales are based on natural phenomena like the freezing and boiling points of water and absolute zero, what is the logical basis for the Fahrenheit scale?
A.Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit, who devised the scale, wanted natural reference points, but he did not choose wisely, said James Schooley of the National Institute of Standards and


Museum Seeks Pay For Views
LEAD: From the high-rise insurance towers and financial service companies of downtown, precisely 4,153 windows have a view of Connecticut's old Capitol building.
Wilson H. Faude knows, because he counted them all before proposing a $10-a-window viewing-rights tax.

Self-Serve Gas Banned Again
LEAD: New Jersey's 40-year ban on self-service gasoline stations received a boost today as the State Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill retaining it.
Supporters said the measure, passed 32 to 4, is meant to meet a judicial test of the ban.
Sponsors said self-service would mean higher prices and inconvenience and would jeopardize smaller stations and hurt senior citizens who have difficulty pumping gas.

Review/Comedy; Moynihan and Green Satirize Life
LEAD: Jackie and Jerry Diamond, the most fully realized characters created by the young comedy duo Moynihan and Green, are an unflappably upbeat show-business couple whose act suggests a third-string Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme.
Performing their tribute to Michael Jackson, the Diamonds praise him as ''a very talented Negro lad'' and go on to mutilate his songs by interpolating stale hipster's slang into the lyrics.

Philip Spina, 93, Dies; Tile Company Founder
LEAD: Philip Spina, the founder and retired president of Standard Tile, one of the country's largest tile distributors, died of complications from a fall on Sunday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I.
He was 93 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Frenchwoman Gains: Christine Damas of France defeated Sabine Auer of West Germany, 6-0, 5-7, 7-5, yesterday in first-round play at the Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany.
In other matches, Jo-Anne Faull of Australia beat Silke Frankl of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2; Nathalie Tauziat of France downed Petra Huber of Austria, 6-2, 6-2, and Silke Meier of West Germany defeated Steffi Menning, 6-2, 6-4.(AP)

F.B.I. Examines Actions of Police at Arizona State
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining the conduct of the Arizona State University campus police in an April 15 incident in which two black students were handcuffed and said they were bullied by officers as a crowd of white students yelled racial slurs.

Aguirre Helps Pistons Put Celtics on the Brink
LEAD: When Mark Aguirre was traded to the Detroit Pistons in February, his new teammates were concerned.
The Pistons didn't like some things they had heard about Aguirre, whether they were true or not.
So several days after he joined the team, Aguirre was taken to dinner by Isiah Thomas, Bill Laimbeer, Rick Mahorn and Vinnie Johnson.


Physicists Challenge Cold Fusion Claims
LEAD: Separate experiments by many research groups have failed to validate a claim by the University of Utah to have achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water, physicists reported today.

Chinese Students Try Networking
LEAD: Students from several Chinese cities gathered today at Beijing University to discuss plans to expand their pro-democracy movement and to form links with schools throughout the nation.


Death Penalty Law in Illinois Struck Down
LEAD: A Federal judge struck down the death penalty law in Illinois today, raising doubts about the fate of 121 prisoners on the state's death row.


USX to Modernize Plant in Gary, Ind.
LEAD: The USX Corporation's. chairman, David M. Roderick, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company planned to spend $240 million to modernize its largest plant, at Gary, Ind.
The keystone of the improvements will be a continuous slab caster designed to shape 1.6 million tons of molten steel directly into slabs, using less energy and less time and leaving fewer blemishes in the steel.

House Panel Sticks to Tough Savings Guidelines
LEAD: In its third day of deliberations on the Bush savings rescue plan, the House Banking Committee today beat back a major challenge to the tough capital provisions it approved last week.


Review/Dance; A Former Soviet Ballerina Makes Her American Debut
LEAD: The Eglevsky Ballet presented a program of oddities in Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University tonight.
Not the least of these oddities was the rarely seen ''Carnival in Venice,'' also known as ''Satanella,'' choreographed by Marius Petipa to a grandiloquent score by Cesare Pugni.

Film Theme Park Opened by Disney
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company opened its $400 million Disney-MGM Studios theme park today.
The 135-acre complex blends film making with backstage studio tours and ride-through, walk-through attractions.
Movie and TV production began last summer on its three sprawling sound studios and back-lot street scenes.


Herbert Denton, 45, Foreign Correspondent
LEAD: Herbert H. Denton Jr., The Washington Post's correspondent in Canada, died of pneumonia Saturday at a hospital in Toronto.
He was 45 years old and suffered from AIDS.

Jogger's Outlook Better, Doctors Say
LEAD: The jogger who was raped and beaten by rampaging teen-agers last month in Central Park has improved substantially, and experts said yesterday that it was likely she would survive and leave the hospital to live independently.
But it is also likely, they added, that she will have at least some permanent brain damage.


Japanese to Buy Hotel Bel-Air
LEAD: A Japanese hotel operator has agreed to purchase the landmark Hotel Bel-Air here from the Rosewood Property Company of Dallas for about $110 million, Rosewood said today.

Impatience Not a Virtue For Yanks
LEAD: With the impatience of a midtown Manhattan cab driver at rush hour or a celebrated Tampa shipbuilder at any hour, the Yankees decided that Al Leiter was not worth waiting for.
And now the Toronto Blue Jays will mine the potential of the 23-year-old left-hander after a trade for Jesse Barfield, a right fielder of diminishing returns since 1986 when he hit 40 homers and drove in 108 runs.

Board's Fate: New Design In Governing
LEAD: Sometime this week, perhaps as soon as today, the commission rewriting New York City's Charter will vote to recommend abolishing the Board of Estimate.
The death of the city board, which has been at the center of civic affairs for 91 years, will mark a major turning point in New York's political history.


Alan D. Ferguson, 75, Former Yale Official
LEAD: Alan Douglas Ferguson, an educational administrator and former assistant dean at Yale University, died of a pulmonary embolism Wednesday at the Lahey Clinic Medical Center in Burlington, Mass.
He was 75 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.


Debentures Priced by Fannie Mae
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $500 million worth of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1999 through various securities dealers.

Review/Opera; After a Week of Total Immersion, Some Reflections on the Met 'Ring'
LEAD: At a time when many new productions of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' might be more aptly entitled ''Der Ringling des Barnum und Bailey,'' the Metropolitan Opera's staging of Wagner's epic has cast a vote for the notion that maybe, just maybe, the composer knew best.
Since September 1986, when the Otto Schenk staging began taking shape with a ''Walkure'' that tried to respect that peculiar idea, the Metropolitan's trend-bucking project has aroused widespread suspicion, even resentment.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday misidentified Dr.
Danny Hillis.
He is founding scientist of Thinking Machines Inc., a supercomputer manufacturer based in Cambridge, Mass.
The company's president is Sheryl Handler.


Broken Nose for Ellis
LEAD: Dale Ellis, a high-scoring guard for the Seattle SuperSonics, suffered a fractured nose Sunday in his team's playoff victory over the Houston Rockets in Seattle.
Bill Boenke, a SuperSonics spokesman, said Ellis would make the trip to Houston for Game 3 but that it was doubtful he would play.(AP)

MCI Gets Contract
LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had given it a five-year contract worth $75 million to $100 million to expand and enhance its voice and digital communications network.
The U S Sprint Communications Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company also bid for the contract, MCI said.

LEAD: With mortality on his mind on the day of a relative's funeral in 1941, President Franklin D. Roosevelt broached the issue of memorials with Justice Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court.

The Worm and the Apple; Dads Change Diapers, Too
LEAD: It took five years and $35 million to renovate the Central Park Zoo, and the city seems to have thought of just about everything to make the place comfortable for both beasts and people - except the possibility that a man might need to change a baby's diaper.
The city rates a worm for its oversight.


2 Killed as Renewed Fighting Threatens Truce in Lebanon
LEAD: Fighting with artillery and rockets broke out again today between Muslim and Christian forces in the capital, threatening a three-day-old cease-fire called by the Arab League.

Moscow Represses Freud's Slip Into Print
LEAD: One hundred thousand freshly printed copies of ''Essays on the Psychology of Sexuality,'' the first Soviet book of Freud's writings since the early Bolsheviks pronounced him taboo, are being held by the authorities and may never reach the reading public.

Max Gewirtz, 98, a Retired School Official
LEAD: Max Gewirtz, a retired assistant superintendent of New York City schools, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center.
He was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Service for Harold Hayes
LEAD: A service for Harold T. P. Hayes, a former editor of Esquire magazine, will be held Monday at 11 A.M. in the auditorium of McGraw-Hill Inc. at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street.
The magazine will sponsor the service for Mr.
Hayes, who died on April 5 in Los Angeles at the age of 62.

Mr.

Czech Gold Venture
LEAD: Czechoslovakia is negotiating with four foreign companies on a joint venture to resume gold mining near Prague, a geological official was quoted as saying last week.
Talks with the companies, including two from Australia, involve an operation that would start in 1991, with an estimated potential of 100 tons of gold, said the official, Josef Pravda, head of the Czech Geological Bureau.


Sea-Exploring Robot Is Recovered Off Italy
LEAD: THE underwater robot Jason and a companion vehicle have been recovered after breaking loose from a tether Wednesday while descending to the wreck of an ancient Roman ship, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution reported yesterday.


In-State Commuting (and Woes) Rising in New Jersey
LEAD: Admittedly 58-year-old William R. Wright of Cranford was gung-ho for mass transit.
A railroad buff, veteran commuter and assistant sales manager, he had gladly taken the 40-minute train ride to Manhattan every workday for 28 years.


Rite Aid Stock Falls on Bribe Charge
LEAD: The stock price of the Rite Aid Corporation fell yesterday for the second consecutive trading day after charges of attempted bribery were brought in Cleveland last week against Martin L. Grass, its president.

Navy Relieves Ship Captain
LEAD: The commander of a Newport-based frigate that collided with another ship 12 days ago has been relieved of his duties on the frigate, the Navy said today.

Lewis Athow of the frigate Trippe was temporarily assigned to Naval Surface Group 4 in Newport, the Navy said.

Nobody Tells the Truth
LEAD: Nobody is telling the truth.
In weeks of arguments and pronouncements about West Germany, NATO, the Soviet Union and short-range nuclear weapons, no diplomat, politician or national leader has had the courage to say plainly what lies beneath it all.
It is this fear: West Germany, already the dominant economic power in Western Europe, will use the Gorbachev openings to become the dominant economic power in Eastern and Central Europe as well.

Up Against the Wall: Murphy Bed's Name
LEAD: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan declared that anyone who might feel the need to manufacture a bed of the type that has stumped the likes of Charlie Chaplin and Jackie Gleason can call it, if they want to, well, what else?
A Murphy bed.


Japanese Wage Growth
LEAD: The average Japanese worker's monthly wage climbed 3.6 percent after inflation in the last fiscal year, the highest real growth rate in 14 years, the Labor Ministry said today.
The wage rose to 343,716 yen, or $2,565, in the fiscal year ended March 31.
The last time real growth in wages was higher was in the 1974 fiscal year, when it climbed 5.9 percent.


Taipei Official Visits China Unofficially
LEAD: Forty years after Communist forces sent China's Nationalist Government fleeing to Taiwan, Taiwan's Finance Minister today became the first Taiwan Government official to return.


COURT, 6-3, EASES TASK OF PLAINTIFFS IN JOB-BIAS SUITS
LEAD: The Supreme Court, ruling in a significant job discrimination case, today made it easier for plaintiffs to prevail in many lawsuits based on sex, race and age discrimination in employment.


Tall Following


WESTERN OFFICIALS ARE NOW HOPEFUL ON A NATO ACCORD
LEAD: The elements of a compromise on the contentious issue of short-range nuclear missiles are beginning to emerge in hurried consultations among the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, senior diplomats from several nations say.


Judge Warns of Mistrial if Secrets Used in North Case Are Disclosed
LEAD: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that he might declare a mistrial if news organizations succeeded in their effort to force disclosure of a classified exhibit introduced into evidence in the trial.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dispute in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over short-range nuclear weapons described the replacement for the Lance missile incorrectly.
The new missiles are to have increased range, but not increased explosive yield.

Bridge
LEAD: When a young team wins two significant events within a short period it is reasonable to conclude that the players are on their way to the top.
Judith Fields, Mamdouh Guenena, John Scheuermann and Mark Lake, all of Manhattan, captured the Flight B Regional Swiss Teams in Hofstra, L.I., on April 2.
Five weeks earlier, with Mark Stratton playing instead of Lake, they had won the Flight B Grand National Team title and qualified for playoffs in Chicago in July.

India Puts Off Missile Test
LEAD: For the second time in two weeks, a last-minute technical hitch forced India today to postpone the scheduled test launch of a long-range missile.
A Defense Ministry official said no new date had been set for a trial of the rocket, which has a striking distance of more than 1,500 miles and is to carry a one-ton technical payload.


Texaco to Stay In South Africa
LEAD: Texaco Inc. will not follow Mobil Inc. in withdrawing from South Africa, Texaco's president, James Kinnear, said today.


Texas Instruments Patent Settlement
LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had reached a patent cross-licensing agreement with Micron Technology Inc. of Boise, Idaho, that will end patent litigation between the companies.
Micron will pay Texas Instruments $38.2 million to cover royalties on Texas Instruments patents on dynamic random access memory chips.


Review/Theater; Bill Irwin Tussles Anew With the Modern World
LEAD: Any fears that Bill Irwin, having arrived on Broadway, might have gone Broadway are quickly dispelled in ''Largely New York,'' the sweet, brief show that the invaluable New Vaudeville clown brought to the St.
James last night.
While Mr.
Irwin may now be playing across the street from ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' he is congenitally incapable of succumbing to high-tech glitz.

As Farms Falter, Rural Homelessness Grows
LEAD: In a steady stream driven by bleak economics in America's farm country, a new class of homeless people is emerging from rural areas: farm families and others who are out of work because farms are faltering.


Is That a Grimace? Ask a Pigeon
LEAD: PIGEONS have been taught to recognize human facial expressions, upsetting long-held notions that only humans had evolved the sophisticated nervous systems to perform such a feat.


McEnroe Manages to Steal Show
LEAD: What did Pete Sampras, Jaime Yzaga, Bruno Oresar, Eduardo Osta, Udo Riglewski and Josef Cihak have in common yesterday?
All were playing first-round matches in the Eagle Tournament of Champions in front of fewer fans than were watching John McEnroe practice.
And McEnroe is not even entered in the singles draw.


Ben &amp; Jerry's Pact
LEAD: Ben &amp; Jerry's Homemade Inc. has agreed with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. to have some of its ice cream made at Dreyer's Indiana plant.
James Miller, general manager for Ben &amp; Jerry's, said that the company had exhausted its capacity and that demand for the ice cream was far outstripping supply.


Flyers Stun Canadiens in Opener
LEAD: Rick Tocchet played hurt, Derrick Smith played cannily and Ken Wregget played worried as the Philadelphia Flyers once again made do without Ron Hextall.


Anti-Apartheid Worker Killed
LEAD: A white anti-apartheid campaigner was shot and killed today outside his home by an assailant firing from a passing car, the police said.


Tuition Protests Spread to Most CUNY Campuses
LEAD: Demonstrations against budget cuts and likely tuition increases spread to most campuses of the City University of New York yesterday, with students seizing more administration buildings, marching in the streets and blocking traffic in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

Our Towns; Colt Strikers See Reason for Hope In 'For Sale' Sign
LEAD: The last time Robert Trinks punched a clock at the Colt Industries firearms plant was on Jan. 23, 1986.
He has been on strike ever since.
So have about 750 of the company's 1,100 workers.
The rest quit.
Or crossed the picket line.
Or died.
Twenty-five have died so far. ''I don't know anyone who has given up on the strike in the past year except guys who died,'' Mr.


U.S. Facing A Struggle After Victory
LEAD: The uninspiring performance of the United States in its World Cup qualifying game against Costa Rica Sunday substantiated Coach Bob Gansler's claim that the Americans have a long way to go before they can be considered the favorite in their battle with four other nations in the region.

High Court to Consider Detroit Papers' Deal
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed yesterday to consider whether Detroit's two daily newspapers should be allowed to merge their business operations under an exemption from Federal antitrust law.


Careers; Building A Better Accountant
LEAD: THE heads of the Big Eight accounting firms are not happy about the education of young people entering the profession.


Some at CUNY See Possible Tuition Rise As Albany Betrayal
LEAD: The protests that continue to disrupt the City University of New York system have been fueled by a growing perception among students, especially minority-group members, that the university is slowly abandoning its historic mission to educate the working-class, student protesters say.

Ringold Journal; A Stretch of River That Time Forgot
LEAD: By quirk of history, a shank of sagebrush country that the Government set aside nearly half a century ago as home for some of the nation's darkest nuclear secrets has become one of its brightest natural wonders.


Layoffs at Jaguar
LEAD: The luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. laid off more than 8,000 workers today because of a dispute that has paralyzed production.
Jaguar said production of 870 cars worth nearly $:22 million ($37 million) had been lost since warehouse workers walked out last week, contending that a manager assaulted a shop steward.The layoffs involve plants in Coventry, in central England, and Castle Bromwich, in the north.


'Unknown' Rookie Jolts John on 7th-Inning Single
LEAD: Tommy John was sailing along on the mound for the Yankees last night until he got to the seventh inning and encountered an unfamiliar face.

Colts Sign Rison
LEAD: Just nine days after the National Football League draft, the Indianapolis Colts yesterday announced the signing of their first-round pick, Andre Rison, the 22d pick over all, who is a wide receiver from Michigan State.
Jim Irsay, the Colts' general manager, said the 5-foot-10-inch, 185-pound receiver signed a five-year contract worth $3 million early yesterday morning.

Jack Rosen, Cartoonist And Builder's Aide, 75
LEAD: Jack Rosen, a cartoonist and public-relations adviser, died of pneumonia Saturday at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.
He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Pepsico Inc., which has been recently riding a wave of consumer favor, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 46 percent, to $165.1 million, or 62 cents a share, up from $113.3 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier.

Corrections
LEAD: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on April 14 described the ownership of the Inter-Continental Hotels Corporation incorrectly.
The company was purchased by the Saison Group of Japan in December from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.


Arafat, Chalking Up a Diplomatic Gain, Meets Mitterrand


Law Review At Columbia In a Dispute On Bias Plan
LEAD: An affirmative-action program at The Columbia Law Review that goes far beyond similar plans at other student legal publications has renewed a debate over how to preserve the quality of the prominent review while remedying discrimination.


Ikko Kasuga, 79, Japan Opposition Figure
LEAD: The founder and former chairman of Japan's opposition Democratic Socialist Party, Ikko Kasuga, died of pneumonia today at Nagoya City University Hospital, hospital officials said.
He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Farley Inc. said its West Point-Pepperell subsidiary had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to explore ways to maximize the value of West Point's Cluett, Peabody division.
Cluett, Peabody makes men's apparel under the Arrow, Coulours by Alexander Julian, Burberry and Gold Toe labels.

LEAD: Seniors at a top-performing high school in this Los Angeles suburb sabotaged their answers on a recent annual test that measures schools' academic quality.

Bush Warns Panama on Election Fraud
LEAD: President Bush warned Panama today that the United States will not recognize the presidential election on Sunday if the results are rigged.
He said it was evident that the Government of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega was ''ready to resort to massive election fraud.''

LEAD: In ''Growing Up in America,'' a documentary feature opening today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, Morley Markson, the film maker, revisits nine of the 1960's counterculture figures who were the subject of his 1971 documentary ''Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family.''


Denver Kills Law That Barred Homes of Unmarried Couples
LEAD: The Denver City Council has abolished a 36-year-old zoning ordinance that made it against the law for unmarried couples to live together in some of the city's more affluent neighborhoods.

Private Domains: Inside Corporate Dining Preserves
LEAD: INSIDE Clarence House, a small textile company on the East Side of Manhattan, lies a spectacular dining room.
Every detail, from the padded taupe wool walls to the individual crystal carafes of wine at every place, was designed to reflect the firm's reputation for luxury and exclusivity.


Charter Panel Rejects Estimate Board and Turns to Council
LEAD: The panel that is writing a new charter for New York City yesterday rejected proposals to preserve the Board of Estimate or to create a two-house city legislature to assume some of the board's powers.
It turned instead to consideration of an expanded City Council of 60 members that would include the five borough presidents.


Oral Roberts Move
LEAD: Oral Roberts, the evangelist, announced yesterday that the university in Tulsa, Okla., that bears his name is withdrawing from the National Collegiate Athletic Association and will seek membership in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.
Roberts said the decision was part of a series of financial cutbacks necessitated by a sharp decline in contributions to the university.


Review/Film; Aggressive Objects Take It Out on Helpless People
LEAD: The eight short works in ''Jan Svankmajer: Alchemist of the Surreal'' are tiny, esoteric masterpieces that blend spectacular animation with good old-fashioned surrealism.
Only in the bizarre world of this Czechoslovak film maker would ''Punch and Judy'' have the alternate title ''The Coffin Factory'' and show puppets escaping from prettily decorated coffins.


2 G.&amp;W. Units In Canada Deal
LEAD: In accordance with a previous agreement, the Canada Development Investment Corporation said yesterday that it would purchase 51 percent of two Canadian book publishers from Gulf and Western Inc. for between $8 million and $9 million (Canadian).
The publishers, which print educational materials, are Ginn &amp; Company (Canada) and GLC Publishers Ltd.


Import Duties On Bearings
LEAD: The United States will impose extra duties on most imported bearings to offset what it calls dumping by nine countries, an independent Government agency decided today.


Pope Urges Zambians To Spur Peace Efforts
LEAD: Pope John Paul II landed in southern Africa today, and wasted no time lashing out against apartheid and urging Zambia to take the lead in bringing peace to this troubled sector of the continent.

The Stone Wall Undermining NATO
LEAD: Finally, West German leaders are beginning to advance a policy on short-range nuclear weapons that makes sense.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl now speaks of linking talks on these weapons to reductions in nonnuclear forces in Europe.
And Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher speaks of limiting rather than eliminating these weapons that are so important to the nuclear deterrent.

Study of U.S. Jobs Program Calls for Focus on the Poor
LEAD: Federal job training programs should be refocused on high school dropouts, welfare recipients and others ''who have low incomes and lack the basic skills necessary to perform well in the labor market,'' a Labor Department study says.


Reviews/Music; Marlboro Ensemble Ends Season At Tully Hall
LEAD: The Musicians From Marlboro chamber-music series is observing its 24th season.
A spinoff from Rudolf Serkin's Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, it combines a sprinkling of veteran instrumentalists with younger players to form touring ensembles, which in New York play at both Alice Tully Hall and the Metropolitan Museum.


Cayton's Corner Attracts Rising Heavyweight Puncher
LEAD: Bill Cayton, the embattled manager of Mike Tyson, has signed another heavyweight as an apparent hedge against the day in February 1992 when his contract with the heavyweight champion expires.


Budget Games
LEAD: The House and Senate are about to approve their respective versions of a fiscal 1990 budget resolution that will supposedly reduce the deficit to $100 billion next year.
Anyone who believes that number needs a refresher course in capital games.

U.S. Mediation Is Accepted in 28-Day Coal Strike

New Yorkers Told Drought Plan Must Stay
LEAD: New York City asked its rain-soaked residents yesterday not to allow an occasional soggy day to lull them into complacency about the need for stringent conservation measures imposed recently.


GERMANS ACCUSED OF EXPORTING ARMS
LEAD: A senior Reagan Administration official charged today that American allies, particularly West Germany, had ignored hundreds of diplomatic protests leveled by the United States in recent years over exports of weapons technology to the Soviet Union and the third world.


Mob-Linked Businessman Killed in Brooklyn
LEAD: A businessman who admitted participating in a $100 million gasoline tax-evasion scheme and having ties to mobsters was shot to death as he drove his Rolls-Royce in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said.


Bank Yields Reported Flat For Week
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were flat for the week ended yesterday.

House Panel Passes Its Version of Savings Plan
LEAD: After considering more than 100 amendments, the House Banking Committee today approved its version of the Bush savings and loan rescue plan.
The legislation imposes tougher capital standards on the industry than the White House plan, while providing subsidies for low- to moderate-income home buyers.


Pact on the FSX Appears Little Changed
LEAD: As the details emerge, the agreement reached last week between the United States and Japan to build the FSX fighter appears to be littled changed on the safeguards on the transfer of technology to the Japanese, officials on both sides say.

Paskey Dedomenico, 78, Pasta Producer
LEAD: Paskey Dedomenico, a food manufacturer whose best-known product was Rice-a-Roni, died Saturday after a brief illness.
He was 78 years old.


Magazine Publisher Is Sold
LEAD: Dearmas Publishing Group, the largest publisher of magazines in Latin America, has been sold to Ediciones Anaya S.A., one of the biggest book publishing companies in Spain, the companies announced on Monday.
Terms were not disclosed, but people at Dearmas said the price was $300 million.


Anne Ackerman, Political Worker, 75

She was 75 years old.

Jesse Jackson: A Capital Idea
LEAD: Here is some free advice for Jesse Jackson as he ponders whether to be a candidate for mayor of Washington D.C.: Run, Jesse, run.


Harvard Re-rejects R.O.T.C.
LEAD: Harvard's undergraduate student council has reversed a decision to ask the Reserve Officers Training Corps back to the campus, ruling that inviting R.O.T.C. back violated the student constitution.
But the debate is not over.
On Sunday night, with about 400 students attended the meeting, the student council voted 43 to 39 against a week-old resolution, approved 41 to 24 the week before, to ask the administration to negotiate with the military and bring back R.O.T.C.


Physicists Debunk Claim Of a New Kind of Fusion
LEAD: Hopes that a new kind of nuclear fusion might give the world an unlimited source of cheap energy appear to have been dealt a devastating blow by scientific evidence presented here.

LEAD: It was another dramatic finish for the Knicks tonight, and this one gave them a three-game sweep of the Philadelphia 76ers in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.


Motoring for a Fall
LEAD: The Romans cooked in leaden pots, and so the empire fell, done in by lead poisoning.
This theory won't beguile people who know that the Roman Empire was as old as biblical Methuselah and that old age eventually fells everything, empires and redwoods included.

LEAD: The Navy has determined that the turret aboard the battleship Iowa that was severely damaged by a gunpowder explosion two weeks ago can be repaired, but officials said today that because they had not yet figured out the cost, no decision has been made whether to go ahead.

Factory Orders Rose 0.7% in March
LEAD: Orders to United States factories for manufactured goods increased seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Government reported today, led by strong aircraft orders.
But analysts still saw signs in the report that the economy was cooling off.


Citicorp Rates Off at Auction
LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, which were up and down in April, began the month of May yesterday with a modest decline.


Judge Rejects Effort to Stop S.I. Navy Port
LEAD: Citing national security concerns, a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday removed the last major obstacle to the Navy's plan to open a new port on Staten Island that critics have said will be a base for nuclear weapons in New York harbor.


SIHANOUK PLACES CONDITION ON RULE
LEAD: In talks on the future of Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-backed Government, today requested further constitutional changes before he would be willing to return, the Cambodian Prime Minister said.


Walt Disney Net Up 24.1%
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said today that its net income in the quarter ended March 31 increased 24.1 percent over the corresponding period last year, largely because of sharply higher profits at its theme parks.


Macmillan Appointment
LEAD: Donald L. Fruehling on Monday was named the president of the new Maxwell-Macmillan International Group.
He will be reponsible for the company's hard-cover and paperback book publishing businesses outside the United States, and he will continue to serve as a director and group vice president of Macmillan Inc.

Julia Smith, 78, Composer and Pianist, Dies
LEAD: Julia Smith, a composer, pianist, teacher and writer on music, was found dead of a heart attack in her Riverside Drive apartment Thursday morning.
She was 78 years old.
Miss Smith was born in Denton, Tex.
She was graduated from North Texas State University in 1930 and completed her education at the Juilliard Graduate School in New York and at New York University, where she received her Ph.D.

Jersey City Mayor and Three Guilty in Officer's Demotion
LEAD: Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Federal District Court here ruled today that Mayor Anthony R. Cucci of Jersey City and three other officials violated the constitutional rights of a detective by demoting him because he supported an opponent of Mr.
Cucci in the 1985 elections.
The judge ordered the defendants to give the officer, Abad Perez, $29,298 in back pay and damages and to reinstate him.

She was 85 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens.

Staff Move by Sears
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company's Merchandise Group said it would move 1,500 employees from its catalogue division out of its Sears Tower headquarters to a Sears-owned building in Skokie, Ill.
Initially, some 650 catalogue advertising and merchandising employees will move between Aug. 1 and Sept. 15.
Other parts of the catalogue group are set to move later to the Skokie building and another location, the retailer said.

LEAD: Maureen McGovern may be the closest thing that America has produced to a homegrown Julie Andrews.
Unflappably demure and upbeat, the 39-year-old singer - who gave her first solo concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening - possesses formidable technical resources of which the most spectacular is a pop coloratura register from which she delivers piccololike tones in perfect pitch.

LEAD: The Washington Capitals yesterday ended speculation that Coach Bryan Murray might be let go because his Patrick Division championship team was eliminated in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs by the Philadelphia Flyers in six games.

Review/Television; An Imaginary Meeting of Dr. King and Malcolm X
LEAD: If the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X had met for an hour or so, what would they have found to say to each other?
Jeff Stetson undertook to answer that question in a 1987 one-act play, an American Playhouse adaptation of which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channels 13 and 49.
Although neither the clash of principles nor the affinity of personalities portrayed here offers any surprises, the scenes in which the men reveal the shared pain behind their very different philosophies of the racial struggle are compelling.

LEAD: Andy Warhol's ''Shot Red Marilyn,'' was auctioned last night at Christie's for $4.07 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist.
The 40-inch-square painting brought double the price expected and was the highest sum paid for a work in Christie's sale which totaled $31.8 million.

They arose some 15 years ago in the wake of the New York Pro Musica, and hence represent the fragmentation of the early-music scene here since the demise of that estimable institution.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: MY brother-in-law speaks of going to Scotland again this fall.
He and my sister were there two years ago, he playing golf and she looking for tall people with hazel eyes and crooked teeth.
It was a joke we had.
Our paternal grandfather, who died before we were born, came from Scotland, and anyone who fit his description was, we figured, a relative.

Ruotsalainen a Devil?
LEAD: Reijo Ruotsalainen, the Finnish defenseman, who played for the Rangers for five seasons, is expected to sign with the Devils today.
The 28-year-old Ruotsalainen, an offense-minded defenseman, scored 89 goals and had 217 assists in five seasons with the Rangers.
He was traded to the Edmonton Oilers by the Rangers in 1986 and won a Stanley Cup with the Oilers in 1987 after joining them late in the season.


Demand for Used Jets Sends Prices Soaring
LEAD: Frustrated by huge backlogs for delivery of new planes from manufacturers like the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, many airlines have decided to buy used jetliners.
And despite growing concern about structural problems in aging aircraft, demand is higher than ever, causing prices to skyrocket.

LEAD: In a development that seems likely to solidify Federal Reserve opposition to further increases in interest rates in the near term, a new nationwide survey by the central bank finds little inflationary pressure from wages or other manufacturing costs and no economic bottlenecks.

LEAD: Sheik Abbas Ben Sheik el-Hocine, rector of the Great Mosque of Paris and considered the top Muslim religious authority in France, died tonight after suffering a heart attack, officials said.
He was 77.


Andrews and Burnett To Give Carnegie Show
LEAD: Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett -who last appeared together at Carnegie Hall 27 years ago - will give a benefit performance for the hall on June 8 at 8 P.M.
ABC-TV will tape the show for broadcast in the fall.


Albany Allows 'Poison Pills'
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo today signed into law a bill allowing New York corporations to institute ''poison pill'' shareholder rights plans.


Mark D. Hirsch, 78, Ex-Professor of History
LEAD: Mark D. Hirsch, a retired professor of history at Bronx Community College, died of a heart attack April 22 while traveling in Nanjing, China.
He was 78 years old and lived in Yonkers.


Clippers-Walton Suit Ordered to Arbitration
LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers and Bill Walton were ordered yesterday by a Superior Court judge to go to arbitration in an attempt to resolve differences over a lawsuit in which the Clippers say Walton failed to live up to his contract.


Bronx Firehouse Closes Pending a Court Ruling
LEAD: A South Bronx firehouse was shut last night after a state appellate court denied a motion to prevent the city from closing the firehouse while a lower court judge decides its permanent status.


BUSH IS CRITICIZED ON CAPITOL HILL OVER NATO DISPUTE
LEAD: The leaders of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees said today that President Bush was wrong to oppose talks with the Soviet Union on curbing short-range nuclear weapons.


A Rarity by Rossini Is Revived to Acclaim
LEAD: Rossini wrote ''Zelmira'' in 1822 for the woman he loved, and took it triumphantly to Vienna, London and Paris.
But that was almost the end of ''Zelmira,'' a dramatic opera that was neither lost nor forgotten, but is virtually unperformed today.
For more than a century, musical directors and singers have gone out of their way to avoid this complicated and majestic work.


Ravitch Formally Joins Mayoral Race
LEAD: Calling himself an independent outsider and ''the guy the politicians have called on to solve the problems,'' Richard Ravitch formally announced his candidacy for mayor yesterday.


Green Sees Turnout as Signal To Revamp School Boards
LEAD: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr.
Richard R. Green, said yesterday that the low turnout in the community school board elections Tuesday appeared to demonstrate that the current structure was unacceptable and needed substantial change.


S.E.C. Moves Against Four
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged four former officials of the Systems and Computer Technology Corporation with preparing false and misleading quarterly financial statements for the Malvern, Pa., computer services company in 1984.


Wilander Takes Slide From No. 1 to Steppingstone
LEAD: It might not be long before tennis fans begin calling Mats Wilander Magic for the disappearing act he has been practicing this year.
In what may be the most dramatic turnabout in the era of open tennis, the quiet, introspective Swede has gone from No. 1 in the world to a steppingstone in just eight months.

LEAD: After months of sifting through job offers from Wall Street firms, Michael D. Madden, the former head of investment banking at Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company, has decided to join Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as managing director of its investment banking division.


Market Place; Investors Favor Savings Industry
LEAD: FEW industries have as much going against them as the savings and loan business.
But many savings institution stocks have come alive in the last month, and the group has outperformed the stock market.

LEAD: When the field for the 115th Kentucky Derby steps onto the track at Churchill Downs Saturday, nearly all eyes and wagers will be on two colts who were born just four days and two miles apart.

LEAD: In 1902, when the Algonquin Hotel opened at 59 West 44th Street in Manhattan, it was thought to be the most modern home away from home in the world.

Judge in North Trial Extends Jury's Hours to Speed Verdict
LEAD: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that he had extended the jury's working hours but would take no other steps to hasten its deliberations.
The jurors today completed their 11th day of deliberations.


Marine Pilot Killed in Crash
LEAD: A military jet crashed during a training flight today, and the pilot died from injuries suffered when he ejected moments earlier, Marines Corps officials said.
The single-seat AV-8 Harrier crashed about 9 A.M. near a training airfield at the Marine Corps Recruiting Depot near Beaufort.
The pilot, whose name was withheld, was one of 25,600 marines and sailors taking part in the Solid Shield '89 training exercise, which began today and is scheduled to run until May 20.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company said it would open 20 Brand Central home appliance and electronics ''superstores-within-a-store'' in the Chicago area within 60 days.
These outlets will be in addition to the 110 that opened within the last month, Sears said.
The first Brand Central superstores, which opened last year in 18 Sears stores in Indiana and Kentucky, were an ''instant success,'' the retailer said.

7th Inning Tough Stretch for Mets
LEAD: An unruly fan tumbled out of the stands in the seventh inning and stumbled across the outfield grass at Shea Stadium last night before finally exiting, in the company of security guards, past the fence in right field.
Sid Fernandez, his routine interrupted, stood on the mound and watched, although it was impossible to tell whether he did so in anger, amusement or indifference.

LEAD: For the second time in a week, ABC television has decided to pull a special hourlong program dramatizing real-life episodes from its prime-time schedule.

Review/Museums; Goya's Dark Vision at the Met, and What's to Be Seen Elsewhere
LEAD: There are not many artists the American public would rather see than Goya.
Much of the 19th-century French art so beloved in America begins with him.
His appeal cuts across classes and styles.
He was at once court painter, protest artist and visionary expressionist whose art is bigger than any style he used or cause he served.

Bowater Stock Up
LEAD: The shares of Bowater Inc., the paper producer based in Darien, Conn., rose yesterday on rumors that someone was accumulating its stock, analysts said.
Bowater rose $1.50, to $33, on the New York Stock Exchange.
More than 1.9 million shares were traded, making it the fourth-most-active issue.
Abitibi-Price Inc., the large Canadian forest products company, was mentioned as a possible suitor, but the company declined to comment.

21 Strikers Arrested at Mine
LEAD: State police arrested 21 strikers today for blocking the entrance to a mine run by the Pittston Coal Group.
The demonstrators, members of the striking United Mine Workers, were trying to maintain pressure on the mining company as federally mediated talks over a new contract were beginning.
The strike began April 5, It affects about 1,500 miners in Virginia and West Virginia.

Why the North Verdict Is Welcome
LEAD: The jury's verdict in the Oliver North trial is cause for satisfaction, not elation or disappointment.
The ambitious former National Security Council staff member is guilty of three serious felonies but not guilty of nine others.
He emerges as neither national hero nor villain.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the possibility of tuition increases at the State University of New York and the City University of New York misstated the current rates.
Full-time students in the State University system pay $1,350 a year; those in the city system pay $1,250.

LEAD: Oliver L. North will lose the $1,900 monthly pension he draws as a retired Marine lieutenant colonel if his conviction is upheld.

LEAD: The dollar finished at varied levels against major foreign currencies yesterday as Federal Reserve intervention and a comment by the central bank's vice chairman sent mixed signals to the markets.


Judge Upholds X-Rated Videos
LEAD: A Federal district judge has dealt a blow to the Government's anti-pornography campaign by ruling that selling sexually graphic videos does not violate community standards in an area as diverse as Los Angeles.

500 Years of Art, for Seeing or for Sale
LEAD: ART at this moment is almost everywhere in Manhattan, and almost everything is art.
It may come with august credentials -in the auction houses, quite often, and in the Goya show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - and downtown it may come with no credentials at all (and possibly be none the worse for that).


Favored Easy Goer Is an Outsider of Sorts
LEAD: A field of 16, ranging from sublime favorites to ridiculous long-shots, was entered today for the 115th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.


On Stage
LEAD:  Back to Brecht It's definite: rehearsals in August, the National Theater in Washington in September, and Broadway before Thanksgiving for a new version of ''The Threepenny Opera,'' starring Sting as MacHeath.


CNW to Meet With Suitors
LEAD: The CNW Corporation said today that it was meeting with potential bidders other than Japonica Partners L.P., the investor group that is suing CNW on charges that it is misleading stockholders about attempts to find a buyer.
Japonica, which is based in


Former Florida Prison Guard, 31, Is Electrocuted as Killer of Girl, 8
LEAD: A former prison guard who suffocated an 8-year-old girl 11 years ago was executed today in Florida's electric chair.

LEAD: An old man faces death.
A baby is born.
Lovers quarrel.
Hope is lost, then regained.

Capital Mayor's Friend Faces New Drug Trafficking Charges
LEAD: A Federal grand jury today returned a new indictment against Charles Lewis, a former city employee and friend of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., adding one count of conspiracy and five counts of distributing cocaine to the 10 charges made against him earlier.


Investors Are Seen For Sabre System
LEAD: The chairman of the AMR Corporation, Robert L. Crandall, said about 20 companies were considering investing in a reservations system that AMR's American Airlines unit will own with Delta Air Lines Inc.
Some overseas airlines and smaller American carriers are among those weighing bids, he said after delivering a speech in New York on Wednesday.


The Law; 'The People's Court': The Case for and Against It
LEAD: It is a case of art altering life. ''The People's Court'' is an eight-year-old syndicated adventure in courtroom verite, the only such television program to use real people, real small-claims cases and a retired judge.


3 Suspects Are Arrested in Rapes
LEAD: A Staten Islander who was recently paroled was charged yesterday with raping a 15-year-old girl and may be charged in similar attacks on two other women in Manhattan, the police said.


Pennsylvania Move On Sale by Eastern
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Attorney General said he had sought court action to block Eastern Airlines' $70 million sale of most of its gates at Philadelphia International Airport to USAir Group Inc.
Eastern, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, has been in bankruptcy since March 9, five days after its machinists went on strike.


Review/Film; An Innocent's Journey on the Rocky Road to Miss Right
LEAD: ''Getting It Right,'' the new English comedy opening today at the 57th Street Playhouse and other theaters, is about Gavin Lamb, a West End London hairdresser, 31 years old and still an innocent when it comes to sex.
Gavin is terrified of people, especially of beautiful young women.
He lives at home with Mum and

LEAD: The law library of the City Bar Association in New York has become one of the first in the country to install devices that read text aloud to blind lawyers and type telephone communications for the deaf.

EXECUTIVES
LEAD: *
El Paso Natural Gas Co. appointed John M. Craig senior vice president of marketing, gas supply and joint operations.


VOWS TO FIGHT TILL 'VINDICATED'; BUSH DENIES A CONTRA AID DEAL  Colonel Faces Jail
LEAD: Oliver L. North, the cocky marine who became the Reagan Administration's covert guardian of the Nicaraguan rebels, was convicted today of shredding documents and two other crimes but was acquitted of nine other charges stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the continuing protests at the City University of New York misidentified the City College building shown.
It was the North Academic Center, not the administration building.


Retail Sales Gained in April On Strong Apparel Buying
LEAD: With reinvigorated consumer buying of women's apparel, many of the nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported strong April sales, prompting analysts to predict an improved second quarter.


Frank O'Rourke, Is Dead at 72; Author of Westerns and Mysteries
LEAD: Frank O'Rourke, a prolific, versatile and popular writer of novels, westerns and mysteries and earlier of short stories and sports fiction, died after a long bout with asthma on April 27 at his home in Tucson, Ariz.
He was 72 years old.

Fraud Term Won't Be Cut
LEAD: A Federal judge Tuesday rejected a request to cut the eight-year sentence of David Bloom, a financial adviser who admitted diverting $10 million of investors' money to live in lavish style.

The Guilty Verdict
LEAD: Please, wait - just a few questions about that gang of thugs arrested for beating and raping the jogger in the park.
Who ruled they are guilty?
What judge listened to the arguments of their defense lawyers?
When did he make the crucial decision about admissibility of their confessions?
What did he then say to the jury before they filed out to consider a verdict?


New Buyout Fund Set by Brentwood
LEAD: Brentwood Associates, a Los Angeles-based investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts and venture capital investments, announced yesterday that it had completed a $140 million leveraged management buyout fund.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $1.20 billion, to $304.17 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The 141 institutional funds had an increase of $1.20 billion, to $75.5 billion.
The assets of the 232 general-purpose funds were up by $119.80 million, to $99.78 billion.

Schoenberg and Liszt
LEAD: The pianist Emanuel Ax is to play Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' Sonata (Op. 28), Schoenberg's Six Pieces (Op. 9), the Brahms Third Sonata and works by Liszt at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.
Tickets are $11 to $20.
Information: 874-6770.


Bush Hopes NATO Allies Find Common Ground
LEAD: President Bush expressed hope today that the Western alliance could work out a common position on short-range nuclear missiles at a NATO summit meeting this month.
But he did not indicate any change in the Administration's opposition to negotiations on such weapons.

Israeli Policemen Faulted in Fatal West Bank Raid
LEAD: A paramilitary border-police unit that shot and killed five Palestinians in a bungled raid in the West Bank last month opened fire without restraint before first trying to subdue demonstrators by other means, a military investigation concluded today.

Ruble Flood Is Criticized
LEAD: The Soviet Union has printed so much new paper money that it could buy all the goods in Western Europe if the Europeans would accept the ruble at the official rate, a group of economists said today.

A Broom Should Be For Brooming
LEAD: As the Philadelphia buzzer was groaning to signal game's end, and the ample Charles Barkley was toppling like a tree to the floor in disappointment, someone on the Knicks found a broom in the vicinity of his bench Tuesday night and a bunch of the players went off the court pushing it.
