Metro Datelines; Racial Task Force For Schools Is Urged
LEAD: The Connecticut Board of Education has voted to ask Gov.
William A. O'Neill to appoint a task force to study ways to desegregate public schools in Connecticut.


Auctions
LEAD: Act II of the May auctions extravaganza begins tomorrow, offering major Impressionist and modern artworks, Art Deco furnishings, a Manhattan town house designed by Philip Johnson, tribal art and a bounty of prints ranging from Rembrandts to Rauschenbergs.
The sales follow a week of record-breaking contemporary-art auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's, and are organized by these houses and by Habsburg, Feldman, a two-year-old Geneva-based concern that is holding its first art sale in Manhattan.

LEAD: Not only a call for democracy, but also anger over inflation and corruption, seemed to impel the tens of thousands of workers who joined students today in demonstrating in Tiananmen Square in the center of the capital.

Review/Midtown Galleries; Four Blocks on 57th Street, a Treasure House of Modern Art
LEAD: There may be more Old Masters uptown and more contemporary art downtown, but the galleries along 57th Street continue to provide as comprehensive a view of 20th-century art as can be found almost anywhere in the world.
One need only traverse the four blocks between Seventh Avenue and Park Avenue to realize that this remains the case.

Review/Cabaret; A Gilded Bag of Ditties
LEAD: Christopher Mason, the much-publicized society songwriter whose ditties poke mild fun at New York's rich and powerful, brought his bag of tunes to the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday for a three-week engagement.


Organists' Benefit
LEAD: The American Guild of Organists is presenting a marathon benefit concert to raise money for AIDS patient care tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. at St.
Peter's Lutheran Church, in the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.
Among the organists who are to perform are Harold Stover, Leonard Raver, Donald Joyce, Gerre Hancock, Sarah Davies, Gwendolyn Toth, William Whitehead, Walter Hilse and John Weaver.


Knicks Anticipate Facing Bulls in Next Round
LEAD: The Knicks went back to work yesterday and the subject was Michael Jordan.


Kohlberg, Kravis Cuts Kroger Stake
LEAD: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company, which owned nearly 10 percent of the Kroger Company from a takeover attempt, has apparently sold some of its shares.
A block of Kroger stock totaling 7.8 million shares was sold on Wednesday to an unidentified buyer on the New York Stock Exchange.

Rape - the Silence Is Criminal
LEAD: The brutal rape and beating of a young woman who was left for dead by a teen-age gang was the most vicious in a series of assaults in Central Park on April 19.
It was the only one involving sexual violence.
Explanations that rely on race or class alone miss the key role that gen-der played: The jogger was victimized because she was a woman, and the boys apparently acted out of a misguided notion of how to prove their manhood.

Software Developer In I.B.M. Accord
LEAD: Interactive Images Inc., a developer of software for I.B.M.
PC-compatible computers, signed a development and licensing agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation.
The company, based in Woburn, Mass., said I.B.M. would become a minority owner under an accord that covers its Easel program.


Canadians Open 9-Mile Rail Tunnel
LEAD: Canada inaugurated the longest rail tunnel in the Western Hemisphere today, completing a task begun in haste and nationalistic anxiety more than a century ago.


Johnson's Home Run Ends It In 10th
LEAD: Months ago, the trade rumors were fierce and frequent and his next supposed place of employment changed nearly daily.
Howard Johnson, understanding he couldn't determine where he might play, resolved to control completely the one place he'd have to make his living no matter what uniform he wore: the small chalk rectangle called the batter's box.


Long Trail of the Iran-Contra Case
LEAD:  Aug. 4, 1981: Maj.
Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps is assigned to the White House with the National Security Council.
December 1981: President Reagan signs a ''finding'' authorizing a covert Central Intelligence Agency operation to support the Nicaraguan rebels.
December 1982:


Bell Suspended
LEAD: George Bell, the Toronto Blue Jay outfielder, has been suspended for two games, Bobby Brown, the American League president, announced yesterday.


Campeau Action In May Dispute
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation said it had filed a complaint against the May Department Stores Company over a disagreement related to May's purchase of the Filene's and Foley's chains from Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. unit.
The complaint, filed by Campeau and Federated in Federal District Court in New York, seeks a judgment on whether the agreement provides for certain adjustments in the amount of money

Fund Officials Warn Exxon
LEAD: Representatives of the three leading New York City pension funds threatened to vote their six million shares of stock in the Exxon Corporation against management at the shareholders meeting May 18 if executives do not demonstrate that they will take steps to avoid accidents like the Valdez oil spill.


After a Cliffhanger Countdown, Shuttle Launches a Venus Probe
LEAD: After waiting nearly an hour for the clouds to part, the astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis rocketed into orbit today and sent a radar-mapping spacecraft on a 15-month, 795-million-mile journey to Venus.

LEAD: The Mozartean Players, an early-instruments ensemble, is to play a Mozart Violin Sonata (K. 454), a Beethoven String Trio (Op. 9, No. 3), and two trios by Haydn (Hob. XV:15 and Hob. XV:29) tonight at 8 o'clock at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: Reijo Ruotsalainen ended a two-year absence from the National Hockey League and signed a contract with the Devils today, said General Manager Lou Lamoriello.

COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: The General Electric Company's aircraft engine division announced new orders totaling $355 million, as its orders so far this year match those for all of 1988.
More than $5 billion in new jet engine orders have been awarded this year to G.E. and CFM International, a G.E. venture with Snecma, the French manufacturer.

Gibbons, Green Separation
LEAD: The co-founders of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen - Leonard I. Green and Edward W. Gibbons - are splitting up, they announced yesterday.
The firm, established in 1969, was one of the early progenitors of the leveraged buyout movement.
Among the companies it has taken private are the Ohio Mattress Company, Budget Rent-a-Car and Kash n' Karry Food Stores


SOUNDS AROUND TWON
LEAD:  McCorkle's Pop-Jazz Susannah McCorkle, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902).
A perceptive pop-jazz vocalist with buttery-smooth phrasing, Susannah McCorkle is performing material from her new album, ''No More Blues'' (Concord Jazz).
High points of the record include a wistfully caressing ''P.S., I Love You'' and a bubbly ''Fascinating Rhythm.


A Soldier and a Prison Nurse Are Killed in 2 Ulster Blasts
LEAD: An I.R.A. bomb exploded near a road today, killing a soldier and wounding two civilians, the police said.
In a second attack, a prison nurse died when a bomb exploded under his car.

Review/Film; Ken Russell Goes Back To Lawrence For Love
LEAD: From the early moments of his new film, when a glittering rainbow arches over emerald green meadows, it is apparent that Ken Russell is the purest interpreter D. H. Lawrence could have hoped for.
That is not unadulterated praise. ''The Rainbow,'' adapted from Lawrence's 1915 novel, comes saddled with all the author's strengths and flaws - heavy symbolism, a feel for the land in the mortal grip of industrialization, swift turns of emotion, high-blown speeches about how men and women might love while remaining independent.

LEAD: The Tony Awards administration committee decided yesterday that Bill Irwin's ''Largely New York'' would be eligible in the category of best play even though it has no words.
Mr.
Irwin has said that the comedy at the St.
James Theater is ''full of language but none of it written.'' The Tony nominations will be announced Monday.


2 Hurt in Laboratory Blast
LEAD: Two explosions injured two graduate students conducting an experiment at Northwestern University on Wednesday, starting a fire, Fire Department officials said.
The explosions apparently resulted from the experiments, said Mike Tirrell, a spokesman for Northwestern.
The victims had been working with an ether-like solvent, said Pat Tremmel, another Northwesten spokeswoman.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page headline on April 15 about an Israeli police ban on attendance at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem by nearly all Palestinian residents of the occupied territories described the action incorrectly.
It was not the first such ban.
The headline, ''For the First Time, Israel Restricts Palestinians' Freedom of Worship,'' was also imprecise in describing the limits placed on the Palestinians' freedom of worship; the restriction affected access to Al Aksa

Copter Crash Kills 5 Marines
LEAD: An American military helicopter making a night training flight hit a high-tension power line and crashed in southern France, killing five marines, officials said today.
The UH-1 Huey, from the amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal currently in port in Toulon, exploded when it hit a hillside about 9:45 P.M.

LEAD: The crucial negotiations to reduce Mexico's bank debt have been moving slowly, participants say, because the commercial banks have objected to the size of Mexico's proposal and are still uncertain about what incentives they will get from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

New York's Cool Blues, With a Hint Of Memphis
LEAD: Blues music usually comes with a geographic tag, indicating a school of musicians: Chicago blues, Texas blues, Memphis blues and West Coast blues all have their masters, their rules and their sounds.
New York blues - raw, gospel-influenced and conversant with jazz - blossomed after World War II until the early 60's and yielded a huge amount of music.

Tears, Not Cheers, in Argentina
LEAD: Argentina's May 14 Presidential election should be cause for celebration.
For the first time in 60 years, a civilian President will have survived long enough in office to see his successor elected.
Raul Alfonsin has done more than merely survive.
He has skillfully guided Argentina to a freer, more tolerant, more democratic civic culture.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Pearls as Gifts
LEAD: Pearls have never been more popular, and they are likely to be welcomed on Mother's Day.

These are grown in oysters after the insertion of beads, causing the oyster to cover the bead with coats of nacre.

LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Open Mind Takes Kentucky Oaks: Open Mind, the nation's top 3-year-old filly, ran down her entrymate, Imaginary Lady, in the stretch yesterday to win the $231,100 Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.
Open Mind, last year's champion 2-year-old filly and unbeaten in four starts at 3, rallied from far back on a sloppy track to score by 2 1/4 lengths.

Melee Site Quiet, but Police Stand Guard
LEAD: More than 200 police officers stood stoically in a cold rain on the Lower East Side yesterday, guarding a two-block area around a demolished building where squatters used to live, while a bulldozer slowly chewed through the rubble of the site.


Commodity Inquiry Said to Have a Second Focus
LEAD: An important focus of an investigation of traders at four of New York's commodity exchanges that was disclosed Thursday is an activity that is the commodity market's equivalent of insider trading, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.


Stake in USAir
LEAD: Michael H. Steinhardt, the New York money manager, has again increased his holdings in the USAir Corporation past 5 percent, from 4.6 percent to 5.18 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Steinhardt said that he had purchased the shares of the Alexandria, Va., airline company for investment purposes only.

LEAD: The Bush Administration complained today that South Korea was continuing to maintain its currency, the won, at an artificially low level that gives it a trade advantage against the United States.

LEAD: The machinists' union at Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it opposed the buyouts or restructuring programs for the carrier that had been proposed so far and that it would begin to develop a plan of its own to gain control of the airline with a friendly investor.

Toni Morrison Lecture
LEAD: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Toni Morrison is to lecture on ''Women, Race and Memory'' at Queens College, 65-30 Kissena Boulevard, at 9:30 A.M.
Monday.
The lecture is part of a series commemorating civil rights workers killed in Mississippi in 1964, one of whom was a Queens undergraduate.
The event, in the Rosenthal Library Lecture Hall, is free and open to the public.

Review/Dance; Balanchine Revival and a Birthday
LEAD: The New York City Ballet revived George Balanchine's 1972 version of ''Danses Concertantes'' for the first time since 1977 on Thursday night.
But first things first.
When members of the audience found an insert in their programs that said ''Happy Birthday Lincoln!'', no one thought that Honest Abe was being honored three months late.

LEAD: ''It is not hard to kill Americans or Frenchmen.
It is a bit difficult to kill Israelis.'' - Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of the Iranian Parliament.  [ 3:4. ]


N-Plant Reports Water Leak
LEAD: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, out of service for repairs, reported a water leak today inside the plant's drywell.
No radioactivity was released during the incident, which lasted from 2:40 A.M. to 3:10 A.M., plant officials said.
Operators were filling reactor systems with water for testing when safety valves began leaking, said a statement by GPU Nuclear Corporation.


Rozelle Search Grows
LEAD: Six weeks after Pete Rozelle announced that he was stepping down as N.F.L. commissioner as soon as a successor could be found, the owners' committee formed to find a successor has decided it needs some help.

LEAD: The dollar, which continues to baffle many traders and economists with its persistent strength, climbed again yesterday despite an unexpected rise in the unemployment rate and repeated rounds of dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve and other central banks.


Murdoch to Sell Travel Businesses
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its travel-related publications to Reed International P.L.C., Britain's largest publishing company, for $825 million.


COMPANY NEWS
LEAD:  Farah in Talks On Company Sale Farah Inc., a maker of jeans and popular sportswear, said it was in substantive talks to sell the company for at least $69 million.
Farah, which makes clothes under its own name and the Generra label, gave no other details.
A full buyout of Farah would value the company at $69 million based on its stock price today of $11.125, unchanged from

War Stills Ancient Villages on Kabul's Lifeline
LEAD: After a decade of war, the horrors of Afghanistan have become widely known.
But here in the mountains of the Hindu Kush, along a river valley fabled for its harsh beauty since the time of Jesus, recent fighting has left a scene of devastation that goes beyond what westerners have previously known about the conflict.


Cavaliers Edge Bulls in Overtime to Force Game 5
LEAD: Larry Nance scored 27 points and Mark Price added 24 to offset a 50-point performance by Michael Jordan tonight, and the Cleveland Cavaliers evened their three-of-five-game playoff series against Chicago at two apiece with a 108-105 overtime victory.


Pit Bull Kills Boy, 3
LEAD: Dustin Webb, 3 years old, has died of wounds inflicted by his grandparents' pit bull terrier, the authorities said.
Dustin died Thursday at John Sealy Hospital in nearby Galveston a day after he was attacked by the dog in the backyard of his grandparents' home.
His grandmother, Geraldine Webb, was in the house.


Carson Pirie Shift Weighed
LEAD: The flagship store of Carson Pirie Scott &amp; Company on State Street in Chicago may be converted to a multi-use real estate development, according to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by P. A. Bergner &amp; Company, which this week agreed to buy Carson Pirie Scott for $453 million in cash.


Industrial Countries to Aid Poorer Nations on Ozone
LEAD: The Western industrialized countries and Japan agreed today to help developing nations adhere to a worldwide ban on a class of chemicals that is destroying the protective layer of ozone in the atmosphere.


Latin Festival
LEAD: Music of the Andean highland will be performed at 8 P.M. this evening as part of a monthlong Latin festival at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
The musical group Inkhay will combine the ancient music of the Incas with European instrumentation.
Tickets are $10.

Review/Music; A Leinsdorf Program Gives Instrumentalists Their Hour
LEAD: The knack for putting together consistently imaginative concert programs is one that only a few conductors ever acquire.
Erich Leinsdorf, as New York Philharmonic audiences have long known, is one of the few.
It is a little odd: he has access to the same music libraries as everyone else.
But his long experience, catholic sympathies and thoughtfully skewered view of the orchestral repertory combine to give many of his programs a fascinating look and, often enough, a satisfying sound as well.


Chrysler Agrees to Sponsor Toned-Down 'Nightingales'
LEAD: Aaron Spelling Productions has agreed to tone down the sexually suggestive scenes in ''Nightingales,'' and the Chrysler Corporation has agreed in principle to sponsor the show.

LEAD: What's to become of New York City's five borough presidents, whom headline writers call ''the beeps''?

Meanwhile the five panicked beeps toss up self-serving ideas that offend common sense.

Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat
LEAD: Rastafarian faith becomes liberation theology in the songs of Bunny Wailer.
Mr.
Wailer frames political questions in moral terms, naming Lucifer as the cause of human conflict and insisting that the struggle for human rights is the struggle of good against evil.


2 Brooklyn Rape Suspects Charged in 2d Case
LEAD: Two young men accused of raping a woman at knifepoint and throwing her from the roof of a three-story building in Brooklyn were charged yesterday with raping another woman on a roof two doors away in March, the authorities said.


About New York; Patches of Light In a Struggle Against the Fog
LEAD: ''The mind is a very strange thing, and the mind after a brain injury is even stranger,'' said Scott Paoli.
He should know.
Two years ago, a 14-year-old driving illegally crashed into the Army captain's car, damaging his head enough to cause a coma.


QUAYLE, IN ALASKA, VISITS SITE OF SPILL
LEAD: On the way back to Washington from his trip to Asia, Vice President Dan Quayle stopped Thursday evening to look at a blackened beach on Prince William Sound, where cleanup crews are working doggedly against oil that washes up on shore again with each new tide.


What China's Students Want
LEAD: China's youth have taken to the streets in a stunning challenge to authority.
They feel they are being asked to forgo the higher living standards enjoyed by non-Communist Chinese and the new freedoms enjoyed by many non-Chinese Communists.
No wonder they are in open revolt.
And it's not just students.


INSIDE
LEAD:  China Reports on Protests


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the space shuttle misstated the reason its launching had to occur by 2:52 P.M. or be postponed.
The concern was that emergency landing fields in Spain and Morocco would grow dark, not that Earth and Venus would move out of proper alignment.


Judge Withdraws
LEAD: The Federal judge who criticized baseball's investigation of Pete Rose yesterday removed himself from handling the criminal case of a man who once lived in Rose's house.


Producing and Shaping Superconductor Material
LEAD: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology received a patent this week for a method of shaping high-temperature superconducting material into wire, coil, sheet and other useful forms.
M.I.T. had announced previously that it would receive the patent, but it was not issued until Tuesday.

Promoting 'Femininity'
LEAD: When a company refuses to promote a woman, who must prove that the decision did not turn on illegal sex discrimination?
The Supreme Court now rules that the woman making the claim must first show that illegal bias played some role.
Once that is shown, however, the burden is on the company to justify its decision.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration has temporarily closed Eastern Airlines' maintenance operation at Kennedy International Airport after finding that the carrier had failed to insure that its planes were properly maintained there.

Corrections
LEAD: A New York Presidential Trivia Quiz in Weekend on April 28 misstated the number of American Presidents who have married while in office.
Presidents Grover Cleveland and Woodrow Wilson as well as John Tyler were married in office.

LEAD: The unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey rose sharply last month, in large part because more people were seeking jobs, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

LEAD: Bobby Beathard, who built the Washington Redskins by relying on his instincts, said yesterday that he had resigned as general manager for the same reason.

LEAD: The second annual Port Washington Tennis Academy Tournament of Champions began play with doubles matches yesterday, featuring the return of John McEnroe, who spent some of his youth on those indoor courts on Long Island.
Port Washington redux was necessitated by another day of rain at Forest Hills, which forced postponement of the singles quarterfinals.


Fire Damages Mexican Palace
LEAD: A predawn fire in the legislative palace blazed out of control for more than an hour today, killing a security guard and heavily damaging the building, officials said.
The state press agency, Notimex, quoted Fire Chief Ignacio Ponce de Leon as saying the fire damaged at least 40 percent of the San Lazaro palace.

Rebuilt Cars: States Seek More Data For Buyers
LEAD: Legislation that requires automobile dealers to tell customers when a ''used'' car is actually a body shop's assemblage of salvaged parts has been approved by about two dozen states and is being considered by others.
The states are acting to cope with a boom in the unregulated market for rebuilt cars.


McCall's Sale to Diamandis Expected
LEAD: Reeling from a sharp decline in advertising revenue, McCall's magazine is being sold to Diamandis Communications Inc., perhaps as early as this weekend, magazine industry executives said yesterday.

Moscow May Get McDonald's by '90
LEAD: Moscow could have its first McDonald's fast-food restaurant by the end of the year, a spokesman for the joint-venture company Moskva McDonald's said.
The company, which plans to open 20 of the American-style hamburger restaurants in the capital, expects to finish work on a building on Pushkin Square in the center of the city by


Pretoria Won't Bend on Namibia
LEAD: South Africa today rejected a proposal by the United Nations Secretary General that its forces in Namibia stop their search for guerrillas and return to their bases.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of editing errors, an article on April 26 about American publishers' participation in the Iran Book Fair misidentified an official of the Oxford University Press and paraphrased her comments incorrectly.


I.B.M. Computers
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce two long-awaited new models in its Personal System/2 line on Tuesday, according to several industry executives close to the company.
One of the personal computers will be a portable based on the Intel 386 microprocessor chip.
This machine has been expected by many computer industry observers for a number of months.

Wicks Hurt in Accident
LEAD: Sidney Wicks, the former star forward at U.C.L.A. who played for Portland, Boston and San Diego in the National Basketball Association, was seriously injured yesterday morning when his car was struck by a truck carrying cement near San Diego, authorities said.


Script May Be All Easy Goer Follows Today
LEAD: It was shortly after 3:30 P.M. last Aug. 19, in front of the ancient and rickety wooden stands of Saratoga Race Track in upstate New York, that it began to look as if the 115th Kentucky Derby here at Churchill Downs might be different from most.


Dr. Koop's Legacy of Principle
LEAD: The skeptics and cynics, this page included, were wrong to fear that Surgeon General C. Everett Koop would use his office only as a pulpit for his anti-abortion views.
Throughout his seven years of service - he has now announced his retirement as of July - he has put medical integrity above personal value judgments and has been, indeed, the nation's First


Koch and Unions Approve Deal to Avoid Layoffs
LEAD: The Koch administration reached agreement with municipal union leaders yesterday on a plan that would save New York City $150 million a year in pension costs and avoid the layoffs of city employees in the coming fiscal year.


Bush Names Observers for Panama Election
LEAD: President Bush today appointed a 14-member delegation to observe the election in Panama on Sunday even though the Panamanian authorities warned that the observers would not be welcome.

Dr. John R. Heller Jr. Dies at 84; Headed National Cancer Institute
LEAD: Dr.
John R. Heller Jr., a former director of the National Cancer Institute and former president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, died Thursday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., five days after he suffered a stroke.
He was 84 years old and lived in Bethesda.

Banks to Offer Mexico Smaller Debt Reduction
LEAD: Mexico and its commercial bankers yesterday adjourned their talks on debt reduction for a week so the bankers could finish work on a proposal that would offer less than Mexico has sought.

Drexel Lost $167 Million In 1988, Court Papers Show
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. lost $167 million last year, according to documents released yesterday as part of a court case.
The loss would have been $261 million but for an accounting change related to the treatment of income taxes.


Turnout of 6% In School Vote Is Lowest Ever
LEAD: Despite an intensive effort to get a large turnout, fewer people voted in Tuesday's community school board elections in New York City than in any since decentralized school operation began in 1970, according to tentative figures released yesterday.

Christine Weston, 85, Author of Novels and Stories
LEAD: Christine Weston, a novelist and short-story writer whose work was set largely in India, died Wednesday in her apartment in Bangor, Me., her family reported.
She was 85 years old.


Mattingly, Balboni Power Yankees
LEAD: In their first four weeks, the Yankees were simply a team that depended on guile more than grit.
When they won, it was by moving runners from base to base, by slipping ahead early and hoping that their pitching held up.
But tonight at Comiskey Park, they tried a different approach.


Choral Concert
LEAD: Harry Saltzman is to conduct the Sine Nomine Singers in Brahms's Five Songs (Op. 104), Wolf's Six Sacred Songs, Berlioz's ''Death of Ophelia'' and Villa-Lobos's ''Cancoes Tipicas Brasileiras'' this evening at 9 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
Tickets are $12.
Information: 362-8719.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With picking the right sunscreen
LEAD: Sun-wary people face a bewildering array of protective lotions and creams this season.
The countless formulas made for different skin types include preparations for the eye area and lips, products that are waterproof or water-resistant, things made especially for children and colored nose coatings and lip protectors in flashy red, pink, yellow, orange, blue and green.

LEAD: The Police Chief's office in this seashore community was firebombed this week, the police said.

Wright, in a Speech at Home, Argues for His Achievements
LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright came home today to try to regain control of his image and shift the spotlight from his controversial business dealings to his war record, his 35 years of service in Congress and his political philosophy.


Burks and Clemens Topple Ryan
LEAD: In their second meeting in six days Roger Clemens beat Nolan Ryan, and Ellis Burks broke a seventh-inning tie with a run-scoring single tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox past the Texas Rangers, 7-6.


East Coast Is Facing Summer Brownouts
LEAD: The East Coast from Maryland to Maine faces an unusually high chance of brownouts and blackouts on hot days this summer because peak electric demand is rising so fast that it threatens to outstrip supply, electric utility experts say.

Bethlehem Steel in Pact With Union
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, reached an agreement with the United Steelworkers Union yesterday on a 50-month contract that will restore wages to the level union members enjoyed before agreeing to concessions seven years ago.

Shuttle's Venus Probe Is Right on Target
LEAD: Bound for Venus, the Magellan spacecraft cruised serenely far away from Earth today on a course so accurate that only a few normal correction maneuvers should be required over the next 15 months to reach the cloud-shrouded planet 795 million miles away.


Satyajit Ray Gives Ibsen A Bengali Spin. . . And Reflects on Life and Art
LEAD: Satyajit Ray is no campaigner, preferring to make films - ''a sort of social service'' - and to write, illustrate, design and publish an original magazine for children; but his values are essentially those of the earlier generation.
His gifted grandfather and father felt the same; they founded and edited the magazine until their premature deaths, generating a stream of stories, verses, riddles, drawings and paintings that easily bear comparison with Lewis Carroll's and Edward Lear's.


With Trumpet Fanfare, Feast Benefits the Arts
LEAD: AMID the fanfare of trumpets, guests in formal attire with brightly plumed masks, strolling musicians and mythological creatures including a griffin and a 27-foot dragon, a Renaissance feast was recently held to benefit the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood.

Emmett Colvin of Dallas, was married yesterday in New York to Helio Fred Garcia, a son of Anezia M. C. Garcia of New York and the late Dr.
Frederick C. H. Garcia.
The Rev.
F.
Forrester Church officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls.
The bride is a member of the education faculty at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: Some years ago, when ''Books Do Furnish a Room'' - the 10th novel in Anthony Powell's 12-volume sequence ''A Dance to the Music of Time'' - was published, an American reviewer, Marvin Mudrick, addressed himself in no uncertain terms to the limitations of the novel and of the sequence. ''Powell's method of getting on with the story must be the most ponderously inefficient of all time,'' Mudrick sweepingly began, noting that when a character is introduced,


Norway Details How Heavy Water Went to India
LEAD: Norwegian investigators say they have evidence that material that could be used in the manufacture of atomic weapons was illegally shipped to a Bombay company in 1983.
The company is listed in the Bombay telephone directory as an affiliate of the Indian Government's Department of Atomic Energy.


6 Are Dead as Tourist Plane Crashes in Jungle of Yucatan
LEAD: A plane carrying American tourists crash-landed in a remote jungle of the Yucatan Peninsula, killing 6 people and injuring 10, officials said today.


Memos to Meese Are Heard in Wedtech Trial
LEAD: E. Robert Wallach sat wordless in a Manhattan courtroom last week while a Federal prosecutor read a torrent of Mr.
Wallach's printed words into the record of the latest corruption trial involving the Wedtech Corporation.

Changing a View
LEAD: Liberals were wary and conservatives were elated when C. Everett Koop, an opponent of abortion, became the Surgeon General of the United States in 1981.
Last week, some liberals probably moaned and some conservatives no doubt sighed with relief when he announced that he would resign in July.
The 72-year-old pediatrician led attacks against smoking and the AIDS epidemic.


51% Support North Pardon
LEAD: A bare majority of the American public says President Bush should pardon Oliver L. North, according to a Gallup Poll conducted for Newsweek Magazine.


In Cornerstone's Shakespeare, Romeo Raps
LEAD: Until recently, the people of this small town in the southwest corner of Mississippi didn't see much in common between themselves and Shakespeare.
They read his plays in school and left it at that.
But when the Cornerstone Theater Company showed up and started building a stage in their local movie house, Shakespeare became the talk of the town.


A Cheerful Cafe in South Norwalk
LEAD: OPENING a new restaurant is an act of faith, and in the last few years there have been a number of such acts along Washington Street in South Norwalk.
The latest is Cafe Parfait, an informal storefront restaurant lodged a few doors from the corner of South Main Street.

Bank Builds New High-Rise
LEAD: THE 1968 HemisFair tower is still the tallest structure in San Antonio, but 10 blocks away workers are putting the finishing touches on an office high-rise that will be the city's tallest commercial building.

QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


Monuments of Medieval Strife
LEAD: TOURING the fortified towns, called bastides, in southwestern France, gives travelers a glimpse of medieval life and a chance to explore some of the earliest examples of urban planning, in a lovely rural setting.


In the Northeast, States Face Budget Squeezes
LEAD: Taxes and fees are going up $1 billion in New York State.
New Hampshire has frozen state hiring.
Elizabeth, N.J., has laid off about 225 city workers.
Here in Boston, officials expect hundreds of layoffs of teachers and municipal employees.


Baruch's Minority Alumni Seek a Separate Group
LEAD: A Federal court is weighing a dispute between the administration of Baruch College and a group of minority graduates who want to form their own alumni association.


Unknown Londoners and a Well-Known Russian (Peter Schaaf); (Eastfoto) (Richter)
LEAD: Last season Ian Hobson gave a three-concert series at Merkin Hall, attended by small but fascinated audiences.
He called it the ''London Piano School,'' and it was a retrospective of composers - some of them so minor that not even experts knew their names - who were active in London from about the 1760's to the 1870's.


Waiting for Motherhood
LEAD: THE flashing red lights of the school bus demanded that I stop.
As the children manuevered down that last large step, they absent-mindedly went their separate directions home.
The afternoon was sunny and warm.
The lights turned off and the line of cars proceeded.


Riding Appalachia's Rapids
LEAD: SOME come for the thrills.
Paddling madly, they raft the Gauley River's Pillow Rock rapid, dropping 25 feet in 20 yards, and shoot through Lost Paddle - a half mile of the highest-rated rapids run by commercial outfitters anywhere - and plunge 14 feet into Devil's Hole at Pure Screaming Hell.


Marilyn Quayle Is Tackling Disasters as Her Cause
LEAD: In Australia, Marilyn Quayle was briefed on floods and cyclones.
In Java, she flew over active volcanoes and stalked killer insects in rice paddies.
In Singapore, she sailed on a yacht around the harbor checking on oil tankers and contingency plans for spills.
In Thailand, she discussed reforestation.


Town Seeking An Open Beach
LEAD: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright.
If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.

By V. V. Harrison.
Illustrated. 254 pp.
New York:  Doubleday. $18.95.


Personal Service
LEAD: To the Editor:


A CHINESE LESSON IN POLITE PROTEST
LEAD: For anyone tempted to think that rebellious Chinese students must be fighting for capitalism and multi-party democracy, a banner fluttering over People's University marchers on Thursday was a rude shock.
It read, ''We firmly support the correct leadership of the Communist Party.''


City Gardens: Retreats Complete With Weeds
LEAD: Fifteen stories above Fifth Avenue, Earl Reiback has planted more than 500 petunias, impatiens, pansies and other flowering plants that will transform his terrace into a garden worthy of a country estate.

LEAD:  Elections on Generals: Panama and Bolivia Vote


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Auto Racing  Senna Gains Pole Spot: The world Formula One champion, Ayrton Senna of Brazil, gained the pole position for the Monaco Grand Prix as he blistered the Monte Carlo streets in a qualifying best in the second practice session yesterday.
Senna toured the twisting, 2.068-mile circuit in 1 minute 22.308 seconds.


PASTIMES: Bridge
LEAD: The Cavendish Club's Invitational Charity Pairs, one of the world's strongest annual events, will be slightly different this year.
There will be 40 pairs instead of 36, and play next weekend will be at the Westbury Hotel, 69th Street and Madison Avenue instead of the host club.

LEAD: A summertime ritual is under way at amusement parks across the land: the competition to have the tallest and fastest roller coaster.
And within weeks of the opening of a new record-holder for height at the Six Flags Great Adventure park in Jackson, N.J., an even taller one has started rolling at the Cedar


Correction
LEAD: Because of a computer entry error, the paperback fiction best-seller list published on April 30 reversed the ranking of two books. ''The Drawing of the Three,'' by Stephen King (Plume/NAL), should have been No. 1. ''Tapestry,'' by Belva Plain (Dell), should have been No. 2.


Pratfalls and Nitwits, Leopards and Hawks
LEAD: Stand back - the superlatives are going to intersect here, the result of the long-overdue video releases of two classic screwball comedies by Howard Hawks, 20TH CENTURY (1934, RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video, $69.95) and BRINGING UP BABY (1938, Turner Home Video, $19.98).


SPA LIFE: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING IN ACTION
LEAD: GRAY SWEATS JUST DON'T CUT IT ANYMORE.
THOSE who are serious about exercise - the ones with board-flat stomachs who visit spas once a year and health clubs once a day -are just as serious about dressing for action.


TIME INC. MEANS BUSINESS
LEAD: Among the ''lush excesses'' of my own experience at Time Inc., where I was a reporter for Sports Illustrated in 1956, was breakfast at the bargaining table (''Time Inc. Means Business,'' by Lester Bernstein, Feb. 26).
In those days, management and the Newspaper Guild (of which I was an active member) sat at a pristine, linen-draped table with a skyline view.


FASHION: On the Street; Suits Are the Order For Lunch in the Park
LEAD: Eating in Central Park is usually an opportunity for dressing down.
After all, who needs to get fancy for a picnic on the Sheep Meadow?
But the luncheon held last Wednesday at the Rumsey Playfield in the park was a special occasion, the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards, and those who attended did some serious suiting up.


Ross Lewis - Subway Muralist
LEAD: In the beginning there were scraggly mustaches inked onto the faces on advertising posters.
Then came the age of graffiti, when no subway was safe from egos and spray cans.


Q and A
LEAD:  Tax on a Brownstone


For Charles Schwab, a Time to Tinker
LEAD: Time weighs heavily at Charles Schwab &amp; Company, the nation's largest discount broker.
Transactions are down and so are profits.
The days of pre-crash trading volume have become a distant memory, and employees have been encouraged to take three-month ''sabbaticals'' at one-quarter pay or to work part time to cut costs.


SPA LIFE
LEAD: The word spa is dusted with a bit of magic.


Vermonters Organizing Opposition to Gas Pipeline
LEAD: Angry Vermont residents are mobilizing in opposition to a plan to run a natural-gas pipeline across the state from the Canadian border.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Santiago
LEAD: As rivers go, the Mapocho sets no standards for either beauty or might, but at this time of year a walk along its south bank as the river flows past Parque Forestal in the center of Santiago has the feel of a walk by the Seine in autumn.
This is not an accident.
The park, with its immense old trees, dusty footpaths and gaslights, was designed by Georges Dubois, a French landscaper, in 1901.


POSTINGS: Fannie Mae Experiment; Senior Thesis
LEAD: To provide low-cost housing for people 62 years old and older, the Federal National Mortgage Association has made $100 million in new mortgage money available to lending institutions under four innovative programs.
The pilot project will provide 1,400 low-cost mortgages throughout the country to see if the programs are viable options for people at or near retirement age.


Prospects; The Flaw in the FSX Deal
LEAD: The Bush Administration announced on April 28 that it had concluded an agreement with Japan for the co-development of a new jet fighter called the FSX.
The deal would transfer American airframe and electronic technology to Japan and transfer Japanese composite material technology back to the United States.


Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
LEAD: Where else but in New York can you find someone who has the qualities of a Mookie Dykstra?
His enthusiasm and energy will carry him 162 games.
He gives 20 home runs, 120 r.b.i.'s, 50 stolen bases and an insurance policy.
Not only do I hope he stays, perhaps he should run for mayor.
He symbolizes what New Yorkers are, and want to be: competitive and dependable.


Two Chinas May Never Become One, But They Are Becoming Friendly
LEAD: CHINA'S six-decade civil war may be ending.
The bearer of the olive branch was Shirley Kuo, Finance Minister in the Taiwan Government, who last week became the first Nationalist official to return to China since the Communist victory in 1949.

Dr.

Star-Crossed Lovers in 'Delancey'
LEAD: YEARS ago, there were matchmakers who arranged for young men and women to meet the perfect marriage partner.
Today, as singles bars and pages of personal ads attest, it seems even more difficult to meet that special someone.


Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack; Senseless Tragedy
LEAD: To the Editor:


Vermont
LEAD: To the Editor: On snow-bright days in winter this Vermonter, transplanted to Michigan, wishes she were close enough to ''skip school'' to Smuggler's Notch.


A Little Quiz for the Comfortable
LEAD: Jamie Mambro and Jay Williams, two advertising executives, are working to help the homeless here with a campaign to benefit the Pine Street Inn, a shelter that provides lodging, food and medical services for 1,200 men and women a day.


As Drought Proceeds, Views Diverge
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY and Westchester County may share the sources of their drinking water, but the same cannot be said for their approaches to its use, especially during a drought.

LEAD: NASSAU County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a candidate this year for the ninth time in the last 15 years, probably has shaken more hands and mailed more letters to constituents than any Nassau politician on the scene today.


Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack
LEAD: To the Editor:


FINDING 'THE ZONE'
LEAD: On behalf of my team, I'd like to thank Mr.
Shainberg for his discussion of archery.
Finding the zone is a goal in itself for many archers, transcending competition and score.
For many of us, archery is not only a sport but a spiritual exercise, the results of which - relaxation, improved concentration and better mental discipline -carry over into our daily lives.


On the Big Questions, the Jury Is Still Out
LEAD: IT took the jurors in the trial of Oliver L. North 12 days and a prayer to reach conclusions about the Iran-contra affair.
History may need more help and certainly more time.

LEAD: John N. Turner's decision to step down as leader of Canada's Liberal Party has given the political opposition a window for renewal that may not open again for several years.

The Minimum-Wage Fight Isn't Really About Pay
LEAD: IN a Congressional session thus far devoid of serious policy-making, it is probably fitting that the first showdown between Democrats and President Bush comes over the largely symbolic question of how much to raise the minimum wage.


Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
LEAD: A great ball team is like an ensemble company: the best players in there every day, at the same position, learning to play together as a unit.
Players do best when they are happy with their jobs and feel that management has a total commitment to them, even when they're in a slump.
The platoon system may seem expedient on paper, but it does not work in the hearts of dedicated players or fans.


The Superpowers Decide Clients Are Too Expensive
LEAD: THERE is a new sound coming from the third world - the sound of superpowers pulling up stakes.
From Afghanistan to Syria to Cambodia to Ethiopia to Angola to Nicaragua, both the United States and the Soviet Union are looking for the exits.
And as they take their cold war home with them, both are coming to recognize the nasty, tribal and intractable nature of some regional conflicts that have consumed them for decades.


Seton Hall Treated Unfairly
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


STREETSCAPES: The Half Moon Hotel; A Symbol of Coney Island Is About to Be Eclipsed
LEAD: IT was once Coney Island's Statue of Liberty, an impressive symbol beckoning to passing oceanliners.
But now the Half Moon Hotel, having spent its waning years as the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center nursing home, is scheduled for demolition as soon as the home completes a new building.

LEAD: In 1971, Gen.
Hugo Banzer Suarez seized power in Bolivia and ruled for seven years, jailing thousands of opponents and exiling others.

LEAD: GREENWICH, which has for several years had some of the best air in the state, had the worst during the hot summer of 1988, according to a state report.

LEAD: I AM not sure whether I've just been lucky with my mailmen or if all letter carriers are the interested, caring people both of mine have been.
I do know that the two men who have delivered my mail over the 38 years I've lived in the same house have indeed been special deliverers.


IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Antique Houses in New Developments
LEAD: NEW ENGLAND'S unique supply of early American architecture has generated something of a growth industry in preservation.
Antique houses are being acquired in increasing numbers, dismantled clapboard by clapboard, numbered and catalogued down to the last fireplace brick, strap hinge and beaded molding, then rebuilt across town or even in another state.


130 Are Said to Die in Pirate Attack on Vietnamese Refugees
LEAD: About 130 Vietnamese refugees were massacred or left to drown last month by pirates who attacked their boat off the Malaysian coast, refugee officials said on Friday, citing the account of the only refugee known to have survived the ordeal.


Winning Photos
LEAD: ''Eyewitness: The 32d Annual World Press Photo Contest Award-Winning Photographs'' can be seen at the Nikon House Gallery in Rockefeller Center through May 20.
The 100 photographs were judged the best of the entries from 1,295 photographers, publications and press agencies of 62 participating countries.

When Berlitz Is Not Enough
LEAD: CONFRONTATION with alien tongues sorts travelers into three groups.
The adepts, at one extreme, ''have an ear.'' Landing in Madrid for breakfast, they're able to chat up the waiter by dinnertime.
At the other extreme are the blithely monolingual, confident that pantomime, loud repetitions of their native speech and the kindness of strangers will carry any day.

LEAD: ''My finances are in shambles,'' the diary entry reads. ''With what unbelievable folly have I so long ignored them and let them drift.
In my 30th year, I was the richest young man in town.
In my 50th - well, I'm driving a 10-year-old car, owe so God-awful much money I'll need luck to pay it off. ''But I will, somehow I will.

Reviews/Music; Mozarteans On Period Instruments
LEAD: One of the nice things about hearing period-instrument concerts these days is that the instruments themselves are generally well played and less of an issue than they used to be.
This is by way of saying that when the Mozartean Players came to the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night, Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn were more on our minds than what they were being played on.

PHILIP MORRIS'S BIG BITE
LEAD: There is considerable irony in Philip Morris's sponsorship of athletic events like the Virgina Slims tennis tournament.
It seems unlikely that the participants in these tournaments smoke.
If they did, they would have neither the respiratory capacity nor the stamina necessary to compete as professional athletes.

Airport Curfew Plan Is Revived, With Noise Level as Guide
LEAD: TWO members of the County Board of Legislators have proposed that a mandatory curfew be instituted at the County Airport to ban noisy planes from midnight to 7 A.M.
Although not a new idea, the proposal has become a practical option, its supporters say, because the county has the data it requires to identify offenders and to substantiate the need for a mandatory curfew.


LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  GOING DUTCH  Smile when you suggest ''Going Dutch'' at Hofstra University.
The people there take the hint literally, and today, for the sixth year in a row, the Hempstead campus will celebrate its Dutch heritage with a Dutch Festival.
The four-hour program begins at noon.


CAMPUS LIFE: Miami of Florida; Women's Hair Is Scrunching Up For Cool's Sake
LEAD: What's up in women's hairstyles at the University of Miami is, well, hair - in stiff, spirited ponytails that look like palm trees sprouting atop the head.
The stiffeners of choice include scrunchers, crunchers and plain old wool.

LEAD: I have observed the phenomenon among surgeons.
There are times when these physicians describe their work as occurring far faster than anticipated: time has ''dilated,'' and movements are performed flawlessly.
I suspect there are many occupations in which the techniques described in your article can be utilized to enhance performance.


Like the West Coast City It Is, Seattle Is Tired of Developing
LEAD: BLESSED with a majestic natural setting, this city has always prided itself on holding onto its quality of life even at the expense of business expansion.
In the last two decades, half-built freeways were stopped in mid-construction, renovation plans for the pleasantly chaotic Pike Place Market were voted down, and parks were built on covered highways and old industrial sites.

High Technology May Get a Break
LEAD: A relaxation of antitrust laws is being given high-level consideration as a way to help American industry remain competitive in high technology.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said that in certain categories of high-tech products the Administration would favor an easing of antitrust laws that penalize corporations for cooperating with competitors.


Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
LEAD: They should play Lenny Dykstra in center and Mookie Wilson in right.
They are both better players than Darryl Strawberry.
Look what happened to Lou Gehrig: He was sitting on the bench, Wally Pipp got sick, Lou went in and Pipp never played first base again for the Yankees.
If a man can hit and field, he must play and not sit on the bench.


More Tuition Was Too Much to Ask
LEAD: GIVEN the sharp rise in the cost of going to college in recent years, a $200 tuition increase - and the first since 1983, at that - might seem relatively low.
But the turbulence of the last two weeks has demonstrated that a tuition increase of any amount remains a politically delicate, sometimes explosive, subject for New York State's public universities.

CAMPUS LIFE: Miami of Ohio; Serenade of Sons Now Sings Praises Of Daughters, Too
LEAD: For 80 years, students at Miami University of Ohio sang a school song that included phrases like, ''Thy sons have quested from thee.'' In that time, those sons went off to fight in two World Wars and battles in Korea and Vietnam.
But for 89 years, daughters, too, have attended Miami, and a little war has been fought and won to convince the university of their contributions.

POSTINGS: Brooklyn Renovation; Time to Shine
LEAD: When the Williamsburgh Savings Bank opened its 29-story headquarters at One Hanson Place in 1929 it became the focal point of downtown Brooklyn and, at 512 feet, the tallest building on Long Island, from the East River to Montauk.
The four-faced clock tower was the world's tallest and even larger than London's Big Ben.


SPA LIFE: THE HOMEBODIE
LEAD: My father is one of the few people I know whose stationary bicycle doesn't double as a clothes rack.
But then again, he's also one of the few people I know who keeps a special notebook in which he records the number of miles he rides each day.
A recent 8 A.M. phone call heralded news that in two years he'd clocked enough miles to have pedaled from Virginia to Los Angeles and back.

TITLE SEARCH FOLLOW-UP
LEAD: Citing biblical allusions in current book titles, William Safire mentions ''Still Small Voices,'' by John and Janet Wallach, which profiles a variety of Arabs and Israelis who ''strive to make their lives amid the violence of the West Bank and Gaza'' (On Language: ''Title Search Follow-Up, April 2).


AND KEEP IN MIND
LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.


COLD HANDS
LEAD: The splendid article by John Stone on ''Why Some Hands Get So Cold'' had one important omission (Body and Mind, March 12).
The application of biofeedback techniques allows the patient literally to warm up cold fingers by releasing the spasm of the artery in the hand.
Patients are conditioned to observe the changes on a sensitive thermometer so that they master the ability to increase the finger teperature.


Common Sense Seems to Be In Short Supply
LEAD: Few people enter a theater hoping to hate the movie, but, having paid their seven bucks, they don't take kindly to insult.
Movie patrons are a prickly, unreliable lot.
Friends one minute, adversaries the next.
They want to believe, and they do believe, sometimes doggedly, until that moment when belief becomes insupportable.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish.
This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired.
After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking.
I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.

North Rouses 850 Supporters in Miami Speech
LEAD: Oliver L. North attacked Congress before a cheering crowd of supporters today, saying too many members interfere in foreign affairs, but he avoided any mention of his recent conviction on three felony charges.


Baryshnikov Searches for The Heart of 'Swan Lake'
LEAD: Tomorrow, when his staging of ''Swan Lake'' launches American Ballet Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House with a gala, Mikhail Baryshnikov will be imagining that somewhere in the audience is a budding romantic who must be placated.
The 41-year-old artistic director of the company seems to have had his former, impatient self in mind when re-staging ''Swan Lake,'' having said his main goal was to direct the ballet toward such an emotional climax that few would dare leave the theater early.

LEAD: RECENTLY, a local church held its annual clothing drive, designed to bring relief to needy people in the area.
Since ours is a family with six children - four sprouting lads and two hemline-conscious maidens - we have much to offer, and participate every year.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-23


Leonide Massine - Ripe for a Reappraisal
LEAD: ''Les Presages,'' which Leonide Massine choreographed in 1933 for Colonel de Basil's Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo as the first of his symphonic ballets, was one of the 20th century's most controversial dance works.
Anyone who saw the Paris Opera Ballet's astonishingly vivid revival in Paris this spring might wonder at the esthetic pettiness of the original protests.


'It's Part of the Legacy of Being Human'
LEAD: IT'S like the light at the end of the tunnel.
Winter is over, and the sunshine, scents and colors of spring invite even the most serious-minded out to play.
The experience is commonly known as spring fever, and people find it harder to work and carry out their assigned responsibilities.

U.S. Researchers Find Big Field of Geysers in Mediterranean
LEAD: A robot submersible, transmitting video pictures to scientists and schoolchildren by way of its long tether and radio links, has revealed a field of hot geysers on the floor of the Mediterranean Sea 110 miles southwest of Naples.

LEAD: A winery worker accused of killing his wife, two of their daughters and four other people pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that could send him to the gas chamber.

Death Masks, Death Warrants And a Revolution
LEAD: The timing could hardly be better.
Two hundred years ago, almost to the day, on May 5, 1789, Versailles witnessed the opening session of the Estates-General, soon to become the National Assembly.
That day is usually viewed as marking the starting point of the French Revolution.

Freedom of Speech And 'Hateful' Ideas
LEAD: The article on the German-American Bund (''Jerseyana,'' April 9), informative and interesting on the surface, offers an excellent example of misguided ''reasoning,'' replete with dangerous assumptions and conclusions lurking behind the facade of fair-seeming words.


PHILIP MORRIS'S BIG BITE
LEAD: Your article on Philip Morris offered (between the lines) some good management advice: 1.
Don't be arrogant. 2.
Don't underestimate the competition. 3.
Don't be stale in marketing. 4.
Don't be wasteful. 5.
Study, then act swiftly.
ROBERT B. ALEN  Los Angeles


Cambodia Deserves Better Than Guns
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia seem to be converging on a workable deal for their country when Vietnam ends its occupation in the fall.
Into this welcome development comes a proposal by Representative Stephen Solarz, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, to send military aid to non-Communist rebels in a coalition led by the Prince but dominated by the dreaded Khmer Rouge.


'Arizona Is Lost, Next Is San Francisco'
LEAD: The Bush bailout plan for savings institutions calls for dismantling the three-member Federal Home Loan Bank Board and placing it under the Treasury.
And since passage seems almost certain, some board members are beginning to leave.


Canescos Pair Up
LEAD: The Athletics' Jose Canseco was far from Oakland and the major leagues yesterday, sitting in a 10,200-seat stadium in Alabama getting ready to play for the Huntsville Stars in a Southern League game.


UGANDA'S LEGACY
LEAD: Ryszard Kapuscinski's article, ''Uganda: After the Terror'' (March 12), is a devastating portrait of the legacy of killing, torture, looting and harassment that took place during the regimes of Milton Obote and Idi Amin.


Tibetans Fear Loss of a Safe Haven in Nepal
LEAD: Tibetan exiles in Nepal, fearful that their country of refuge will grow more dependent on China because of an Indian economic blockade, say they are worried about their future in this land, where they are prohibited from taking part in anti-Chinese activities.

A Leader Going Out In Style
LEAD: For his farewell appearance this afternoon as artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Charles Wadsworth had a range of choices.
He could have stepped out of character and taken a solo piano turn with something valedictory such as Beethoven's ''Lebewohl'' Sonata.
Many in the Alice Tully Hall audience for this final concert of the society's 20th season will be in the mood for something at least that sentimental.

The Bountiful Tables of the Lot
LEAD: THERE are many reasons why the Lot, as well as the departments that spread out from its boundaries, has maintained a gastronomic culture all its own.
This ocher-hued, rustic land offers no easy access to Paris, and even Bordeaux and Toulouse - the closest major cities - remain a world apart.
The culinary richness of its farmers and independent country folk has remained relatively undiminished, as well as widely envied, by the rest of the country.

Filling the Antitrust Void
LEAD: TRY your hand at antitrust law: Competing manufacturers of television sets illegally agree to overcharge retail merchants $100 for every set the retailers buy.
The retailers unwittingly pass along the entire $100 overcharge to unsuspecting consumer purchasers.
Who has the right to sue to collect damages from the manufacturers?

TIME INC. MEANS BUSINESS
LEAD: One of Time Inc.'s failed publications was not listed in your article.
That magazine was called Letters.
It started as a free eight-page supplement to Time to accommodate the overflow of letters to the editor.
When it reached 20 pages, ads were solicited.
In 1937, three years after it started, circulation reached 25,000 a year.

A Romantic Style Gets Back to Its Roots
LEAD: The Gothic revival style in 19th-century European furnishings was spurred in the late 1820's by the spread of nationalism and religious revivalism.
What resulted was chairs, chests, clocks and tablewares embellished with Gothic spires, trefoils, crosses and knights in shining armor, images spiced by fantasy and enriched by glitter or the jewellike colors of medieval stained-glass windows.

CAMPUS LIFE: Virginia; Steeplechasing As Cocktail Party Despite the Mud
LEAD: In spring a young person's fancy turns to steeplechasing.
So popular is the sport now that not even heavy rains could stop thousands of students at the University of Virginia, and many alumni, from traveling five miles last week to attend the Foxfield Races, the main spring event here, both as spectators and, in one case, as a jockey.

LEAD: ENCLOSING an interior doorway by sheathing it with wallboard is an easy remodeling project.

...A 100th Birthday Counters the Silences in a Family's Life
LEAD: MY grandfather will turn 100 next week.
He is the same age as the Eiffel Tower and 100 years younger than the French Revolution.
From the neighboring Cote d'Azur, from Paris, from all the provinces of France, from New York, from Virginia, from the French West Indies, the family will travel to the south of France to celebrate with him.

LEAD: I guess if your taste runs toward muscle-bound bull terriers and huge chaws of tobacco, you may prefer Dykstra.
Personally, I prefer the bighearted, soft-spoken Mookie, motoring down the basepaths.
JESSICA REGELSON  Brooklyn


A Day to Step Out of Studio 'Isolation'
LEAD: RUTH DUCKWORTH'S serene porcelain forms are matte white, eggshell thin and precise.
In contrast, Albert Paley's decorative ironwork seems to exert an inner energy as its dark and twisted rods culminate in whiplash swirls.
Works by these two internationally known craft artists are featured in an exhibition on view at the College Art Gallery of Montclair State


Raising a Bar
LEAD: Perry J. Watkins made it no secret that he was gay when he was drafted in 1967, but the Army said he could be discharged only after homosexual activity was proved.
By 1984, Mr.
Watkins was a sergeant with an exemplary record, a career soldier like his father.
But the Army discharged him under a rule change which said that avowed homosexuality barred military service.

Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about preschool programs misidentified the state agency providing a free booklet, ''Choosing a Child Care Center.'' The booklet is available from the Division of Youth and Family Services, 1 South Montgomery Street, CN 717, Trenton 08625.


Art and Horticulture Combine in Stamford Silvermine Show
LEAD: FLORISTS, greenhouses and garden clubs have joined some 200 artists in ''Festival '89,'' an exhibition of art, crafts and decorative home accessories at the Silvermine Gallery at Metro Center in Stamford through May 13.
There are fresh flowers, silk flowers and paintings of flowers.


Mets Beat Astros On Johnson's Homer
LEAD: Howard Johnson celebrated his one-week anniversary as the No. 2 hitter in the Mets' lineup yesterday by doing what he has done since he became the No. 2 hitter.
He produced a big hit.


Overactive Machinery
LEAD: FROM TIME TO TIME, NOT INTENDING TO, I imagine myself in charge of my own body.
It's a faintly unpleasant sensation: sitting there in the cockpit, worrying whether everything is operational.
The scariest part, easily, is the stomach.


THE SOLDIERS: Anger and Frustration
LEAD: The warrens and alleyways of the Nablus casbah are desolate and still.
For the fifth straight day, the 20,000 Arab residents of the ancient market are under curfew, locked in their homes night and day as punishment for the killing of an Israeli soldier a few days earlier.
But as Moshiko Giat, a reserve paratrooper, and the seven other members of his patrol move through the narrow twisting corridors, pressing themselves tight against walls, pointing their automatic rifles around every corner before they turn, it's clear they feel a strong threatening presence.


Living Up to a Name Promising Much
LEAD: MICHAEL ANTHONY JOSEPH TOSCANO must be a confident man.
Imagine naming your restaurant Creative Cuisine.
That's right, Michael Anthony's Creative Cuisine.
It's in East Moriches, and with that monicker is a tempting target for any critic inclined to take a cheap shot.


A Harlem Church Welcomes A Bishop on Her First Visit
LEAD: When Josephine Green started singing in the choir of Saint Philip's Episcopal Church in Harlem 51 years ago, the notion of a woman holding high office in the diocese, or even leading a congregation in prayer, was unthinkable. ''We thought God - a man; our father - a man,'' she said. ''Anything with authority was male, even in the household.

Steaming Into Yorkshire's Past
LEAD: THE piercing, high-pitched whistles.
The elegant, high-stepping locomotives, the clouds of steam, the delicate carriages with compartments opening directly to the outside, ''The Lady Vanishes,'' ''The Thirty-Nine Steps,'' all those other Hitchcock movies - the British have been carrying on a love affair with railroads practically since they invented them, more than 150 years ago.

LEAD: Aleksandr Mogilny, the Soviet hockey player who defected in Stockholm earlier this week to join the Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League, spent his first full day in the United States in seclusion today as club officials discussed his future with American immigration officials and the N.H.L.

LEAD: THE last time the State Supreme Court sat in the Old Statehouse, the Boston Red Caps had just won a National League pennant and work was just about done on the new $2.5 million Capitol.


Reviews/Dance; Otrabanda And People Gone Wild
LEAD: The first half of ''Quasi-Kinetics,'' presented by Otrabanda at La Mama Annex on Thursday night, is like an endless evening spent with one of the ruling-class bores who populate New Yorker cartoons.
In the theater-dance piece, written and directed by Roger Babb, a man and a woman talk exhaustively of appearances and the way they see each other.


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wells, Me.; Town Seeking An Open Beach
LEAD: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright.
If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.


The Beat Goes On - And Time Stands Still
LEAD: ''American Bandstand'' notwithstanding, the measure of a commercial dance record is almost never its beat.
The history of dance music is one of bad records with good beats and good records with monotonous thuds.
The beat is at most an instigator, a means toward a greater reward.


Scandal in the Moonlight
LEAD: What business do city officeholders have also holding time-consuming posts in political parties?
None, in the view of Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., head of New York City's Charter Revision Commission, who would ban such behavior.


Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source
LEAD: CALIFORNIA still has the jump on the rest of the country when it comes to pioneering America's revolution in food and drink.
Lately the state has turned its attention to beer; the repeal in 1976 of a Prohibition-era law against homebrewing has allowed a new generation of homebrewers and microbreweries to flourish.


VOTER-SIGNUP BILL GAINS IN CONGRESS
LEAD: Faced with steadily dropping voter turnouts, Congress is advancing a sweeping proposal that would make it much easier for Americans to register to vote.


A Sculptor Who Really Gets Into His Work
LEAD: Antony Gormley is both director and actor on a sculptural stage as spare as anything in Beckett.
He is the mind deciding where his figures will go, and he is the body from which his squatting, flying and tumbling figures are cast in plaster and then fixed in lead.
Even when there are two figures and they seem to be a man and woman in sexual union, the molds were taken from him alone.

LEAD:  Senate


FICTION
LEAD:  GOLDILOCKS.
By Andrew Coburn. (Scribner's, $17.95.) Crime novels - unlike mysteries, which usually rely heavily on plot - are successful largely due to their interesting characters and their mood of psychological tension.
The most effective, like those by Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler, create sinister worlds we don't mind visiting, but certainly wouldn't care to live in.


SPIES &amp; THRILLERS
LEAD:  WEAPON by Robert Mason (Putnam, $18.95) has an unusual and amusing premise.
Meet Solo, a $2 billion robot designed for the Army by a brilliant American.
Solo is going to be the ultimate soldier.
He is packed full of gadgetry that gives him amazing strength and speed.
He reads codes, picks up transmissions from space satellites and has his own kind of intelligence.

LEAD: Three years ago it would have been unthinkable for Marion Copenhaver, a state legislator here, to do what she did last month: urge a cutoff of state money for the Christa McAuliffe planetarium, a monument to the Concord teacher who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

Information, Please: Phone Companies vs. Newspapers
LEAD: AFTER several failed experiments earlier in the decade, the newspaper industry all but abandoned its quest to develop electronic systems that would allow subscribers to read the news on a home video screen.
Now newspapers and other vendors of information are being upstaged by the telephone companies, which are seeking to stake their claim in the emerging field of electronic publishing.

Ordinarily, damages this extensive would take six months or more to repair.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish.
This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired.
After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking.
I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane.


Chang on Rise but He's Still Not in Agassi's Act
LEAD: There were times last year when Michael Chang was reduced to a footnote in the Andre Agassi story.
Agassi had flair - a punk rock hairdo and equally colorful personality -plus a game that vaulted him to six tournament titles and No. 3 in the world.
Chang preferred a brush cut and an impassive expression on the court, masking his emotions.

Hungarian Radio Broadcasts Long-Banned Revolt Speech
LEAD: Breaking a long taboo, the Hungarian radio today broadcast a speech first made by Prime Minister Imre Nagy on the day that Soviet tanks entered Budapest to suppress the 1956 rebellion.
In the speech, Mr.
Nagy said the invaders intended ''to overthrow the legal Hungarian democratic Government.''

PASTIMES: Numismatics
LEAD: Every coin collector looks for mint errors on coins.
Even the young collector will look to see if there is a miss-strike or double-strike on a cent or nickel.
The days of finding a three-legged buffalo are perhaps over - more recent coins fill our pockets - but still the search continues.
One extremely rare error is the brockage.

LEAD: ''ALL of us who work with her are convinced that were it not for her calling, she would surely be the head of a Fortune 500 company today,'' said Marge Lovero, director of the Entrepreneurial Center at Manhattanville College here.


Reviews/Dance; Pretty Boy Floyd and Shakespeare
LEAD: A lot goes on at once in ''Outside the Law,'' presented by the Irondale Ensemble Project on Wednesday night at the Rapp Arts Center.
The group, which also works with troubled children in the New York City school system, has woven a populist telling of the story of the notorious bank robber Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd and a little topical satire into the fabric of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It.

New York in Flower
LEAD: New York City is not usually thought of as sylvan, but that's just what it is at this time of year.
A street in Greenwich Village, for instance, is canopied with white blossoms, the pear trees on both sides having met and married in its center.
The pink of cherry blossoms clashes with the red of old brick houses all over town, and magnolia trees are flaunting their last candles.

LEAD: AS New York City struggles to remain a competitive alternative for small businesses and manufacturers, one of the vexing problems is that commercial landlords are allowed to buy electricity at regulated wholesale rates, then charge tenants any price they want for that power.

Park Bandshell
LEAD: To the Editor:


Paying a Price
LEAD: ''Being good in business is the most fascinating kind of art,'' Andy Warhol once said.
That Mr.
Warhol's pop art is both good business and fascinating was demonstrated last week when his portrait, ''Shot Red Marilyn,'' a 1964 depiction of Marilyn Monroe, was auctioned at Christie's in New York.
The price, $4.07 million, was the highest ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist, who died in 1987.


Solo vs. Package
LEAD: To the Editor: As a participant last November in a T.W.A.
Getaway tour to London, I agree with Stanley Carr (''Solo or Package?'' Travel, March 5) that there are definite cost advantages to package tours.
But these savings can be expensive in the form of discomfort, sleepless nights and ruined vacations.

A Continent's Referendum on Democracy
LEAD: BEGINNING this month and continuing through the next year, voters in more than a dozen Latin American countries will be going to the polls to render judgment on a decade of hardship.
Though the 1980's have been marked by the disappearance of military dictatorship and the emergence of democratic civilian rule in one country after another, that shift, like the coming cycle of presidential elections, has occurred against a backdrop of a continentwide economic crisis that has left the people disenchanted and newly implanted institutions vulnerable.

They can write as feminists, says Ntozake Shange, and they can try to present a uniquely female perception of the world - a world in which their reality has often been illegitimate, or silent.
They can, says Cindy Lou Johnson, try to understand in some way what goes on between men and women.

For West Bank Arabs, Education Has Been Deemed a Criminal Act
LEAD: Every day, hundreds of Bir Zeit University students disguise their textbooks, talk their way through army checkpoints and sneak off to secret classes in church basements, clubs and professors' homes.


Race May Skip a Cycle
LEAD: The Coors International Bicycle Classic, America's premier cycling race, may not be held this year, its owner-director said.
And if the race is run it will have another name and sponsor.
But he said that in any event he was confident the race would be run next year.

LEAD: Officials of the United States and Taiwan failed to reach agreement today on trade differences after five days of talks in which the Americans urged the Taiwanese to liberalize import practices even further.

LEAD: The door of a traveling freight train blew off, swooped up a Brooklyn man standing in a glass booth at the Beacon station and dumped both about 25 feet down the tracks, the police said today.

Hungary Deal For 13 Banks
LEAD: Thirteen Western European banks have paid $110 million for 49.65 percent of Hungary's leading lighting company.
The banks plan eventually to list the company's shares on Western stock exchanges, in the first such offering of its kind.
Shares in the company, Tungsram, were bought from the Hungarian Credit Bank Ltd.

Publishers Experiment With Lower Prices
LEAD: Bantam Books this week is shipping to bookstores almost 100,000 copies of ''Creature,'' a 329-page horror novel by John Saul.
A hardcover novel of that length would normally carry a retail price of $18.95.
But to entice Mr.
Saul's large paperback audience to buy his book in hard cover, Bantam has priced it at $12.95.

She was 66 years old and lived in Riverdale.

RESULTS PLUS

Senna's winning time was 1 hour 53 minutes 33.251 seconds as he beat Prost by 52.528 seconds.

Up in the Air (60 Feet High) For 2 1/2 Hours
LEAD: While trapped for two-and-a-half hours inside a carnival ride, suspended upside down 60 feet in the air, Tracy Burgher of Queens felt cold, bruised and scared.
But what hurt worse, the Far Rockaway teen-ager said, was that afterward no one from the carnival said they were sorry.

Page A1


Mountain Sickness a Sneaky Ailment
LEAD: THE main problem with altitude sickness is that most people don't recognize that they have it.
The symptoms are usually mild and may resemble flu or some other short-term illness.
But a recent study that explores acute altitude, or mountain, sickness indicates that one out of every four people get ill when they go 6,000 feet or more above sea level.

Black Bass in the Northeast
LEAD: New York has an abundance of black bass waters.
Fully exploring the bass fishing in just the Thousand Islands area of the St.
Lawrence River would take half a lifetime.
New York's general black bass season opens June 17 and closes Nov. 30; the daily bag limit is five fish, minimum length 12 inches.
