Foreign Stock Data
LEAD: American investors added $1.5 billion to their holdings of foreign stocks last year, reversing net sales of 1987, the Securities Industry Association said in a report released yesterday.
In 1987, the year of the stock market crash, Americans sold $1.1 billion more of foreign stocks than had bought, the association said.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Argentina's inflation rate was 33.4 percent in April, according to official figures released Friday.
The figures do not reflect the fact that prices of items like flour and sugar have doubled or trebled in the last few weeks.
Private economists predict that the consumer price index could rise 50 percent in May, exceeding the record of 42.23 percent set in March 1976.

Harcourt Loss Widens
LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said Friday that its loss widened to $116.1 million in the first quarter from a $35.3 million loss in the period a year ago.
Revenue rose 14 percent, to $315.5 million, froi $276.7 million a year earlier.
Losses increased largely because of rising interest rates on the company's debt and higher marketing costs for new products in the schooh publishing division.

Quake in Remote China Area
LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked a remote region of China near the Burmese border early today, toppling homes and cracking streets, the official New China News Agency said.

A.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday incorrectly described the planned flight of the Magellan spacecraft.
Although the orbits of Venus and the Earth are only 26 million miles apart, the spacecraft will travel 795 million miles, passing around the Sun, before it reaches Venus.

Summer Coats
LEAD: How many times in the summer have you wished for a wafer-thin coat?
They're nice to toss on when it rains or it is a bit cool, or when you want to create a dramatic billowy effect.
Yet these coats are always hard to find, particularly when warmer weather arrives.
There are a few around town now, though they are apt to be available in limited quantities only.

LEAD: Marc Chagall's ''Violinist With the World Upside Down,'' from 1929, was sold last night for $4.6 million, a record at auction for the artist, in an auction held by Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based auction house.

Tourism in Australia
LEAD: Tourism has overtaken coal as Australia's second-largest source of foreign revenue, the Tourism Minister, Graham Richardson, said today.

Richardson said in a statement.

LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' and ''Black and Blue'' received 10 nominations each yesterday to lead the race for the 1989 Tony Awards.

Jersey Suit Alleges Bias in Raising of Beach Fees
LEAD: Belmar raised beach fees in 1986 in part to keep blacks from visiting the seashore community, a state attorney said today in opening one in a series of trials aimed at lowering the cost of using New Jersey beaches.

Municipal Workers Endorse Dinkins Bid
LEAD: The city's largest union endorsed Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins for mayor yesterday, accusing Mayor Edward I. Koch of mismanagement and inefficiency.


2 Disappointments for ABC, Low Ratings and an Ending
LEAD: ABC suffered two major disappointments yesterday, getting disastrously low initial ratings for the first installment of the conclusion of ''War and Remembrance'' and canceling ''Moonlighting,'' once the network's second most popular show.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Bolivian presidential election misidentified a candidate.
He is Gen.
Hugo Banzer Suarez.


Robins's Net Rises by 12.7%
LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company, the pharmaceutical maker in its fourth year of Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, today reported a 12.7 percent increase in earnings for the first quarter of 1989.


Who Got the Best Deal?


Talking Business with Brindisi of S.C.A.; When Executives Act Like Raiders
LEAD: For five years, Louis L. Brindisi has been trying to make corporate executives think like corporate raiders.
Mr.
Brindisi, a senior partner with a newly formed firm called Strategic Compensation Associates, a joint venture between Korn/Ferry International and the Management Compensation Group, argues that a ''raider mentality'' - a strong concern about the company's stock price -can help executives make their businesses more productive and profitable.


Large Volcanic Eruption Could Damage Ozone, 2 Researchers Report
LEAD: A MAJOR volcanic eruption could significantly accelerate the destruction of the earth's protective ozone layer by industrial chemicals, two atmospheric scientists have reported.


RULE OVERTURNED ON AGENT ORANGE
LEAD: A Federal district judge has thrown out the Veterans Administration's rules on health damage attributed to the herbicide Agent Orange and has ordered the agency to reconsider claims of more than 31,000 Vietnam War veterans.


Insurers Seeking Relief On California Rate Cut
LEAD: Three business days after the California Supreme Court upheld the main provisions of an initiative requiring insurance companies to roll back rates 20 percent, at least 18 insurers have asked the California Insurance Department for exemptions on the ground that the change would impose hardship on them.


Ford Raises Prices
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company raised the prices of three car lines and some options because of higher costs for material and labor.
Ford said base prices for the Ford Festiva, now about $6,500, would rise 1.7 percent; the Mercury Tracer, now about $8,900, would rise 1.3 percent, and the Lincoln Continental, now about $28,900, would rise 1.5 percent.


Topping 20 Years of Dance With Even More Dancing
LEAD: There are times when ghosts must be faced and consoled.
That is the message of ''To Comfort Ghosts,'' a dance by Dan Wagoner that will be performed tonight through Sunday by Dan Wagoner and Dancers in the company's spring season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).
And facing his own ghosts is what Mr.


Canadiens Confident Of Eliminating Flyers
LEAD: There is restraint and moderation in their method, and discipline is their password, which is why the Montreal Canadiens aren't chortling just because they are a game away from becoming the Wales Conference representative in the Stanley Cup final.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the National Transportation Safety Board misidentified its chairman.
The acting chairman is James L. Kolstad.


Here Comes Mr. Jordan, At Altitude
LEAD: When he first ascended into the National Basketball Association's stratosphere, Michael Jordan was considered a medley of Julius Erving, Elgin Baylor and Earl (The Pearl) Monroe.
But now, after four seasons at altitude, Michael Jordan is incomparable.
Nobody knows that better than opponents assigned to cover him.

LEAD: The dollar rose broadly in brisk trading yesterday and reached its highest level against the West German mark since August.

LEAD: In its most significant software announcement in years, the International Business Machines Corporation will introduce next Tuesday a collection of software programs that will provide the same ''look and feel'' to users of most of its machines, from personal computers to mainframes.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that John J. Creedon, its president and chief executive, will retire on Sept. 1.

The Editorial Notebook; For Foundlings, a Refuge
LEAD: Foundlings are often the stuff of Bible stories (Moses in the bulrushes) and fairy tales (princes placed on humble doorsteps).
But they are also the reason the Sisters of Charity opened a hospital in New York City 120 years ago.
In the hospital's first 10 weeks, 123 abandoned babies were given to the nuns.

LEAD: As Congressional insiders know, it is not always the elected official who calls the shots in major matters of policy or those minor things called favors.
It can be one of the powerful among the ever-changing 14,000 staff members on Capitol Hill.

LEAD: Minutes after the Chicago Bulls' heart-stopping playoff victory Sunday, someone asked Doug Collins how he felt.
The Bulls' coach was honest; he said he was drained.
But he also said he felt a sense of anticipation looking ahead to Chicago's next challenge, the Knicks.

North Is Viewed as Misguided
LEAD: A majority of the American people view Oliver North as ''well-meaning but misguided,'' according to a Gallup Poll taken after Mr.
North's conviction last week on criminal charges stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: Calling for an ''all-out, all fronts fight'' against crime in New York City, Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo yesterday proposed a major expansion of the state and city criminal justice systems, including additional police, probation officers and prison cells.


Tally Brown, 64, Dies; Singer and an Actress
LEAD: Tally Brown, an actress and a cabaret performer, died after a stroke on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.
She was 64 years old.

LEAD: A man whose two infant daughters died under similar circumstances within three years told police that his wife was upset after giving birth and apologized both times for not having boys.

LEAD: Jim Bakker relaunched his television ministry today in a nearly deserted shopping center on the outskirts of this central Florida city.

Kenneth Lynch, 82, Modern Blacksmith And Artist in Metal
LEAD: Kenneth J. Lynch, a skilled blacksmith who created many pieces of metalwork adorning New York City buildings, directed repairs on the Statue of Liberty in the late 1920's and twice restored the weather vane on Boston's Old North Church, died Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn., after a long illness.

Give Police Big White Front and Back Numbers
LEAD: To the Editor:


Martin L. Mellman, 69, Is Dead; Led Democrats in Nassau County
LEAD: Martin L. Mellman, the former chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, died of undetermined causes Friday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 69 years old and lived in Port Washington.


Brilliance and Recklessness Seen in Fusion Collaboration
LEAD: THE two chemists who started a scientific furor by claiming to have achieved low-temperature fusion in a jar of water may not be widely known, but friends and acquaintances say they are a fascinating pair with unique strengths and weaknesses.

LEAD: The bombs returned to the Bronx last night, but they weren't unleashed by the team that bears no resemblance to its ancestors.

LEAD: THE conceptual boundary between humans and computers, called the interface, is the area of some of the most intriguing research in science.

Colleges Welcome Research Gifts but Ask More for Buildings
LEAD: American foundations gave more than $1.6 billion last year to colleges and universities, but the money was mainly for research, and academic leaders say the grants neglected the worsening decay of collegiate buildings and classrooms.


Calcutta, at Age 300, Is Planning a Long Party
LEAD: India's biggest city is getting ready to celebrate a birthday.


Johnson Is Top 6th Man
LEAD: Eddie Johnson of the Phoenix Suns, who led all non-starters in the National Basketball Association in scoring with a 21.5 average, yesterday was named the winner of the league's Sixth Man Award.
The 6-foot-9-inch Johnson received 33 votes from a nationwide news media panel.
Thurl Bailey of Utah was second with 26 votes and Dennis Rodman of Detroit was third with 17.


Moe Goldman, Ex-Basketball Player, 75
LEAD: Moe Goldman, a standout basketball player at City College who later played professionally with the Philadelphia Sphas, died Sunday.
He was 75 years old.


Avon Sues Amway, Jacobs
LEAD: Avon Products Inc. filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking a Federal court order to prevent a partnership of the Amway Corporation and the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs from buying more Avon stock.

LEAD: THE ''AI Catalog'' from Thinking Software is a wonderful potpourri of programs for all personal computer users, from the rawest beginner to the experienced DOS jockey, including those who are just out for a good time.

LEAD: Speaker of the House Jim Wright, batting aside one allegation of impropriety after another, denied today that he had ever held up legislation in exchange for campaign contributions or taken a free ride on the plane owned by the operator of a chain of nursing homes.

The old, rural Wilton is Eugenia Slaughter.
For half a century, Mrs.
Slaughter has lived here on 20 acres of lush, rolling fields that are divided by stone walls and anchored by a 1757 farmhouse with a tilted red barn.

Millicom Shares Post $10.50 Gain
LEAD: Shares in Millicom Inc., a New York-based concern that develops cellular radio-telephone systems, soared yesterday after an analyst for Bear, Stearns &amp; Company issued a buy recommendation that valued the company's assets at $75 a share.
Millicom's stock jumped $10.50 a share yesterday, to $38.25.
Its gain of 37.8 percent was the largest among over-the-counter issues.

Game 5 of the Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series will be in Calgary on Wednesday night.

Market Place; Precipitous Drop In Cash Flows
LEAD: CASH flow has become the investment theme of the 1980's.
For much of the decade, investors who focused on corporate cash flow, which was growing much more rapidly than reported earnings, were able to turn in a superior performance.
Expectations of rising cash flows were a major reason that companies were willing to go deeply into debt to make acquisitions and leveraged buyouts.

U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Restrictions On Abortion Clinics
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Boston ruled yesterday that an effort by the Reagan Administration to prevent Federally financed family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions was unconstitutional.


Bell Begins Penalty
LEAD: George Bell, the Toronto Blue Jays' outfielder, began serving a two-game suspension yesterday after withdrawing an appeal for a hearing.


Addicts' Children Are Youngest Torture Victims
LEAD: To the Editor:


OIL CONCERNS FACE CHARGE IN INQUIRY
LEAD: Senate investigators contend that some oil companies have cheated Indians and the Interior Department out of millions of dollars of oil and oil royalties.


British Fusion Effort Fails
LEAD: Britain's top atomic energy laboratory said today it had failed to generate large amounts of energy by nuclear fusion at room temperature, despite the cooperation of a chemist who played a major role in a claim last month that such fusion had been achieved.
The announcement dampened hopes of finding a cheap and limitless source of energy.


Resetting Body Clock
LEAD: HIT the ground running after a long flight and the effect of jet lag may be reduced, researchers say.

Mets Silenced by Reds in 2d Straight Shutout
LEAD: The pitch was outside, and so Dave Magadan dropped his bat and began to walk toward first base with two out in the seventh inning.
Trouble was, it was only the third ball.
Magadan, alerted to the fact and then considerably embarrassed by it, had to turn and pick the bat up again.
He then promptly struck out.


Saatchi in Japan
LEAD: In Japan, Saatchi &amp; Saatchi consolidated its advertising subsidiaries on Friday, merging Tokyo-based Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Advertising K.K. with another Saatchi holding, Yomiko DFS.
The new agency will be named Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Advertising, Japan.
Yomiko DFS was itself a joint venture of Yomiko, Japan's seventh-largest agency, and Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, which was acquired by Saatchi in 1986.


SWISS HALT PLANS FOR PLANT IN IRAN
LEAD: A Swiss company has abandoned its plans to build a chemical plant in Iran that American officials feared could be used to make poison gas, Swiss officials say.


Fires Kill Two Adults And Two Children
LEAD: Fire sped through a three-story house in Queens early yesterday, killing two young sisters, and two men died in a Manhattan fire that fire officials said might have stemmed from drug use.
The fires left 44 people homeless.
In the Queens fire, Harjindar Kaur, 6 years old, and her sister, Kamaljit Kaur, 11, died when fire gutted the house they lived in at 94-17 41st Avenue in Corona, a Fire Department spokesman, Efrain


OPEC Output Spurt in April
LEAD: OPEC's oil output registered a faster monthly rise in April than in any other month since last autumn, with an average of 20.9 million barrels produced daily during the month, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today.


Vestige of Book Row: Ex-Owner on Sidewalk
LEAD: With all the alarm about the situation of the homeless, the problems of George Foss, who is shopless, is far down the list of things New Yorkers are worrying about.
Yet, Mr.
Foss's appearance as sidewalk purveyor on Broadway after a working lifetime under a roof is something of an exclamation point at the end of a New York cultural chapter that was called Booksellers'


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The oil and gas rig count rose last week by 13, to a total of 764, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A week earlier, the number of working oil and gas rigs had fallen by 16, the company said.
A year ago, the count totaled 897.
The count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.


Norman in Tournament
LEAD: Greg Norman of Australia yesterday became the last player from 1988's four-way, first-place playoff at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic to commit to play in this year's tournament at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.
The other three in the playoff who had enrolled earlier for this year's event, to be held June 8-11, are David Frost of South Africa, Ken Green of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Seve Ballesteros of Spain, the eventual winner of the playoff.


Police Shooting Suspect Said to Blame 2 Others
LEAD: A suspect in the shooting of an undercover narcotics officer Friday was held without bail yesterday after a prosecutor said he implicated two others in statements to the police.


Burson's Brace Is Off
LEAD: Doctors in Columbus, Ohio, removed yesterday a traction brace that had held the Ohio State player Jay Burson's head and neck rigid since a neck injury in mid-February cut short his senior season.


Panel to Discuss Threats to Rushdie
LEAD: The issues - First Amendment, legal and publishing - raised by the Iranian threats against the life of Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' are to be discussed in a seminar tomorrow sponsored by Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts, a New York public-service group.

2 Urge Extending Passaic Tunnel Plan
LEAD: Five years ago, the Passaic River in New Jersey overflowed its banks.
Three people lost their lives, scores were injured, and more than 9,000 had to be removed.
Thousands of homes and businesses were damaged at an estimated cost of $330 million.


Giant Planet
LEAD: Astronomers have detected the effects of a giant planet in orbit around a star.
But having gained one planet, scientists have lost a planetoid in the solar system, which has now been classed a comet.


Spending Is Catching Up With Revenue for Cities
LEAD: Cities and counties in the United States are increasing their spending faster than their income is rising, according to two new Census Bureau reports.

U.S. Confirms It Lost an H-Bomb Off Japan in '65
LEAD: Japan's tense relationship with the United States military worsened today with the disclosure that a hydrogen bomb, lost off an aircraft carrier 24 years ago, remains on the ocean floor 80 miles from a Japanese island.


Frederic Mueller, 53, iModern-Art Collector
LEAD: Frederic Bernhardt Mueller, a former partner in the Pace Gallery, a prominent contemporary-art dealership in Manhattan, died on May 1 at his home in Oahu, Hawaii.
He was 53 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on March 29 misstated the fat content of a three-strip serving of bacon.
As a fitness program manager has recently written to point out, the fat accounts for 81 calories and 77 percent of the caloric content.


Study Rejects Requiring School Bus Seat Belts
LEAD: The National Research Council, in a report commissioned by Congress, today recommended against requiring seat belts in school buses.
It said the potential safety benefits, saving one life a year, were not worth the cost, estimated at $40 million annually.


Argentine Military Junta Leader Is Out of Jail
LEAD: A former commander of the Argentine Air Force, Orlando Ramon Agosti, was released from prison today after completing his sentence for torture of political prisoners during the 1976-83 military regime.

Soviet Author With Strong Feelings About PEN
LEAD: As a short-story writer, Tatyana Tolstaya deals in ambiguities.
As a Soviet citizen, she knows how to live with them. ''Things can be good, while also being bad,'' said the 38-year-old great-grandniece of the author of ''War and Peace.'' ''We can understand contradictions.''


Commodity Inquiry Focuses On Sharing of Order Data
LEAD: The criminal investigation of trading practices at four New York commodity exchanges is examining whether brokers and traders illegally shared information with each other about customer orders, allowing them to make trades before the orders changed market prices, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.

LEAD: Over the years, choreographers have often created dances about people struggling on perilous journeys.

At their best, such dances are metaphors for life's mystery and uncertainty.
At their worst, they are cliche-ridden.

LEAD: An Air New Zealand jumbo jet carrying 350 people swerved to avoid a small plane less than 500 feet away over the Pacific Ocean, officials said today.

British Oil Output Drop
LEAD: British North Sea oil output this month could drop to its lowest level in a decade because of offshore accidents, allowing Norway to move into the top spot in Western Europe's monthly production table for the first time since 1976.
Gareth Lewis-Davies, an analyst at Woodmac, a brokerage that specializes in the study of North Sea oil developments, said the drop in British ouput was temporary and caused largely by the closing of the Brent pipeline system on April 18 after a gas explosion.


Interview Magazine Is Sold
LEAD: Brant Publications Inc., which publishes Art in America and Antiques magazines and special interest antiques books, has acquired Interview magazine from the estate of Andy Warhol.

Surgery for Mathews
LEAD: Greg Mathews, a St.
Louis Cardinal left-hander, will undergo surgery on his pitching elbow later this week and will miss the remainder of the season.
The surgery on Mathews, 26, will involve the transfer of ligaments from his right wrist to his left elbow.
After having soreness during spring training appearances, Mathews was sent to Louisville for a 20-day injury-rehabilitation assignment.


Public Shop Or Private, What's Best?
LEAD: The battle by the publicly held Ogilvy Group to remain independent in the face of a hostile bid by the WPP Group has sparked a debate in the advertising industry about the relative merits of public versus private ownership of agencies.
Publicly held agencies, including the WPP Group, say that only public ownership can provide the resources necessary for growth, even if it makes an agency vulnerable to market pressures.

Southland May Sell Its Stake in Citgo
LEAD: The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said it might sell its half-interest in the Citgo Petroleum Corporation and all or part of its distribution and food centers in order to reduce the debt it incurred in a leveraged buyout last year.
Southland's bank debt totals $1.56 billion.

LEAD: Two prospering regional banking companies, the Banc One Corporation and Barnett Banks Inc., are considering making offers for 20 banks formerly owned by Mcorp that are now controlled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a Texas banking consultant said today.

LEAD: The world has started to take very seriously the established threat to the life-protecting ozone layer from industrial chemicals.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Yawning  Q. Why do my mouth and eyes sometimes water when I yawn?
A.
The American Medical Association says that medical authorities believe the watering of the eyes may result from pressure on the main tear glands, at the outer margins of the eye sockets, because of the facial contortions involved in yawning.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  CYCLING  A Top Sprinter Takes 3d Stage: Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium used team strategy, then sprinted away from a dozen riders yesterday to claim the Lehigh Valley to Harrisburg Road Race, the third stage of the Tour de Trump.
Vanderaerden, considered one of the world's finest sprinters, rode conservatively into a steady headwind in a pack of about 50 riders during much of the 116.3-mile race through the farmlands of central Pennsylvania.


Mr. Bush's Sweet Wheat Deal
LEAD: Cynical politics!
Betrayal of the taxpayer!
Soft on the Russians!
On every side, President Bush's decision to subsidize wheat sales to the Soviet Union has ignited heated criticism.
But even on brief reflection, the criticism looks hasty, even unfair.
The costs of Mr.
Bush's decision are small.
The potential benefits are substantial.

LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that airlines cannot be forced to pay for a new Denver airport through higher usage fees, and the decision is expected to limit local governments' ability to raise funds to finance future airports, industry experts said yesterday.


2 CHEMISTS DEFEND FUSION EXPERIMENT
LEAD: Two chemists who assert that they have created nuclear fusion in a jar staunchly defended their experiment at a meeting Monday night, saying they had new evidence that their device produces bursts of energy.


Muslim Side in Lebanon Keeps Up Fierce Shelling to Deny Foe Arms
LEAD: Determination by Syrian troops and their Muslim militia allies to prevent new arms shipments from reaching Christian forces is keeping artillery battles at fierce pitch here despite an Arab-brokered cease-fire.


Citicorp Rates Fall
LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
It was the second straight drop this month.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.595 percent, down from 9.679 percent last week.
It also sold $50 million worth of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.423 percent, down from 9.561 percent.


Nissan Dealerships
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company's Infinity division has fallen significantly behind in opening dealerships for the fall introduction of its luxury cars, Ward's Auto Dealer, a trade publication, said.
Company officials confirmed they would have only 45 to 50 locations open by Nov. 8 instead of the planned 65 to 70.

Sotheby's to Sell Campbell Soup Heir's Art
LEAD: The art collection of John T. Dorrance Jr., heir to a Campbell Soup Company fortune, will be auctioned in October at Sotheby's.
The collection of Impressionist and modern art, French 18th-century furniture and Chinese, English and German porcelains is valued at $105 million to $140 million, which is believed to be the highest estimate for a single collection in auction history.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: ANCHOVIES, a staple of Mediterranean cooking, have never had widespread appeal in this country.
For one, fresh anchovies are rarely available to the home cook here.
Typically they are sold salted in jars or cans, yielding a product that has little relation to fresh anchovies, although the salted ones can be put to good use in many ways.

'Yo Picasso' Brings $47.9 Million at Sotheby's
LEAD: Picasso's ''Self-Portrait: Yo Picas-so,'' a 1901 blue-period painting that was bought in 1981 at Sotheby's for $5.8 million, was sold last night, again at Sotheby's, for $47.9 million.
The price was the second highest paid for an artwork at auction, a figure exceeded only by the $53.9 million paid in November 1987 in the same rooms for van Gogh's ''Irises.

Presidents, he turned a 3-to-1 victory for the opposition into a triumph for his own hand-picked presidential candidate, Carlos Duque.
According to Jimmy Carter and surveys coordinated by the Roman Catholic Church, the winner by a landslide was the challenger, Guillermo Endara.

LEAD: The Sri Lankan Government is expected to begin peace negotiations in the next few days with a guerrilla force that defied Colombo for a decade and held off the Indian Army for the last two years.

About Education

Dawson Is Hurt
LEAD: Andre Dawson, the Chicago Cubs' slugging outfielder who was the National League's most valuable player in 1987, has torn cartilage on the inside of his right knee and will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow.He is expected to be lost to his team for at least a month.
Dawson, who has had two previous operations on each knee, may also have damaged cartilage on the outside of the knee.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on April 14 about the use of foreign repair stations by United States air lines incorrectly described maintenance work done on Continental Airlines Boeing 747's by an Australian company.
With the special permission of the Federal Aviation Administration, Continental has had maintenance work performed in Australia since last October.

LEAD: Jose Canseco, the Oakland Athletics' outfielder, will undergo surgery today to remove part of a bone in his left wrist and will be out of the lineup six to eight weeks.

He suffered a fracture of the hamate bone in his wrist this spring.


Review/Dance; New 'Swan Lake' Opens Ballet Theater Season
LEAD: Relax.
Mikhail Baryshnikov's ambitious new production of ''Swan Lake'' for American Ballet Theater is not nearly so eccentric or revamped as advance word had it.


Glaxo Holdings Names New Chief Executive
LEAD: Ernest Mario, who heads Glaxo Inc., a large American pharmaceutical concern, yesterday was named chief executive of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., the parent company based in London.


Results Plus
LEAD:  TENNIS  Maleeva Wins: Manuela Maleeva led a parade of favorites through the second round of the Italian Open women's championships yesterday in Rome.
Second-seeded Maleeva of Bulgaria downed Barbara Romano of Italy, 6-3, 6-2; No. 3-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada romped over 17-year-old Silvia Farina of Italy, 6-2, 6-2, while fourth-seeded Aranxta Sanchez came on strong in the second set to beat Linda Ferrando of Italy, 7-5, 6-1.

LEAD: Aleksandr Mogilny, who left the Soviet national team in Stockholm last week to play for the Buffalo Sabres, filed for political asylum today in the United States.

LEAD: An Agriculture Department official said today that all federally inspected plants for slaughtering poultry and hogs in Arkansas had been put under ''intensified surveillance'' for traces of the pesticide heptachlor, which has been found to cause cancer in animals.

LEAD: The dollar ended slightly lower against the mark yesterday after comments by American officials dampened speculation in the United States and in Europe, traders said, of a change in the policies of the Group of Seven industrialized countries.

LEAD: Despite glowing reports of successful multimillion-dollar fund-raising drives, many of the nation's top research universities are having trouble sustaining both advanced research and strong undergraduate liberal arts programs.

Another Relapse
LEAD: Stanley Wilson, the former Cincinnati Bengal running back, who was suspended for substance abuse before Super Bowl XXIII, has suffered another relapse and has entered a drug rehabilitation clinic in Phoenix for three months, according to Reggie Turner, his attorney. ''Emotionally he's not handling things very well right now,'' said Turner, who added that he was concluding a deal with a magazine to publish Wilson's story of his drug relapse the night before the Super Bowl.

A Little Ingenuity Can Make Common Fare Uncommon
LEAD: WHEN I was a child growing up in France at the end of World War II, food was scarce and even ordinary staples were limited.
Nevertheless, my mother's ingenuity enabled her to create memorable meals for our family.
I still prepare variations on them today.
The accompanying recipes illustrate this imaginative cuisine, born of necessity.

New Polish Devaluation
LEAD: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, Monday for the fifth time this year, reducing its value by 4.23 percent, according to new exchange rates published by the official press agency P.A.P.
There were three devaluations last month, the most recent on April 24.
The new official rate, which applies only to foreign tourists and foreign trade dealings, is 710 zloties to the dollar, compared with 680 on Friday.

Castelli Gives Major Work to the Modern
LEAD: The art dealer Leo Castelli has given the Museum of Modern Art a major work of postwar American art, Robert Rauschenberg's 1955 ''Bed.'' A pre-Pop icon whose use of everyday objects influenced Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and their generation, ''Bed'' is a large ''combine painting'' composed of the artist's quilt, sheet and pillow savagely attacked with thick paint.

Topics of The Times; Sidewalk Enrichment
LEAD: A New York man who makes a habit of picking up coins on the street returned from a visit to Cambridge, Mass., to report that Harvard Square is paved with silver.
In New York, he's used to finding pennies.
But in just two days at a Harvard reunion, he netted four dimes.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: TO many parents, the thought of their children going through puberty raises feelings ranging from ambivalence to dread.
The physical changes in their children are a sign that their relationships are going to change as well.
Parents expect that the surge of hormones that leads to new body hair, changing shapes and cracking voices will also bring about dramatic changes in their children's behavior, including increased moodiness, defiance and outbursts of anger.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about a reunion of the Columbia School of Journalism class of 1939 misidentified the teacher to whom Bernard Redmont referred when he recalled, ''He asked us to use whatever color paper we could write on the fastest, so I always used green.'' It was the author Walter B. Pitkin, not Douglas Southall Freeman.

Reviews/Dance; The Balanchine Who Was a Master of Classic Simplicity
LEAD: George Balanchine's ''Ballo della Regina,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, is an exuberant, often giddy exercise in classical dancing set to rollicking music from Verdi's ''Don Carlo.'' There are passages for the corps filled with the simplest and least adorned of classroom steps, and so the ballet, like some of the choreography Balanchine made for children, offers yet another look at Balanchine as a master of vibrant simplicity.

LEAD: Sing another ''Happy Birthday'' to Irving Berlin.
At 101 years old today, he may be America's most celebrated and adored centenarian, and is certainly the most melodic.
Otherwise, according to a report by the Census Bureau, he's fairly typical.

Navy Fire Victims Named
LEAD: The Navy today released the names of the six sailors killed Tuesday in a fire on the supply ship White Plains in the South China Sea.
Killed were Baxter Lesarlley, of Santa Fe, N.M.; Jon Rummel, of Elmira, N.Y.; Muoi Cao, of Ventura, Calif.; Todd Follis, of Zuni, N.M.; Paul Novotny, of Howells, Me.; and Darryl Edwards, of Flossmoor, Ill.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in some editions of Business Day yesterday misidentified a New York commodity trader who received a subpoena from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as part of its investigation of the futures markets.
It was Paul Tudor Jones 2d (not John Tudor Jones) who said he had been informed that he was not a target of the investigation.


Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column in Business Day on April 13 about the promotion of consumer products in movies referred incorrectly to appearances arranged for Molson beer.
It was a company called Advertising in Movies, not the Entertainment Marketing Group, that placed the beer in the film ''Wall Street.'' Molson was not used on television in ''Thirtysomething'' or ''Dallas.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about auto makers' calls for changes in the financing of health care misstated the timing of severance benefits to 200,000 former employees of General Motors.
Benefits were paid in 1987 to those who had been laid off, but they were no longer covered in 1988.

Record Alligator Is Caught
LEAD: A trapper has harpooned the biggest alligator on record in Florida, a 13-foot, 10 1/2-inch reptile that weighed 1,043 pounds.
Biologists needed a tow truck to maneuver the animal onto three scales.
Columbus White, a licensed trapper, hauled the alligator out of a lake near Gainesville April 17 because patrons of a nearby fish camp felt threatened, the Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission said Tuesday.

Stay out of the way of the mayhem and don't get caught doubled up in laughter.

LEAD: April sales among several of New York's biggest retailers increased by an average of 7.3 percent in the city and 8.9 percent in the metropolitan area from the period a year ago, a spot-check found yesterday.

LEAD: ''ENLARGE!
Enliven!
Enlighten!'' says the tour guide in ''Lettice and Lovage,'' the Peter Shaffer hit in London.
Enlarge indeed.
This eccentric guide varnishes her facts as regularly as the Victorians varnished their woodwork.
Not to worry.
In return for her ''enhancement'' of Elizabethan history, this theatrical fancifier wins her audience, if not historical purists.

LEAD: The Socialist Workers Party said yesterday that it had nominated James Harris, 41 years old, of Brooklyn, a former member of the United Auto Workers, as its candidate for mayor.

Personal Health
LEAD: The last two decades have seen a dramatic improvement in the ability to prevent and treat life-threatening heart disease.
Changes in living habits, like eating less fat, stopping smoking and getting more exercise, are stemming the epidemic of coronary deaths.
And the lives of those already afflicted with heart disease are being prolonged by coronary care units, pacemakers, bypass surgery and drugs that stimulate the heart, thin the blood and lower cholesterol and blood pressure.

Swedish Savings Plan
LEAD: The Swedish Finance Minister, Kjell-Olof Feldt, proposed Wednesday that the Government force Swedes to save money to cool the country's overheated economy.
Under his plan, private citizens and companies would add 4 percent to their tax bills.

KENYA TO SEEK BAN ON TRADE OF IVORY
LEAD: In a reversal of position, Kenya announced today that it would seek a worldwide ban on the trade of ivory, a move intended to preserve its fast dwindling elephant herds.


Zoning Upheld Against Stores For Sex Books
LEAD: New York State's highest court today narrowly upheld the right of municipalities to enact zoning laws that force bookstores and theaters that sell sexually explicit material to move out of downtown shopping areas and into less-visited neighborhoods like industrial districts.


Reviews/Film; 'Fistfighter,' Barehanded Vengeance
LEAD: George Rivero, the silver-haired star of ''Fistfighter,'' looks far too mature for the role of a man who can whip to a quivering pulp anything that stands in his way.
As C. J. Thunderbird, a muscle-bound drifter who sets out to avenge the death of a boxer friend, he creams several fighting machines that are younger, meaner and hulkier than he is.


An Outlandish Event for a Serious Cause


A Seamless Safety Net
LEAD: The Federal safety net is sagging.
In the 1930's it was possible to fashion a social welfare policy around a few key ingredients - old-age pensions, unemployment insurance, aid to dependent children.
But now, says an ambitious new Ford Foundation report, insuring a basic standard of living will require a policy that spans the whole life cycle of people in need.


Rail Officer Dismissed In Job Fraud Scheme
LEAD: A Long Island Rail Road police officer was dismissed after his arrest yesterday for reportedly collecting $8,000 in sick pay while working as a substitute teacher on Long Island.


Behind Bulls' Fire A Coach to Match
LEAD: Doug Collins attended a Broadway play Wednesday night, enjoying a temporary escape from the stress of coaching the Chicago Bulls.
A few years ago, Collins might have felt guilty taking a break during the playoffs.
But while Collins remains one of basketball's most intense coaches, he is gradually learning to relax.


T.V.A. to Retire High-Rate Bonds
LEAD: The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to retire about $750 million of high-interest bonds and save itself $30 million in interest payments annually.


In the Footsteps of Saint-Exupery
LEAD: WALKING tours have become a bustling and imaginative industry.
As the weather begins to turn warm, tours proliferate to the point where it is possible, as it is this weekend, to choose from walks in most of the boroughs with a staggering variety of themes.
New Yorkers now know a good deal more about the city's nooks and crannies and its cultural and social history.


2 Officers Charged in a Racial Assault on a Man
LEAD: Two New York City police officers were charged yesterday with beating a man and subjecting him to racial abuse, the latest indictment in an investigation of allegations of brutality by white officers against minority-group members in Queens.

First, because she has won the Ladies' Professional Golf Association event four times and second, because of her friendship with the late Peter Busatti, the founder of the tournament.

LEAD: Richard J. Phelan of Chicago, the investigator on the brink of bringing down the Speaker of the House, was once described as a lawyer who takes a ''wide-angle approach'' to his cases.

LEAD: The Bush Administration proposed comprehensive legislation today establishing a Federal fund to pay for cleaning up oil spills, an idea that had languished in Congress for years until the recent Alaskan spill.

LEAD: Steve Friedman, who created ''USA Today: The Television Show,'' has resigned, effective May 29, as president of GTG East, which produces the program.

On Stage
LEAD:  'Perestroika' at Purchase This summer is the last call for the Pepsico Summerfare festival held at the Performing Arts Center in Purchase, N.Y.
After 10 years and contributions of almost $10 million, Pepsico, which produces the festival with the State University College at Purchase, is pulling out because, a spokesman said, ''it is felt that the amount involved is too much to devote to one project.


Winning Colors Looks to Get Untracked
LEAD: When was the last time Winning Colors won a race?
Unlikely as it seems, she has not seen a winner's circle since last year's Kentucky Derby.


Financial Aid Proposal
LEAD: Dick Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday that he favored the adoption of a rule that would enable athletes who need financial aid to receive funds over current Federal limitations.


Alar Ban Is Coming
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it expects within 10 days to begin formal steps to ban the apple-ripening agent Alar, which has been called a health threat, especially for children.
The process could take as long as three years.
The Processed Apples Institute said sales of such products as juice and sauce are off 20 percent from last year because of fears about Alar use by some growers.


Market Place; Global Traders Get New Vehicle
LEAD: DO American financial markets need a quick and easy way to bet on the direction of stock prices in the rest of the world?
The answer will start to become clearer today, as futures and options begin trading on an index of foreign stocks.


Giamatti Schedules a Hearing For Rose to Respond to Report
LEAD: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti yesterday scheduled a hearing for Pete Rose for May 25, an indication that he feels he has enough evidence of possible wrongdoing to warrant giving the Cincinnati Reds' manager an opportunity to defend himself.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  THE WESTERN REPRISED


Huge Peronist Rally Ends Campaign
LEAD: The memory of Juan D. Peron came vibrantly alive in Argentina today as Carlos Saul Menem, the Peronist presidential candidate, ended his campaign to outpourings of adoration and expectation.


In Pursuit of the Clever Quotemaster
LEAD: Their names can be found in Rolodexes all over town.
They are the Washington quotemasters, those political analysts, economists, Sovietologists and Washington hostesses who are masters of the acute observation, the pithy quote, the succinct declarative statement.


Stood Up for Prom, She Files a Lawsuit
LEAD: A 15-year-old girl is suing the boy who was to take her to the high school prom, contending he owes her about $50 for the shoes, flowers and hairdo she never got to wear.


Max Gordon, 86, Jazz Promoter And Founder of Vanguard, Dies
LEAD: Max Gordon, who for 54 years operated the Village Vanguard, one of the most influential clubs in jazz history, died yesterday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 86 years old.


After Debate, Schwarz Yields on Land-Use Plan
LEAD: Two weeks ago, the chairman of the panel that is rewriting the New York City Charter proposed radically altering the way that public and private land is governed.
On Wednesday, he proposed that such decisions be made much the way they are now, but by an appointive body instead of by elected officials.


Reviews/Art; Fame in No Hurry for Arnold Friedman
LEAD: If during his lifetime Arnold Friedman never enjoyed the success he deserved, the painter has received his share of attention lately.
Friedman's work was shown sporadically before his death in 1946, and during the next 34 years it appeared in only 11 exhibitions of one sort or another.


A Chance for Budget Honesty
LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee wants President Bush to face up to the true budgetary costs of bailing out bankrupt savings and loans.
The committee is right.
Mr.
Bush's financing plan is a transparent effort to avoid the appearance of a bigger budget deficit.
It's also needlessly expensive.


League Post Filled
LEAD: Carl F. Ullrich, the director of athletics at Army, was named executive director of the Colonial League.
Ullrich will serve in a dual capacity as West Point's director and the Colonial's leader for the 1989-90 academic year and then become the full-time executive director.


Amgen Rises $3
LEAD: Shares of Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., rose $3, to $40, in over-the-counter trading yesterday after a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended approval for erythropoietin to combat anemia in patients with kidney problems, before or during dialysis treatment.


Yanks Heading West, Perhaps Into Trouble
LEAD: The last time the Yankees made a 10-game trip to the West Coast they had one of their three most successful three-city Western journeys ever.
But the last time they went to the West Coast they suffered their most disastrous three-city Western journeys ever.


2 Wall Street Firms Join To Buy Savings Units
LEAD: With great fanfare, two of Wall Street's leading investment banks said yesterday that they were teaming up with another partner to mine investment opportunities in the troubled savings and loan industry.

LEAD: These are not cheery times in Wooster Square, an old, once-seedy Italian neighborhood near Yale University that in recent years has become a stylish favorite among those with a taste for Brooklyn-style brownstones and National Register of Historic Places plaques.

In a Roguish Gallery: One Aging Black Ballerina
LEAD: Eleanora Antinova, an aging American black ballerina who long ago danced in Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, is outrageous, egomaniacal, grande dame-ish and full of pain.
She is also the alter ego of Eleanor Antin, a white performance artist, who made Eleanora up out of whole - well - tulle in the mid-1970's, and has been playing her ever since.


Sears Still Looking
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company is still searching for a new headquarters for its 6,000-person merchandising group, but the group prefers to stay in the Chicago area, said Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman.
At a news conference after Sears's annual meeting, Mr.
Brennan said Sears continued to review relocation proposals from cities around the country.

Wright.

'Star Wars' Plan Facing a Delay, Its Director Says
LEAD: The Bush Administration is delaying development of key parts of Ronald Reagan's antimissile plan for two years while it studies a proposal that could radically alter it, the project's new director said today.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about oil-production shutdowns in the North Sea misstated the timing for a resumption of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's operations at its Piper Alpha platform, which was severely damaged in a gas explosion last July.
Occidental will submit its plans for restarting production on Piper Alpha to the British Government this summer, and, if the Government approves, the company said it hopes to resume operations by 1992.

Writers Guild Votes
LEAD: The Writers Guild of America, East has voted overwhelmingly to affiliate with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
The union, which represents 3,200 writers of television shows and feature movies, CBS and ABC news writers and other news personnel, voted Wednesday night to become part of the Department for Professional Employees of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which already includes such unions as the Screen Actors Guild.

LEAD: Western military analysts say that by announcing plans to scrap some short-range nuclear weapons, Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave West Germany support in the campaign for talks on such weapons.

LEAD: Medical experts say that increasingly the victims of fatal asthma attacks fall into two groups: black and Hispanic people, who often lack access to medical care, and patients who have suffered from the disease for a long time, treating it themselves using prescribed medications.

On a slightly less goofy level, it is a nostalgic chance for baby boomers to escape to the toy-and-television culture of their childhoods.

LEAD: The nation's retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, a smaller rebound from the lackluster trend of the two previous months than economists expected.

A Medieval Marketplace
LEAD: The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, is to hold its annual Medieval Marketplace tomorrow to raise money for its community outreach programs, which include a soup kitchen, a shelter for the homeless, an AIDS ministry and a summer day camp.
The 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. event is to feature musicians playing medieval hurdy-gurdies, puppeteers, home-baked goods, antiques, collectibles, clothing, toys and books.

Use of Jail Barges Is Backed
LEAD: New York City can use two converted barges as jails, a judge ruled yesterday.
Acting Justice Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, saying jail crowding is at crisis levels, refused to issue a preliminary injunction against use of the Bibby Resolution, moored at Pier 36 in the East River at the foot of Montgomery and Clinton Streets.

LEAD: Arthur C. Austin, a former conductor and radio producer, died of cancer Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital.
He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds rose by $2.9 billion, to $307.06 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $1.29 billion, to $76.8 billion.
The assets of the 232 general-purpose funds were up by $1.03 billion, to $100.80 billion.

Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Interest rates on both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate home loans rose in April to their highest levels in more than three years, the Government reported Wednesday.
Fixed-rate mortgages in early April rose 0.21 percentage point from the previous month, to 11.58 percent, and adjustable-rate mortgages rose 0.37 point, to 10.14 percent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported.

LEAD: The White House and the Justice Department have pledged to the House ethics committee that the Justice Department will not undertake any investigation of House Speaker Jim Wright until after the committee has completed all its work, senior officials on Capitol Hill said today.

The Wrong Road to Auto Insurance
LEAD: The California Supreme Court's recent decision on Proposition 103 contains a lesson for the nation: On the subject of automobile insurance, there's no free ride.
Instead of seeking relief from high rates in plebiscites, consumers would do better to demand measured, rational legislative remedies, beginning with genuine no-fault insurance.

Montedison S.p.A.
LEAD: The Italian Cabinet approved a measure effectively giving the chemical giant Montedison S.p.A. a significant tax break on the planned merger of its chemical business with state companies in the sector.
The decree would cut the capital gains tax liability of Italian companies involved in strategic mergers or joint ventures by 75 percent to encourage such alliances in the national economic interest.

LEAD: Midori, the remarkable Japanese violinist, is 17 years old now, and despite her diminutive stature has long since graduated to a full-size violin -a Guarnerius del Jesu, in fact, which not all 17-year-olds get to play.
She and her mother and her management have been properly cautious about capitalizing on her fame as a prodigy.

LEAD: Now celebrating its 10th anniversary, the Chicago International Art Exposition is, by exhibitor and visitor consensus, one of the best and biggest art fairs in the world.

Mussolini in Balkans
LEAD: To the Editor:


Surprise in the Andes
LEAD: As democracy was being mugged in Panama, it was showing surprising resilience this week in Bolivia, a country once synonymous with instability.
An orderly presidential vote produced no majority winner, so the final selection will again be made by the congress when it convenes in August.
Strikingly, the front-runners are Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, the architect of a tough economic stabilization plan, and former President Hugo Banzer, who endorses it.

LEAD: As unpredictable as the recent weather in Ohio, Fuzzy Zoeller left everyone gaping in disbelief today as he not only maintained his lead in the 14th annual Memorial Tournament, but also increased it from one stroke to five.

Reviews/Music; Africa's Vast Variety, In Sights and Sounds
LEAD: Pygmies from the rain forests of Zaire, their bodies dappled in paint, cross the stage in a loping crouch, singing in complex, staggered counterpoint.
From Niger, two pipers with puffed cheeks (on the shawm-like alghaita) and two drummers, all in long robes, move in slow processional, playing starkly penetrating melodies.

LEAD: Steve Ross's program at L'Omnibus de Maxim's, Madison Avenue at 61st Street, where he will be singing at the piano Wednesdays through Saturdays until June 3, pays its respects to the well-established sources one might expect in such a setting - Cole Porter, the Gershwins, Noel Coward.

LEAD: R. Philip Custer, emeritus senior member of the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, whose career in cancer research spanned nearly six decades, died of congestive heart failure May 3 at his home in Narberth, Pa.
He was 85 years old.


Critics of Test Find Merit Scholar Field Is Three-Fifths Boys
LEAD: More than three-fifths of this year's National Merit Scholarship semifinalists are boys, according to a report by a research group that has charged that the standardized test used in selecting the students is sexually biased.


Black Wins $40,000 Under Stiff Housing Law
LEAD: In a reflection of newly strengthened provisions of the Fair Housing Act, a Florida mobile home community has agreed to pay a black New Jersey woman $40,000 for discrimination.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Lendl and Becker Gain: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, the top two seeded players, reached the semifinals of the German Open tournament yesterday in Hamburg, West Germany.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 13, 1989
LEAD:  Economy


News Summary
LEAD:  International 3-7  President Bush's Soviet policy was outlined in a long-awaited speech.
He cautioned that Moscow still had to earn warmer ties with the West and resurrected a proposal for East-West aerial surveillance.
Page 1  Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut was welcomed by the Western allies, but diplomats said the move only aggravates the divisions within NATO over negotiations on curbing short-range missiles.


Esteban de Jesus Is Dead at 37; Former Lightweight Champion
LEAD: Esteban de Jesus, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion from 1976 through 1978, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in San Juan, P.R.
He was 37 years old.


Transactions
LEAD:  Baseball


Runaway Freight Train Derails, Killing 3
LEAD: A speeding freight train hauling 69 carloads of potash derailed this morning in San Bernardino, demolishing a row of houses, killing a trainman and two children and shaking the area like an earthquake, officials and residents said.
At least one person is missing.


3 Killed in Bronx, but Infant Is Unharmed
LEAD: Two men and a woman were found shot to death in a Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, but the woman's 4-month-old daughter was found unharmed in her crib, the police said.


Add Kiki To Knicks' Chemistry
LEAD: In the weeks before the Knicks finally acquired Kiki Vandeweghe, every New York basketball lab technician wondered how the 30-year-old jump-shooter with the bad back would affect the ''chemistry'' of this young team.
But as the Knicks awaited today's third game of their Eastern Conference semifinal with the Bulls in Chicago, their test tubes were bubbling over with a new potion.


Kremlin Move On Arms Adds To NATO Split
LEAD: Western allies today welcomed Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut, but diplomats said the Soviet move had only aggravated the divisions in the NATO alliance over talks on reducing short-range nuclear weapons.


Ethics Panel Seeks Bank Records Of Loan to Wright for Investment
LEAD: The House ethics committee has requested the bank records of a $100,000 loan that House Speaker Jim Wright received in 1983 to finance his investment in a nursing home business, a bank official said today.

LEAD: A former lobbyist for Teledyne Electronics was sentenced today to six months in prison for his role in a scheme to pay bribes for inside information about a military contract.

LEAD: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said today that the United States had begun consulting foreign governments to see whether any would accept Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama if he could be persuaded to give up power.


Disney Stock Soars
LEAD: The stock of the Walt Disney Company gained sharply today for the second consecutive day, propelled by strong attendance at its new movie theme park and overall enthusiasm for the company's prospects, analysts said.
Disney rose $5 a share today, to $92.125, after climbing $1.25 on Thursday.
The movie park, which opened on May 1 as part of the Disney World complex in Orlando, Fla., is expected to increase total attendance at Disney's Orlando site by about 20 percent, said Christopher Dixon, an analyst for Kidder, Peabody.


BUSH VOICES HOPE ON SOVIET CHANGE, BUT WITH CAUTION
LEAD: In a long-awaited speech on Soviet-American policy, President Bush said today that the United States was ready to welcome the Soviet Union ''back into the world order.'' But he cautioned that Moscow still had to earn the right to a new and warmer relationship with Western nations.

He was 91 years old.

LEAD: A great sitarist, like any other classical virtuoso, must have a command of extremes, from infinitesimal subtleties of pitch and timbre to crowd-pleasing displays of speed.
Unlike Western classical musicians, a sitarist reveals his prowess in music that is likely to be almost entirely improvised.

Guidepost; Things That Lock
LEAD: This is the time to repair winter's wear and tear on locks, other door and window hardware and window sashes.
Simple lubrication is almost always the remedy.
Lightweight household oil is the standby.
But newer products that contain silicone or Teflon do not stain as oil sometimes does, and won't harm paint or woodwork.

Inflation Fears Given Some Relief
LEAD: Inflation worries eased considerably in response to some new statistics.
Wholesale prices for April showed an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent, much less than expected.
Gasoline prices, up 7.2 percent, had their steepest monthly rise in nearly two and a half years, but were offset by declines in food and auto prices.

ARTFUL SURVIVOR

I like calm and continuity.
I think as a person I'm very controlling, and I'm afraid of big risks.
I'm not a skier or a mountain climber or a motorcyclist.
And I'm not a safari girl - I never want to go on a safari.
My safaris are all on the studio floor.

The Three Sisters
LEAD: THE PLANS ARE THUS: ON JULY 4, 1992, surrounded by an international armada of Tall Ships, a replica of Christopher Columbus's tiny fleet - comprising the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria - will arrive in New York Harbor, commencing the party of the half-millennium.
In celebration of the quincentennial of Columbus's first trans-Atlantic voyage from Iberia to the New World, the ships will stop in the Bahamas at San Salvador, now Watlings Island, the probable site of Columbus's first landing.

Now, at the age of 20, she has returned to her native land, hoping to find Mamta, the mysterious tribal woman who she believes is her mother.

LEAD: At one point in ''Cowboys,'' a documentary produced in 1976 (as part of ''Bill Moyers's Journal'') about the difficult but rewarding life of cowboys in northwestern Colorado, one of the subjects says, ''All we can know is our own time.'' For Bill Moyers, one of the most celebrated and at times controversial producers of documentary films, it is a key phrase: ''That is what compels me as a journalist, to know as much as I can of my own time.

MOSCOW CAUTIONS NATO ON REPLACING MISSILES IN EUROPE
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that if NATO decided to replace and improve its short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, the Soviet Union would consider either halting the dismantling of its own nuclear rockets or developing a new weapon.

It is simply a question of laying off the saturated fats.
The recipes below are substantial enough for company; they have little fat but get plenty of flavor from marinades and light sauces.

LEAD: AS gasoline retailers converted to self-service, drivers had to get used to the idea that they might not be able to count on their local service station to make repairs, change tires or even clean their windshields.

IT GRIPES ME TO SAY THIS
LEAD: Gripe did originally mean grip, as Roy Blount says in his article, but that's not the point here.
An old meaning of gripe is intestinal pain, and because people with a bellyache often go around bellyaching, the word eventually acquired the slang meaning ''complaint.''  LOUIS JAY HERMAN  New York, N.Y.


PASTIMES: Camera
LEAD: There's no arguing about the usefulness of filters.
With slide films they are virtually a necessity, since you can't fiddle much with the image after it has been shot.
But even those of us who use color-negative films, which can readily be color-corrected in the printing stage, find good reasons to put filters in front of our lenses.


Bob Hiemstra - Fashion Illustrator
LEAD: His talent is to be able to draw in such a way that the result always looks as if it had been done in a flash, even if, as Bob Hiemstra, a fashion illustrator, explained, ''It took five days rather than five minutes to get it off the drawing board.''

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into.
I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long.
The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing.
This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.


Banker's Lady Wins Shuvee
LEAD: Banker's Lady proved herself the new queen of American racing by running Winning Colors into defeat and then pulling clear to a 2 1/4-length victory over Rose's Cantina in the $174,300 Shuvee Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.


Mission Decor in a Carolina Inn
LEAD: WE were on an unsteady course toward the lounge.
A friend and I had stopped for a drink at the Grove Park Inn in Asheville, N.C., and as we walked down a long, wide corridor, I was drawn left and then right, again and again.
I wove this way toward a big hulk of an oak sideboard or that way toward a severe-looking couch with wooden slats at its sides and back.


PASTIMES: Numismatics
LEAD: It's been nearly 75 years since the British passenger liner Lusitania was torpedoed by a German submarine.
The ship's sinking slowly sucked the United States into World War I and inspired one of the most controversial medals ever made.
That medal and others by the German sculptor Karl Goetz will be sold at auction today at the Omni Park Central Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 56th Street at 1 P.M.


Using Scaffolding Instead of Ladders
LEAD: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders.
Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand.
Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.


MEDICAL JARGON
LEAD: In his response to Morton Hunt's article, Dr.
Weiss insults a large portion of the public whose intelligent command of medical jargon is as natural to them as his own is to him.
No one, especially the patient, is better served by the use of ''everyday names'' to describe symptoms.
How can ''my belly hurts'' possibly supply nuances that a detailed description of the location, intensity and duration of pain would not?


A Youthful Subculture on Capitol Hill
LEAD: They call themselves ''Hill people,'' a subculture of the recent college graduates who hold many of the 19,000 staff jobs in the offices of senators, representatives and congressional committees on Capitol Hill.
They perform similar jobs, associate with similar friends, frequent the same night spots, survive on the same shoestring budgets and a good many of them are at least toying with the idea of devoting their lives to public service.


Ardsley Perspective On the Soviet Union
LEAD: ''Soviet Travel: Friendship and Flexibility'' by Roberta Hershenson  [ April 9 ]  brought back memories.
My son John, a 15-year-old Ardsley High School sophomore at the time, was with his teacher, Larry Mayer, on that first trip to the U.S.S.R.
That was 10 years ago this month.

When Dissidents Are Free, What Are They?
LEAD: NOT so long ago, ''dissident'' was a widely used term whose meaning was obvious.
As he spoke out on injustice from his banishment in Gorky in the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov was certainly a dissident.
In Poland, Adam Michnik and Jacek Kuron were clearly dissidents as they condemned a system that retaliated by jailing them or keeping them out of work.

Precisionism With Emotion
LEAD: GEORGE AULT (1891-1948) was a Precisionist to the degree that he reduced architectural forms to a geometry inspired by Cubism.
But where Charles Sheeler and other Precisionists purged their scenery of all human associations, Ault charged his with emotion.

CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; A Street Festival 20 Years Later: Fun, Not Protest
LEAD: What a difference a couple of decades can make.
In 1969, the University of Wisconsin's Miflin Street Block Party became the focal point for a three-day student protest that left 80 people injured, 20 of them police officers.
These days it is just a happy one-day festival.


Manila Uncovers Mass Grave
LEAD: The Philippine military said today it had uncovered a grave with the bodies of at least 13 Communist rebels killed as spies by their comrades.
An army statement said soldiers dug up the grave on Friday in the mountains south of Manila after a former rebel confessed that his companions had killed guerrillas suspected of being agents of the military.

Prospects; The Dollar Flies Higher
LEAD: Last week the dollar rallied against the world's other major trading currencies, reaching a 30-month high against the West German mark, an 18-month high against the British pound and an eight-month high against the Japanese yen.
Although the central banks of the major industrial powers - the G-7 - have intervened in the currency markets to push down the dollar, the effect has been negligible.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into.
I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long.
The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing.
This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.


Judge Drops Hiring Quotas For New York State Police
LEAD: Nearly a decade after imposing strict quotas for the hiring of minorities and women by the New York State police, a Federal judge has lifted his court order and commended the department for its recruitment efforts.


The Perfect New England Village
LEAD: ON three summer days in 1681, the Puritan settlers of Hingham, midway between Plymouth and Boston, raised the frame of their new meetinghouse.
For inspiration, they drew on what they remembered of church architecture in England, then dominated by the Elizabethan Gothic style.
But because they lacked the stone or bricks of the home country, they used the available local material, large virgin timbers.


PASTIMES: Chess
LEAD: Most experienced tournament players distrust radical early violent mating attacks - they've seen too many of them flop - so it is a terrible embarrassment when one of these coffeehouse adventures achieves a smashing success.


Using Scaffolding Instead of Ladders
LEAD: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders.
Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand.
Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.


MEDICAL JARGON
LEAD: The letters from two physicians, Wendy S. Aronson and Carl Austin Weiss (April 16), critical of Morton Hunt's Body and Mind article ''Patients' Rights'' (March 5), merely serve to reinforce the extraordinarily cogent points Mr.
Hunt was trying to make.
To wit, too many doctors nowadays have become haughty, arrogant, too busy to listen, and clutching at the pedestals they themselves have erected on patients' backs.

Bright colors.

Sheer fabrics.
Beach dresses.
Polka dots.
Molded bras.
Neoprene.
Want to be in fashion at the seaside this summer?
Wear suntan lotion, a big straw hat and at least one of the above.


THE WHITE SHIRT
LEAD: You devoted five pages of your magazine to displaying five white shirts, none of which costs less than $132 (Fashion: ''The White Shirt,'' April 23).
I suppose there are some who might pay $560 for a white shirt.
The shirt itself is very good-looking.
And the price tag may serve to convince them they've bought something stylish and elegant.

Steps to Ban Alar Announced
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced steps to prohibit the use of Alar on apples and other foods but said final action is not likely for at least 18 months.

FICTION
LEAD:  CLOSER.
By Dennis Cooper. (Grove, $15.95.) The gay teen-age boys who populate this short, brutal novel are not entirely indistinguishable from one another, but their energetic couplings betray a fatal sameness that is only occasionally relieved by the homicidal fetishes of their older lovers.
Some readers have found similarities between the novelist and art critic Dennis Cooper's work and that of Jean Genet or William Burroughs, but it must be said that he lacks the ordering instincts of the one and the wild comedy of the other.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into.
I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long.
The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing.
This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.

New 'Circle' Is Suburban Bluegrass
LEAD: Tradition can be a tricky thing.
In the broadest sense, just about all music is traditional, unless it uses unique instruments and brand-new structures.
And in the narrowest sense, virtually no music is purely traditional since each new interpretation alters the tradition in some way - although that process is itself a traditional one, as oral traditions constantly sift promising innovations from indulgences and tangents.

LEAD: ON a bright April morning, a wrong turn landed me on Belleville Avenue in New Bedford, Mass.

In the blocked roadway stood a construction worker, watching the machine and chewing at a bread and meat combination in his hand.


PASTIMES: Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: After the soil has dried out, continue planting, especially container-grown perennials and shrubs.
Indoors use at half-rate, a water-soluble fertilizer on seedlings, which will be transplanted to the garden later this month.
Snap faded flowers off daffodils, tulips and other spring blooming bulbs to avoid the formation of unwanted seed pods.


Turning On the Research Switch
LEAD: Time was when most companies felt that research and development was something they had to do for themselves and technology developed by others was adopted only as a last resort.
However, as international competitive pressures have grown and research has become more expensive, that ''not-invented-here'' syndrome has faded.


FOR THOSE WILLNG TO PAY, CATALOGUES OF CATALOGUES
LEAD: The idea of charging customers for catalogues may seem ridiculous.
But the concept could be just the ticket to offset retailers' higher postal expenses and winnow browsers from their mailing lists.
People who pay for catalogues, after all, are more likely to place orders.

Water Rules Near End After Rain and Thrift
LEAD: With millions of twists of the wrist, New Yorkers have saved about 5 billion gallons of water since a drought emergency was declared almost two months ago, helping set the stage for the possible lifting of some water-use restrictions tomorrow.

LEAD: To Stephen Doyle, a 32-year-old co-conspirator behind the design of the magazines Spy, In Fashion and The New Republic, graphic design is a bit like driver's education. ''You communicate through layout,'' he said. ''Type tells the reader when to speed up and when to put the brakes on.''

Pretoria's Forces Halt Pursuit of Namibian Rebels
LEAD: South African Army units stopped their search for rebels in northern Namibia and returned to their bases today under an international agreement that requires insurgents of the South-West Africa People's Organization to withdraw at least 90 miles inside Angola.


Bush Crime Proposal Relies On Deterrence, Aides Say
LEAD: President Bush plans to announce a $1.5 billion anticrime proposal Monday aimed at increasing the number of prisons and law-enforcement officers as well as broadening the use of the death penalty for convicted murderers, Administration officials said today.


A Debate About The Inevitability, And the Fragility, Of Democracy
LEAD: IN the 19th century, it could be said that there were two alternative predictions about mankind's future.
Marx proclaimed the inevitability of world socialism while Toqueville asserted that democracy, which he saw with some trepidation as rule by the consent of the governed, would surely replace rule by the few.

IN THE NATION: Houston; A Disney Creation for Visitors To the Johnson Space Center
LEAD: SINCE 1964, when what is now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center was built on 1,600 acres of prairie land donated to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Rice University, the aerospace industry has been an integral part of Houston's identity as well as its economy.


Red Lobster Blues
LEAD: To the Editor:


Debating States' Rights In South Asian Nations
LEAD: LAST week, as ethnic Tamil guerrillas met with leaders of Sri Lanka for the first time, the hope in everyone's mind was that a political formula could be found for ending six years of civil war.
The formula under discussion was the classic device used by democratic nations to make room for regional differences: federalism.


Louisville
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9).
The J.B.
Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's ...
Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years.


Most on Board Are Seeking A New Chancellor by Fall
LEAD: Most of the members of the New York City Board of Education say they hope to install a successor to Dr.
Richard R. Green, the Schools Chancellor who died Wednesday, by the opening of school in September.


MEDICAL JARGON
LEAD: If Mrs.
Hunt was describing her symptoms accurately, what difference does it make whose jargon she was using?
If she understood the terms and used them comfortably in speaking to someone who also understood them, the only impediment to the transfer of information would be the arrogance of a physician who is threatened by an informed, intelligent patient.


Can the U.S. Bail Out Thrifts Without Sinking Real Estate?
LEAD: AS the Bush Administration's proposed savings and loan bailout works its way through Congress, more and more attention is being paid to a peculiar challenge: how to carry out the plan without worsening the depression in Southwestern real estate prices that helped cause the crisis in the first place.

''Choice'' Schools Isn't the Whole Answer
LEAD: ''Move for Parental Choice in School Gains'' (April 16) seems to favor Gov.
Thomas H. Kean's simplistic approach to improve the quality of education in New Jersey.
Permit the parent of a child to have a choice of the school the child will attend, and educationally the child will succeed.

LEAD: THE issue of recycling versus incineration, to manage New Jersey's solid-waste crisis, is the focus of great controversy.
To date, these solutions have been viewed as black or white - either we recycle or incinerate, and passionate arguments have been presented for each position.

Crime and Punishment
LEAD: In 1973, John P. Mack, then 19 years old, worked at a home furnishings store in a Virginia suburb of Washington.
As he later confessed, Mr.
Mack attacked a 20-year-old woman, Pamela Small, pounding her skull with a hammer and slashing her.
He served 27 months in jail before being released to a clerk's job in the office of Representative Jim Wright of Texas.

LEAD: WITH summer - and bathing suits - around the corner, it is time for sensible eating.
