It is simply a question of laying off the saturated fats.
The recipes below are substantial enough for company; they have little fat but get plenty of flavor from marinades and light sauces.

It's a Fan's Kind of Town
LEAD: In this city, sports fans do not do The Wave.
They do not wave hankies.
They do not paint themselves in team colors or wear goofy costumes.
They watch the game.
And they shake the rafters.
If it's mere entertainment you want, try City Hall.
Sports is too serious for such shenanigans.
As Shakespeare, had he grown up in Chicago, would surely have said:

Keeping Hotel Phones From Ringing Up Charges
LEAD: IF you are staying at a minimum-service economy motel, miserly phone service should not be a surprise.
At the Econo Lodge on International Drive in Orlando, Fla., for instance, guests cannot use the telephone in a room for any outside call, whether collect, credit-card or whatever, until a $10 deposit is received by the front desk.

Why give up on him?

Pitching is 90 percent of the game and, unfortunately for Yankee fans, George Steinbrenner has proven his inability to grasp this concept.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-19


Using Scaffolding Instead of Ladders
LEAD: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders.
Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand.
Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.


LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Cooking Enough For Later
LEAD: Many Italian dishes lose nothing by being frozen.
Here is a basic recipe for lasagna, with or without meat, that makes a Sunday meal and has enough left over for dinner days later.


Man or Beast, They Are Made For Music
LEAD: Musical sculpture - slit gongs, horns, harps and drums in the shape of oxen, buffalo, horses, long-beaked birds or armless men - are silhouetted against the walls of the great hall at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art.
These figural instruments include several that are monumental in scale and many more that convey movement or the music they were devised to bring alive.


Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
LEAD: Al Leiter has proven he talks a good game and nothing more.
The Yankees needed Jesse Barfield's run-producing bat to protect the franchise, Don Mattingly.
The gloom-and-doom prophets in the news media, who are openly rooting for Barfield to fail, can no more guarantee that Leiter is the next Sandy Koufax or guarantee that Barfield won't annually hit 30 plus homers and 100 plus r.b.i.


It's Autumn in Paraguay But Spring Is in the Air
LEAD: The damp gray skies of an approaching South American winter have settled over this riverside capital.
But on the chilly cobblestone streets below, young women have started wearing miniskirts.


Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
LEAD: No!
Al Leiter for Jesse Barfield will go down as a Nolan Ryan for Jim Fregosi trade.
George Steinbrenner and Syd Thrift should learn from the Mets that you build with young pitching.


Correction
LEAD: A listing of new members of the National Academy of Sciences on April 30 misidentified one and omitted another.
They are Ahmed H. Zewail, professor of chemical physics at the California Institute of Technology, and Donald B. Zilversmit, professor, section of biochemistry and molecular and cell biology, Cornell University, and career investigator for the American Heart Association.

STORMING MONTANA'S WILDERNESS
LEAD: If we don't produce the minerals and energy we require from domestic sources, our only alternative is to get them from abroad, primarily from underdeveloped countries where few safeguards are applied to resource development.
The wilderness advocate is having an ''esthetic experience'' in our forests, but he might ponder the morality of having this burden borne by people who live on a subsistence level.


China's Hero of Democracy: Gorbachev
LEAD: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives on Monday for four days of talks designed to restore normal relations between China and the Soviet Union, he will be cast in the unusual role of champion of democracy.


To the Airport
LEAD: To the Editor: The directory of ways to get to New York area airports (Travel Advisory, March 12) omitted two of the quickest and least expensive.
To La Guardia, several subway lines, including the E, F, R and 7, run to Roosevelt Avenue or 74th Street-Jackson Heights, an interconnected station, from which the Q-33 bus goes to all La Guardia terminals except the Marine Terminal (Pan Am shuttle).

LEAD: A starched white collar and cuffs were de rigeur back in great-grandfather's day, and he was no fashion slouch.
The proof is still with us, although today's women have taken it in a new direction.

LEAD: Tommy John walked quickly through the clubhouse and out the door that leads to the playing field.
He was wearing shorts, a T-shirt and running shoes, and there were beads of perspiration gathered across his forehead.
He still had work to do.
He did not stop, did not look up.

LEAD: William J. Ward, a teacher and book editor who was a historian at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Lutheran Medical Center.

PERU FIGHTS TO OVERCOME ITS PAST
LEAD: LONELY AND DEPRESSED, BROODING on the perfidy of a nation that once worshiped him, Peru's young President, Alan Garcia Perez, rarely emerges these days from his ornate, 19th-century palace in the heart of Lima.
Twice last year, he tried to resign.
Earlier this year, a military coup looked imminent.

LEAD: In the nearly five months since a terrorist bomb concealed in a cassette tape player tore apart a Pan American Airways 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland, security at Europe's airports and at Kennedy International Airport has grown steadily tighter.


POSTINGS: Newark Strip Shopping; Three Downtown Projects
LEAD: Ground will be broken May 23 for the third retail development in downtown Newark to be started this year, a 54,000-square-foot strip shopping center at West Market Street and 12th Avenue, adjacent to the University of Medicine and Dentistry's University Hospital.
The $5.5 million center, with 33 stores and restaurants, is to be Newark's largest minority-owned and -developed retail project.

IT GRIPES ME TO SAY THIS
LEAD: I'm with you, Roy (''It Gripes Me to Say This,'' by Roy Blount Jr., April 16).
I've been on a nonstop gripe-fest since your article appeared, and there's no telling when I'll stop.
My husband has turned a deaf ear, the cats have skittered away, all from my unstoppable grousing.
And it feels swell.

Brigham Young Selects Leader
LEAD: Rex E. Lee, who served as Solicitor General in the Reagan Administration, was named Friday as the 10th president of Brigham Young University, the nation's largest private university.
Mr.
Lee, 54 years old, is to assume the presidency July 1.
He succeeds Jeffrey R. Holland, who was appointed on April 1 to a leadership position in the Mormon Church, which owns the university.

Owen's Bat Helps Expos Top Giants
LEAD: Spike Owen tied the score with a two-run homer in the seventh inning and then singled home the winning run with two out in the ninth as the Montreal Expos beat San Francisco, 5-4, today, ending the Giants' five-game winning streak.


Zoeller Loses Lead, But Only Briefly
LEAD: Fuzzy Zoeller continued his amazing performance in the cold and rainy 14th annual Memorial Tournament today when he chipped over a bunker and into the 18th hole for a birdie 3 to maintain his lead by a stroke over Bob Tway going into Sunday's final round.


PASTIMES: Bridge
LEAD: Political leaders receive awards frequently, but a double ceremony tentatively scheduled to take place in New York City on May 30 will be distinctly different.
Two awards will be given to one of the leaders of the People's Republic of China for services to bridge.


Cautious Optimism in Shore Pollution Fight
LEAD: AS the days get warmer and schools of mackerel end their spring run up the New Jersey coast, state officials are hopeful that new laws and programs put in place since last year to reduce coastal pollution will make this summer a better one than the last three.
But researchers and environmentalists remain cautious about how to address the long-term underlying causes of coastal pollution.


When a Dancer Turns Choreographer
LEAD: ''A few months ago, i was rehearsing a new ballet in Studio 3 and Twyla Tharp was in Studio 4 and Misha was in Studio 5,'' Clark Tippet, the 34-year-old dancer-turned-choreographer with American Ballet Theater, said recently, ''and I suddenly began thinking, 'What am I doing with this group?' When I choreographed my first few pieces, I had nothing to lose, but I realized the company was counting on me this time, and it spooked me.


The Melody Is Sicilian for a Change
LEAD: NORTHERN Italian restaurants are in vogue on Long Island.
Most are sumptuously elegant with prices and food closer to Paris than Rome.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  A WOLVERINE IS EATING MY LEG.
By Tim Cahill. (Vintage, Paper, $8.95.) In this collection of adventure stories, Tim Cahill, a columnist for Outside magazine, says offhandedly that ''every once in a while, I like to flirt with some physical challenge in which the price of failure is death.'' He recounts, in much the same manner, such challenges as squeezing through barely passable openings a half-mile beneath the earth, diving off the Philippines for poisonous sea snakes and hiking Death Valley in the summer.


Magadan's Pinch-Hit Gives Mets Victory
LEAD: Dave Magadan, the denizen of the dugout, sat on the Mets' bench in Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon.
He heard the sellout crowd of 46,484 yelling.
He saw the San Diego Padres walk Darryl Strawberry on purpose to load the bases with two down in the 11th inning and the score tied at 3-3.
And he sensed that Davey Johnson was calling his name.

Reviews/Theater; Repertorio Espanol in 'La Casa de Bernarda Alba'
LEAD: Hatred, jealousy and despair come to life, almost as characters in their own right, in the Repertorio Espanol's Spanish-language production of ''La Casa de Bernarda Alba.'' But this new staging of the Federico Garcia Lorca play, under the direction of Rene Buch, moves so fast at times as to become a headlong rush to tragedy.


Correction
LEAD: An article on March 5 incorrectly described the founding of the National Plastics Center and Museum in Leominster, Mass.
The museum, which opens later this year, was founded by an unaffiliated group of individuals in the plastics industry.


Jay Doblin, Designer, Dies at 68; Clients Included Major Industries
LEAD: Jay Doblin, a leading industrial designer who also taught for three decades at the Illinois Institute of Technology and directed its Institute of Design for 14 years, died of cancer Thursday at Lutheran General Hospital in Chicago.
He was 68 years old.

LEAD: AS the nation's most populous state, and one of its more affluent, California is a market so large and lucrative that industries will suffer almost anything to succeed here.

FICTION
LEAD:  ECHO OF LIONS.
By Barbara Chase-Riboud. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this, her third novel, Barbara Chase-Riboud takes on one of the most fascinating episodes in the history of the slave trade, the successful rebellion of a group of Africans on board the Spanish slave ship Amistad.
Led by the man who would be known in America as Joseph Cinque, the intended slaves killed the captain and crew of the ship and, with no maritime knowledge, attempted to sail back to West Africa.


The Case of the Vanishing Art
LEAD: It has happened again.
Two months ago, several representatives from Christie's in New York appeared at the Frick Museum to remove from its walls a painting that had been on view there for nearly 20 years.
Jacopo Pontormo's extraordinary rendition of a young man is to be auctioned on May 31, and Christie's expects the bidding to surpass $20 million.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  THE CHIP WAR: The Battle for the World of Tomorrow.
By Fred Warshofsky. (Scribners, $22.50.) Fred Warshofsky has taken his tape recorder and toured the American semiconductor industry, recording the anguish of its leaders as they watch their markets relentlessly eroded by Japanese competition.
He has also traveled to Japan and visited factories, universities and Government officials to paint a picture of a near-invincible rival.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Pittsburgh
LEAD: Pittsburgh, long thought of as the smoky city of mills and factories on the banks of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, can no longer be regarded as ''hell with the lid off,'' as the journalist Lincoln Steffens once described it.


POSTINGS: Six Screens on Second; Films For Fillmore East
LEAD: The Beach Boys haven't played the house for a while, and neither have the Allman Brothers or Country Joe McDonald and the Fish.
But entertainment finally will be returning to Fillmore East, the East Village theater that was a mecca for jazz and rock fans in the 1960's.
The 2,600-seat theater has been closed for two years; indeed, for two decades it has been more dark than open.

IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Connecticut; For New Haven, a New $360 Million Neighborhood

Nepal
LEAD: To the Editor: Seeking advice from a specialist in tropical and travel medicine should be foremost when a family is planning to bring youth along on a trek to a developing country.
The incidence of typhoid, shigella, amebiasis, tuberculosis, diphtheria, meningococcal infections, dengue fever, hepatitis, rabies, hookworm and other intestinal parasites is high in Nepal and many other countries where trekking occurs.


Using Scaffolding Instead of Ladders
LEAD: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders.
Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand.
Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.

Program Examines Sand and Chopin
LEAD: In many ways, Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin was a precursor of today's supermom: she supported her two children by writing about 80 novels (under the pseudonym of George Sand) and she was a staunch advocate of freedom in living for women.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into.
I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long.
The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing.
This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.

At the Victoria and Albert, A Collection of Missteps
LEAD: Every so often, there surfaces in the international art world a truly terrible idea.
An idea of precisely that order was approved unanimously not long ago by the trustees of the Victoria &amp; Albert Museum in London.
The essence of it was that henceforth the curatorial staff of the museum were to concern themselves entirely with scholarly pursuits, leaving the day-to-day work of the museum - the ''housekeeping,'' as it is now called - to a chain of command newly set up for the purpose and attuned to modern managerial methods.

Correction
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on April 23 about a proposal to administer drugs to a criminal defendant misstated benefits of the drug Cogentin in countering possible side effects of anti-psychotic drugs.
Cogentin can alleviate drooling and involuntary muscle movements, but can cause mouth dryness and blurring of vision and can aggravate a condition called angle-closure glaucoma.

LEAD: Since he became commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association five months ago, Bill Blue has been working feverishly to upgrade the image and increase the exposure of women's golf.


NAVAJO COPS ON THE CASE
LEAD: ON A STARK, SNAKEWEED-IN-fested plain in northwestern New Mexico sits an enormous mound of hardened lava that was squeezed out of the earth in the Pleistocene Epoch.
It's called Mitten Rock, and some Navajo Indians believe it to be inhabited by witches.
Tony Hillerman steers his four-wheel Isuzu Trooper up for a close look at the monolith.

LEAD: Not since Mr.
Ed, the talking horse, wore hats - not all the time, but he wore them - has horse haberdashery had more of an audience.
Horse wear showed up in nearly a dozen fall collections, reflecting either fashion's collective unconscious or a sudden surge in the equestrian passion.

The Muddle in Eating 'Right'
LEAD: I REMEMBER how my happy baby used to conduct imaginary orchestras with asparagus spears as her batons, how she pruned tiny broccoli trees proudly with her two teeth, and how she gummed cold chunks of apples to ease the pain of teething.


Miss Kang to Marry
LEAD: Kim Chook-Saeng of Cheju Island and Seoul, Korea, has announced June wedding plans for her daughter, Sue Kang Kyung Sook, and Gregory W. Neumann, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Roy G. Neumann of Darien, Conn., and Naples, Fla.
Miss Kang, also the daughter of the late Kang Doo-Bong, is a chief purser for Cathay Pacific Airlines in Hong Hong.


Kremlin Offers to Destroy Disputed Siberian Radar
LEAD: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it is prepared to totally dismantle a long-disputed radar in Siberia if the United States agrees to a strict interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, according to Bush Administration officials.


Arab Oil-Exporting Group Readmits Egypt
LEAD: The Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to readmit Egypt, whose membership was suspended because of its peace with Israel a decade ago.
The move was a further step in Cairo's return to the Arab fold after 10 years of ostracism.

A Comeback in Hard Disks
LEAD: Manufacturers of hard-disk drives for personal computers have watched their stocks hit one new low after another, but now some are recovering.
Last fall, Seagate Technology, the largest independent hard-disk company, announced that it had a glut of inventory, cut prices and took a loss, setting off an industry-wide binge of price cutting, losses and layoffs.

Susan Kiley Wed To K. M. Osborn In New Canaan
LEAD: Susan Cordiner Kiley, a daughter of Patricia C. Kiley of Norwalk, Conn., and Timothy M. Kiley of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., to Kevin Michael Osborn, a son of Marjorie P. Osborn of Teaneck, N.J., and Norman V. Osborn of San Diego.
David Howland, a justice of the peace of New Canaan, officiated.


CAMPUS LIFE: Chicago; 700 at Camp-Out To Beat the Rush For Fall Classes
LEAD: By any standard, it was a huge camp-out: 700 undergraduates on the main quad at the University of Chicago last weekend braving 30-degree weather not to raise money for charity, buy concert tickets or demonstrate for or against some cause, but to enroll in next year's classes.


A Village Art Shop Owner Is Shot to Death
LEAD: The owner of three Manhattan art galleries was found shot to death in what the police believe was an attempted robbery near one of his galleries in Greenwich Village.

LEAD: To the Editor; Commenting on the dilemma of ''Tilted Arc,'' Jan R. Harrington suggested  [ Letters, April 16 ]  that ''any piece of purely decorative public art be rented for display for no longer than five years,'' after which the rental could be renewed for up to 20 more years before a decision to purchase.

Is It Time to Redevelop Park Avenue Again?
LEAD: MORE than any other thoroughfare in New York City, Park Avenue has been a street of surprising change.
From the first grade-level railroad in 1834, to the sinking of the tracks and construction of middle-class housing after 1875 to the electrification of the railroad and the building of luxurious mansions and then apartments after 1900, the broad boulevard has consistently provided fascinating real estate news for more than a century and a half.


New Pain on Top of Little Rock's Old Weariness
LEAD: Thirty-two years after Federal troops were summoned to integrate Central High School here, a demoralizing, seemingly endless battle is being fought with renewed intensity over the Little Rock schools.


A Spring of Drought Restrictions Shrivels Busines at Nurseries
LEAD: MAY is the equivalent of the Christmas buying season for those who sell ornamental plants, shrubs and trees.
But on a recent afternoon, thousands upon thousands of plants, trees and flats of seedlings covering six acres at Tony's Nurseries in Larchmont were still waiting for the hundreds of buyers who never came.

Beware the Winged Tyrant
LEAD: ANYONE who has ventured into the bosky back country in our part of the world - the Northeast - knows how easily the Garden of Eden can turn into Monster Island.
All it takes is bugs.
For instance, I recall 30 years ago as a child being jammed under a big old Army tent with 27 other campers on a witheringly hot and rainy night in the New Hampshire woods.

LEAD: Youssou N'Dour, the Senegalese singer who performed at the Ritz on Tuesday night and who is one of Africa's most famous international musicians, didn't start his show until halfway through his set.
Leading a band including three drummers, a guitarist, a bassist, a saxophonist and a keyboardist, he looked vaguely uncomfortable - as if the show were a minor irritant to his day.

Review/Music; When East and West Meet Without Mingling
LEAD: Trying to build a cultural bridge across the Pacific Ocean usually ends up marooning creative engineers somewhere west of Hawaii.
The expanse is great, and so distant are the two respective shores that messages from each are only dimly received.
What begins as a melding of two cultures, in other words, ends up having distressingly little to do with either.

Peter Scott, 50, Leader In Cause of Gay Rights
LEAD: Peter Scott, a champion of gay rights who canceled a campaign for the California Assembly after learning that he had AIDS, died of complications from the disease at his home Saturday.
He was 50 years old.
A lawyer who gave up his practice to advocate gay rights, Mr.
Scott worked to defeat measures requiring the dismissal of homosexual teachers and requiring that people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome be registered with the state.


Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is limited to today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills.
On Wednesday the Treasury is expected to announce the terms of its two-year and five-year note auctions scheduled for May 24 and May 25, respectively.

LEAD: The United States egg industry, already reeling from a five-year slide in sales, is in turmoil over government arguments that hens cannot lay low-cholesterol eggs.

Corrections
LEAD: An article and a headline on Thursday about the 1989 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music referred incorrectly to the festival's presentation of ''Laurie Anderson - Empty Places'' next October.

Should Uncle Sam Tilt to HDTV?; Yes: It's Pivotal to Industries of the Future
LEAD: Washington is riveted on high-definition television, a development that displays sharper pictures on wider screens.
The American electronics industry wants $1.35 billion of Government money to help it compete, belatedly, against Japanese and European companies.
Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher says the industry can't rely on ''Uncle Sugar,'' but he nonetheless offers a surprising sweetener: a proposal to relax the antitrust laws so as to allow co-production of equipment.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
The European Community is expected to pass laws this week requiring health warnings on all tobacco products, despite opposition from Britain and Greece.
The European Community Executive Commission wants all tobacco products sold in the 12-nation bloc after 1992 to carry two warnings: ''Smoking causes cancer'' and ''Smoking causes cardiovascular diseases.


Death Penalty in Heinous Cases Is Appropriate; Moral Standing
LEAD: To the Editor Of course, we must do all we can to avoid executing innocent people (''Why Execution Is Dead Wrong,'' editorial, April 29).
Therefore, at the least, no one should be sentenced to death unless it is absolutely certain (not merely proved beyond a reasonable doubt) that he or she committed a capital crime.

But Still No Kitchen Sink
LEAD: Mountainsmith, a company in Golden, Colo., has reinvented the tepee to accommodate a wood stove.
The tent, called the Mountainshelter, comes with a cone-shaped opening at the top for fitting a stovepipe.
The hole is lined with the same material that firefighters and race car drivers wear for protection against fire.

Question Box
LEAD:  Two-Homer Innings  Q. How many Yankee batters have hit two home runs in one inning and who was the last one to do it?
A.
Since 1900, the feat has been achieved 18 times in the major leagues, and of the eight American Leaguers to accomplish it, three were Yankees.
But no Yankee has managed to do it since 1977, when Cliff Johnson became the third one in the history of the franchise to trot round the bases twice in the same inning.


A Question Mark For Sunday Silence
LEAD: Sunday Silence, who won the Kentucky Derby nine days ago, is being treated for a bruised right front foot and could miss the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.


Joana M. Vicente Is Wed in Lisbon
LEAD: Joana Maria Vicente and Jason Robert Kliot were married yesterday at the Palace of the Count of Obidos in Lisbon.
Rabbi David B. Kudan of New York and the Rev.
Peter Stilwell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
The bride is the daughter of Manuel da Conceicao Machado Vicente and Maria Natalia Pereira Gomes, both of Lisbon.

LEAD: Orel Hershiser pitched a two-hitter and Eddie Murray hit two home runs to drive in five runs today as the Los Angeles Dodgers broke a 25-inning scoreless streak and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-0.

LEAD: A fire burned for nine hours in the engine room of a Liberian tanker carrying 450,000 barrels of crude oil from Galveston to Port Arthur today, but the Coast Guard said the cargo was not threatened.

Coelho was arranging the financing to purchase the bonds himself, Mr.
Coelho said today.


In Hungary, the Political Changes Are Tempered by Economic Fears
LEAD: In an atmosphere of increasing freedom of expression, Hungarians are looking forward to a possibility that after 44 years of Communist rule the party may permit free elections that could one day drive it from power.


New Savings Unit Rule
LEAD: Federal regulators plan to draft rules to protect savings institutions from hostile takeovers after they convert from the mutual form of ownership to stock ownership.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had directed its staff to rewrite the agency's rules so that the purchase of a savings institution's stock with hostile intent could be a ground for denial of a takeover application for three years after an institution converts to stock ownership.

United on Civil Rights, Divided on Enforcer
LEAD: Rare is the battle that would pit the Rev.
Jesse Jackson against the head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, that would make opponents out of Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of more than 180 civil rights organizations.


Scottish Plant Destroyed
LEAD: A stone-crushing plant in Scotland was destroyed in a fire Saturday night, and an anonymous caller said today that Scottish nationalists had blown it up because the quarry where it was situated was going to be used as a nuclear waste dump.
The police have not commented on the cause of the fire at the Glensanda granite quarry near the west coast resort of Oban.


Fed Held Unlikely to Ease Policy
LEAD: Despite widespread hopes that the Federal Reserve Board will soon move to ease monetary policy, a number of credit market analysts said that such a move is not only unlikely, but unwise.


Victorious Rarick Outpaces Lopez
LEAD: Nancy Lopez drew the largest galleries and was the sentimental favorite, but Cindy Rarick upstaged her with steady golf and captured the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic today by two strokes over Laura Davies of Britain.

Down Into White Water, Then Up, Up and Away
LEAD: SLOWLY and smoothly, the multicolored balloon floats over green rolling hills still wet with dew, over purple lupine and wild iris and daisies in a horizontal bouquet.
Then, in deliberate motions, the balloon descends toward the rushing river until gurgling white water swirls into the wicker basket as it skims the rapids and rises back into the air.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Sabatini Keeps Italian Open Title: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina overcame fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, yesterday to win her second consecutive Italian Open championship in Rome.
Sabatini earned $60,000 for the victory.(AP)  Agassi Tops Edberg: Second-seeded Andre Agassi won the $160,000 Aldi tournament in Ede, the Netherlands, defeating top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the final.


How to Fix School Decentralization
LEAD: How many corrupt board members were thrown out in New York City school board elections?
How many concerned parents were voted in?
The complete answers are days away.
But one dismal return is already known: Despite recent revelations of abuses on local boards and an aggressive get-out-the-vote effort, only about 6 percent of voters went to the polls.

Review/Dance; A New Cast for Ballet Theater's 'Sylphides'
LEAD: American Ballet Theater got off to a slow though lovely start with ''Les Sylphides'' on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, but from then on it was a triumphant evening.
The inner vitality of the ballet, choreographed by Michel Fokine and set to music by Chopin, seems to elude most American companies.


No Rabies in S.I. Wolf Attack
LEAD: The pet wolf that attacked a 3-year-old Staten Island boy did not carry rabies, the Health Department reported yesterday.
Following surgery Saturday night, the victim, Timothy Bajinski, was in critical but stable condition Sunday at Staten Island Hospital with head cuts, said a hospital spokesman, Arleen Ryback.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Employers are aggressively bargaining with doctors and hospitals on health-care costs, and steering workers to the ones with the best price.
Although the costs to these employers are lower, patients may lose some freedom of choice, and other companies and individuals may end up paying more.

Rabbi Bernard Berzon Dies at 76
LEAD: Rabbi Bernard L. Berzon, spiritual leader for 43 years of Congregation Ahavath Israel, now called Young Israel of Avenue K in the Flatbush-Midwood section of Brooklyn, died Thursday after heart surgery at New York Hospital.
He was 76 years old and had lived in Jerusalem since his retirement in 1982.

LEAD: Soviet-American trade prospects are brightening as the pace of the two countries' business contacts increases and as President Bush leans toward easing a 15-year-old law setting tariffs on Soviet imports up to 10 times higher than those from most other countries.

Boase Move By Omnicom
LEAD: The takeover battle for the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership grew more complicated on Friday, with the Omnicom Group apparently expressing its willingness to pay up to 360 pence a share, or about $5.99, for a substantial minority stake in the British agency, said advertising executives close to Omnicom's plans.


Editors' Note
LEAD: The Patterns column on the Fashion page last Tuesday reported that the Italian designer Gianfranco Ferre would take over the design responsibilities at Christian Dior, according to fashion executives in New York and Europe.
While the executives confirmed the report, the column should have credited Women's Wear Daily with the disclosure, a day earlier.

Parish Forced Out of Fragile Church
LEAD: For fear that the great plaster vaults might come crashing down with a single note of the organ, the congregation of the Church of the Holy Apostles in Manhattan has stopped worshiping in the sanctuary, severing a tradition that goes back to antebellum decades.

LEAD: An unusual Government-industry coalition is expanding its efforts to promote civilian uses for a new kind of aircraft even as the Pentagon is halting development of a military version of the aircraft.


East Germany Losing Its Edge
LEAD: East Germany is the Communist world's vaunted economic success story, hailed as proof that traditional German values of hard work, discipline and thrift can translate Karl Marx's theories into reality.


Alice-Leone Moats, 81, Journalist, Is Dead
LEAD: Alice-Leone Moats, a journalist who was the author of nine books, died Sunday at Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, after a long illness.
She was 81 years old and lived in Philadelphia.


Scientists Find Clues to Cholesterol Absorption
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have found clues to the way cholesterol is absorbed in the intestine, and the discovery may eventually lead to new drugs to prevent it from entering the bloodstream.

LEAD: The woman accused of being a leader of a sacrificial cult and four men were indicted today in drug-related slayings, including the deaths of 15 people at a ranch outside Matamoros, near the United States border.

Stewart Perowne, 87, Diplomat and Author
LEAD: Stewart Perowne, a diplomat, archeologist and historian who wrote books on the history and antiquities of the Mediterranean, died Wednesday at Charing Cross Hospital here.
He was 87 years old.


Iran Economic Plans
LEAD: Iran's Planning and Budget Minister has predicted annual economic growth of 5 percent for the next five years, creating two million new jobs.
The minister, Masud Roqani-Zanjani, said at a news conference in Teheran that the Government planned to sell some nonstrategic industries to the private sector and use the proceeds to develop strategic units.


Doctors Concerned About Unpublished Results
LEAD: Doctors and medical researchers are expressing concern that many clinical studies have never been published because they produced negative results.
They warned that this practice has deprived physicians of information crucial to proper treatment of patients.

Chess
LEAD: Is chess becoming too elitist at the international level?
That is the direction the game is taking when sponsors arrange tournaments in which a small number of the highest ranking grandmasters on the International Chess Federation's computer list play a double-round event.

Rig Count Climbs a Bit
LEAD: The count of oil and gas rigs climbed by 7 last week, to 771, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago, the count totaled 883.
The count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

LEAD: Macmillan Inc. will sell its Katharine Gibbs secretarial schools and its Technical Schools division to Phillips Colleges for $31.5 million, the two parties announced yesterday.

It said the acquisitions from Macmillan would give Phillips 85 colleges in 24 states.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline on Saturday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll that examined American attitudes toward Panama misstated a finding in some copies.
In answer to one question, a majority of those polled said the United States should adhere to the Panama Canal treaties; on another question, 50 percent said they disapproved of the treaties themselves, while 35 percent approved.

The Passing of the Gray Fedora
LEAD: In a gallery of the Museum of Modern Art there used to hang a Richard Oelze painting, titled ''Expectation,'' of a group of men and women gazing at a lowering sky.
The men for the most part wore gray fedoras.
The effect of the crowd of soft gray crowns, punctuated by the center creases by which fedoras are styled, was one of foreboding, foreshadowing the end of something.

Every Year, 70,000 Dead Elephants
LEAD: There's a saying among conservationists that a live elephant is worth more than a dead one.

Their proposal deserves strong support from all civilized nations.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about New York's commodity exchanges described the relative trading volume of three stock index futures contracts incorrectly.
The most active of the three is the Standard &amp; Poor's 500 stock index futures contract traded at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index future contract, traded at the New York Futures Exchange, is next.

Ivory Coast Cocoa Shift
LEAD: Ivory Coast, the world's biggest cocoa producer, said today that it would sell its next crop through London in hopes of raising prices from their present 13-month lows.

The French trade house Sucres et Denrees played a key role in managing Ivoirian cocoa exports in 1988-89.

Rothschild in Frankfurt
LEAD: The Rothschild banking dynasty, which has its start here in the 18th century, plans to reopen an office in this city after an 88-year absence, the city treasurer said today.
The Frankfurt office was closed in 1901 as the city's role as a financial center temporarily waned.
The city treasurer, Ernst Gerhardt, said Rothschild planned to open an office with about 20 people this summer.


Scientists Pinpoint Genetic Changes That Predict Cancer
LEAD: RESEARCHERS are well on their way to determining the precise genetic changes that must occur to make a normal cell cancerous, an achievement that could make it possible to identify people susceptible to particular kinds of tumors.

Rate Rise Seen in Egypt
LEAD: Under pressure from Western creditors, Egypt will increase its domestic interest rates, Egyptian newspapers said today.
They did not say how much the increase would be, but central bank officials have recommended an increase of two to four percentage points on deposit rates and of one to two points on loans.

New Polish Devaluation
LEAD: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, today for the sixth time this year, reducing it by 5.3 percent, according to rates published by the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita.
The zloty has now been devalued by the national bank by almost a third since Jan. 1, when the rate was 503 to the dollar.

Menem, Peronist. What's a Peronist?
LEAD: In despair over a crumbling economy, Argentine voters let hope prevail over caution in Sunday's presidential election.
The victor by a solid electoral majority is the Peronist, Carlos Saul Menem.
The U.S. can share the hope, acclaim a democratic election and yet keep in mind Peronist disasters past.

MEXICO LOOSENING INVESTMENT RULES
LEAD: Continuing its efforts to make the country's economy more competitive worldwide, the Mexican Government today announced a sweeping liberalization of its foreign investment regulations.
It revoked measures that have prevented majority foreign ownership of businesses and opened to foreign investment some areas that have previously been off limits altogether.

Trade Board in Ruling
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that for the first time it would require broker associations - groups of brokers who pool income - to register with the exchange.
The measure was approved by the board's directors, presumably to stiffen enforcement in the wake of an undercover operation at the exchange by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Drought Beyond the Drought
LEAD: In the wake of yesterday's downpour, the very word ''drought'' sounds almost silly.
May showers have raised the reservoirs to more than 90 percent of capacity and washed away New York's fears of another drought, the third in the last decade to require emergency water conservation rules.
The state drought management task force now recommends lifting the emergency.

Wine Talk
LEAD: NEW ZEALAND has 3.2 million people and 120 wineries.
That's quite a few wineries for approximately the same number of people I meet every morning squeezing into the Lincoln Tunnel.
In fact, the New Zealanders each year drink about 14 liters of wine per person, three times what Americans down, but nothing special when compared with French and Italian consumption.

Review/Recital; Soprano's Mozart and Ravel
LEAD: Berenice Bramson is an experienced soprano who now spends much of her time teaching.
Judging from Sunday afternoon's program at Weill Recital Hall, one assumes her pupils are fortunate.
Miss Bramson retains a firm technique (though it is a little frail at the top of her voice), she has an excellent sense of how a melodic line should be sung and her taste in material is first rate.

Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, on Sunday at 7 P.M.
Mr.
Gordon died Thursday at the age of 86.
The Mel Lewis Orchestra and guest soloists are scheduled to perform.

Why Discourage Democracy?; Four Good Ideas for Getting More People to Vote
LEAD: When the country held the Presidential election last November, Americans yawned.
Barely half the voting age population voted - the lowest turnout since 1924.
Why?
The arid campaign didn't help.
But neither did America's system of registering voters - a 50-state hodgepodge so daunting that only two-thirds of the voting age population is registered.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: BOUILLABAISSE, the Provencal fish stew, has countless variations in this country.
While some of the Mediterranean fish that go into the classic version are unavailable in the United States, a perfectly good rendition can be made with native species from Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf waters.
I have come up with a bouillabaisse-type fish stew that calls for monkfish, tilefish or blackfish, in any combination you like.

Why Voters Wink at Scandal
LEAD: If Jim Wright's constituents remain more loyal than distressed that their man has been accused of serious ethical wrongdoing, they will be following in a well-established tradition in American politics.
Voters know - and appreciate - a politician who has the power to deliver jobs.
And politicians know that taking care of constituents is a far more effective route to political power than satisfying platitudes about morality.

LEAD: At its annual meeting yesterday in Manhattan, the Interpublic Group of Companies announced that its board had approved a 3-for-2 split in its common stock and a 50 percent special dividend to shareholders at the end of this month.

LEAD: Amway, the privately held direct-selling company based in Ada, Mich,, said in a letter to the board of Avon Products Inc., that it would negotiate an increase in its offer of $39 a share for Avon if the cosmetics company furnishes it with non-public information.

LEAD: The board of directors of Prime Computer Inc. amended the severance agreements, known as ''golden parachutes,'' with top executives in a way that actually lowers the amount of cash the employees would receive if they leave the company after a change in control.

LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is offering $200 million in senior subordinated notes due in 1999.

Shearson said the issue was rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

Uncertain Times At the Royal Ballet
LEAD: Anthony Dowell, the longtime premier danseur of Britain's Royal Ballet, sat in his modest office at the Royal Opera House, a leg gracefully stretched across a chair, and summed up how his life has changed since he became artistic director of the company nearly three years ago.


Blue Jays Eyeing Piniella
LEAD: Lou Piniella, the Yankees' highly paid former manager, and Bud Harrelson, the Mets' dugout coach, are on the Toronto Blue Jays' short list of managerial candidates, a source close to the club said yesterday.

At the Nation's Table
LEAD: REGULAR visitors to Hickin's Mountain Mowings Farm, atop Black Mountain in this southern Vermont town just north of Brattleboro, are not surprised to find a bird of paradise plant growing near the maple sugar house.
The farm, owned for the last 41 years by Frank and Mary Hickin, is known for its unusual plants, produce and foods.

LEAD: Dan Majerle scored 9 of his 24 points in a pivotal third period and Tom Chambers had 13 of his 24 in the final 10 minutes as the Phoenix Suns beat the Golden State Warriors, 116-104, tonight to win their Western Conference semifinal playoff series in five games.


Los Angeles Library Reopens After 2 Fires
LEAD: The Los Angeles Central Library has reopened for business, nearly three years after two arson fires destroyed or damaged more than a million books.


Pay and Power at Issue in Los Angeles Walkout
LEAD: More pay seemed to be the sticking point as Los Angeles teachers stayed out of school for a second day today, but emotions were also high on the issue of how much teachers themselves should be allowed to determine conditions at their schools.

LEAD: Midway in the second quarter, with the Knicks having burst into a 56-47 lead, Patrick Ewing raised a clenched fist and Mark Jackson was whirling his right index finger.

Court to Say Who Owns 6th-Century Church Art
LEAD: Four rare Byzantine mosaic fragments from the sixth century have been placed in an Indianapolis vault awaiting the outcome of a Federal court trial this month that may determine their ownership.
This unlikely setting is the latest stop on a bizarre journey that began in Cyprus with the Turkish invasion in 1974 and that wound its way through Munich, Geneva and New York with a cast of characters that would be at home in an Indiana

Bruins Choose Milbury
LEAD: The Boston Bruins yesterday named Mike Milbury, a combative Bruins defenseman from the mid-1970's to the mid-1980's, as the 18th coach in their 65-year-history.
Milbury, a native Bostonian who was also named assistant general manager, succeeds Terry O'Reilly, who resigned to devote more time to his family.


Antonia Fraser's Book of Warriors
LEAD: Antonia Fraser's new nonfiction book, ''The Warrior Queens,'' celebrates commanding women.
Lady Antonia's last historical panoply, ''The Weaker Vessel,'' chronicled the secret lives of women suppressed in 17th-century England.
In contrast, her new book deals with women who conquered kingdoms, massacred their rivals and ruled with an iron lance.

4 Nations Weigh Ban on 747-400's
LEAD: Four European nations will ban commercial flights by the Boeing Company's new 747-400 series unless the United States company makes design changes for greater safety, a Dutch spokesman said.
A Transport Ministry spokesman, Harald Hameleers, said the Dutch demanded modifications months ago in concert with civil aviation agencies in Britain, West Germany and France, which together form the Joint Airworthiness

Grain and Soybeans Plunge; Copper Continues Its Slide
LEAD: Grain and soybean futures prices plunged today on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to forecasts of increased rain.


Gaza Workers Expelled From Israel
LEAD: The army and the police began rounding up thousands of Arab workers from the Gaza Strip today to enforce an order that they leave Israel and return home immediately or face arrest.


Ohio Official Ousted After South Africa Trip
LEAD: The superintendent of the Ohio Highway Patrol has been dismissed because he accepted two free trips to racially segregated South Africa as the guest of two municipal agencies in Johannesburg.

Massachusetts to Use Team In Drive Against Polluters
LEAD: Massachusetts plans to use undercover agents, aerial surveillance and search warrants to bring criminal charges against polluters.
But the plan, announced today by Gov.

600-Volt Arc From Rail Burns 3 Track Workers
LEAD: Three subway track workers were badly burned yesterday in Brooklyn when a section of track they were removing for repair hit the third rail, shooting a 600-volt arc around them and setting their clothes on fire.

LEAD: Gen.

A California Museum Sues Over Hal Wallis Collection
LEAD: Seven days after the auction at Christie's of eight pictures from the collection of Hal B. Wallis, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art filed suit yesterday in New York State Supreme Court against the Hal B. Wallis Foundation; its president, Brent Wallis, who is the son of the late motion picture producer, and Christie's, the auction house.


See Florence and Swoon
LEAD: For years, travelers to Florence have believed it was the Italian water that made them go funny all over -faint, hallucinate, perspire heavily, suffer palpitations and stomach cramps.
Today, because of the researches of a psychiatrist named Graziella Magherini, the world knows better.
It wasn't the acqua; it was the art.

Reviews/Theater; 40 Years of Hummable Memories From the Movies
LEAD: ''Blame It on the Movies'' the perky new revue of movie songs at the Criterion Center, springs from a nearly sure-fire theatrical premise.
Put eight singers and dancers on a set that evokes the velvet twilight of an old-time movie palace, hand them 40 years of mostly familiar film songs to perform, and somewhere along the way everyone will have at least one nostalgic button pushed.


Anne Murphy, 62, Fordham Libraries Head
LEAD: Anne M. Murphy, director of libraries at Fordham University, died of cancer yesterday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y.
She was 62 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

Levi Strauss to Sell Shares In Japan Unit to the Japanese
LEAD: Levi Strauss &amp; Company, the giant jeans manufacturer, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1985, said today that it would sell stock in its Japanese subsidiary to the Japanese public.


19 Injured in Brooklyn As Car and Bus Collide
LEAD: At least 19 people were injured when an automobile and a bus collided in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, a transit official said.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article yesterday about a lawsuit arising from the Attica prison uprising of 1971 gave an incorrect account of how guards and inmates died when the prison was stormed by the police.
Investigations showed that police gunfire killed all 10 hostages and 29 inmates who died when the prison was retaken.

French Supermarkets Sold by TLC Group
LEAD: TLC Group Inc., the New York investment company headed by Reginald F. Lewis, said yesterday that it had sold Societe Eurpoeene de Supermarches, a leading supermarket chain in France, to the Bouriez Group for a price in excess of $260 million in cash and assumed debt.


San Juan Airlines
LEAD: San Juan Airlines will stop flying and close its headquarters here if the Canadian Government approves the sale of its four Canadian routes to Horizon Air Industries, San Juan's president, Jim Sherrell, said.
San Juan will continue to operate its Shuttle Express ground transportation service at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport.

LEAD: Though S. J. Perelman was pigeonholed as a humorist, he was, first of all, a literary artist - an acrobat with language - and his wit and erudition are imperishable.
Feeling low?
Enervated by ennui?
Read Perelman and rejoice.


NWA Expands Severance Awards
LEAD: The board of NWA Inc. has expanded the company's ''golden parachute'' severance agreements to include 200 more members of the management of Northwest Airlines Inc. and the Northwest Aerospace Training Corporation.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, NWA did not disclose how much the plan would cost a company that took over the airline holding company.

In Praise Of Fragant Paulownia
LEAD: FOUR years ago, in the gift shop at Winterthur in Delaware, I bought a small potted seedling of Paulownia tomentosa, a tree native to China and named in honor of Anna Paulowna (1795-1865), a Dutch princess noted for her passion for botany.
The tree was only one year old, and it had been pruned back to the ground to give it a root system capable of supporting the rapid growth that was sure to follow that summer.

LEAD: The Upjohn Company, one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies, said it expects a speedy review by the Food and Drug Administration for a drug it is developing to treat head injuries.

Talking Deals; RJR 'Junk' Test Passed by Drexel
LEAD: DREXEL BURNHAM LAMBERT INC. got a much-needed shot in the arm last week.
In what is being called a watershed for the $200 billion ''junk bond'' market, the embattled firm was the principal underwriter of a sale of $4 billion of securities of the RJR Holdings Capital Corporation.
The offering, which set several records, has received rave reviews from portfolio managers and bond traders.

Law'' (shown at 10 P.M. Thursdays on NBC) became evident.
Not only are the committee-written scripts more disjointed than ever, not only are some scenes sloppily edited to disguise the absence during shooting of main characters who were supposedly present, but now the series is also falling back on old gimmicks.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation has decided to stop making copiers for the A. B. Dick Company because the Chicago-based company's sales were cutting into Xerox's markets, a Xerox spokesman said today.

LEAD: National Secretaries' Week came and went last month without much notice in the Big Apple.
But up in Maine, where there are fewer distractions, radio station WMGX staged an ''Office Olympics'' in downtown Portland.


On the Other Hand
LEAD: The weather has certainly mixed its blessings so far this year.
The balmy winter was a pleasure and kept heating bills down.
But on the other hand, as everybody kept saying, it may have been the ominous greenhouse effect.
The endless spring rains have flooded cellars and made a mess of outdoor life.

LEAD: Scotland has its own currency, its own educational and legal system and its own state church.

Review/Music; Flutist From Iceland Plays New Works in Her Debut
LEAD: Ashildur Haraldsdottir is an Icelandic flutist with considerable musical gifts, onstage charm and - from an American viewpoint - a wonderfully euphonious name.
Miss Haraldsdottir, who was born in 1965 and who has studied in Boston and New York since 1983, gave a debut recital Monday night at CAMI Hall devoted entirely to contemporary music for her instrument.


Reviews/Music; Opera Ebony Sings Verdi
LEAD: Opera Ebony, now 16 years old, has been branching out in ambitious directions.
Last year, the company undertook a co-production of ''Porgy and Bess'' with the Finnish National Opera, taking it on tour in Finland and the Soviet Union.
On Saturday night, in an unofficial cultural exchange, the company brought Eri Klas, the Estonian conductor who led ''Porgy,'' to make his American debut with the Verdi Requiem in Aaron Davis Hall at City College.

Review/Music; A Festival Where Art and Rock Collide
LEAD: The Bang on a Can Festival, which began as a single marathon concert in 1987, has quickly established itself as both a showcase for an array of avant-garde styles and a lively burst of contemporary fireworks to brighten the end of the formal concert season.
This year the festival has evolved into a series at the RAPP Arts Center, and in the final program, heard Saturday night (it was repeated on Sunday), three composers explored the intersection of art music and rock.

LEAD: An investment group led by Thomas E. Feil, the chairman of the V Band Corporation, has dropped its proposal to acquire the telephone equipment concern, based in Yonkers.
Mr.
Feil and KBA Partners L.P., a venture capital concern, had made a proposal to acquire V Band for a price in the range of $9 to $11 a share, for a maximum total purchase price of $57 million.

Spinoff Plan Gains At Morton Thiokol
LEAD: Morton Thiokol Inc. received permission from the Internal Revenue Service for a tax-free spinoff of its commercial businesses.
The businesses, which produce specialty chemicals, salt and inflatable restraint systems, will operate under the name Morton International Inc.
The company still awaits stockholders' approval of the move.

Montana Recovering
LEAD: Joe Montana, the quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, underwent surgery on his left knee last Thursday at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif.
It was the quarterback's fifth operation since 1983 and the second on the same knee.
He is expected to recover before preseason training camp begins in mid-July.

British Airways Positive on Boeing
LEAD: British Airways said it was confident that the latest version of Boeing's jumbo jet would come into service despite calls by four European nations for extra safety measures.
The airline has ordered 19 of the new 747-400's, at a cost of more than $2 billion.
The first is due to arrive next month.
Although the 400-seat jet has been cleared by United States authorities, Britain, West Germany, France and the Netherlands have said they would not allow the aircraft to fly unless Boeing made changes in the wiring and in the upper-deck floor to strengthen it against explosions.

This approach can work with splendid comic precision, as it did last year in Mr.

LEAD: Is it swimming?
Is it dance?
Waterworks, which performed on Saturday night at the handsome Manhattan Plaza Health Club pool, falls somewhere between.
The performers are billed as swimmer-dancers.
Choreographers were listed for each of the 10 pieces on the program, but they included competitive swimmers and a swimming coach.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Floor Paints and Caulks  Q. The pine floor in our house has several coats of paint on it that are wearing off.
The caulking between the widely spaced boards is firm, but cracked open.
I plan to sand the paint without removing all of it, then apply fresh paint.
Can I use some type of water base paint (low gloss preferred), and is there a paintable caulk that expands and contracts as the boards expand with humidity?


Hispanic Art Exhibition
LEAD: ''Hispanic Art in the United States: 30 Contemporary Painters and Sculptors,'' an exhibition that includes painting, sculpture, works on paper and mixed-media objects, will run through Sept. 4 at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section.
Luis Cruz Azaceta, Robert Graham and Manuel Neri are among the artists whose work is on display.

Up to a point the play is about the surrender of the city of Verdun to Prussian forces in September 1792, when a number of European monarchs tried to stop the revolution and restore Louis XVI to the throne.

LEAD: Two promoters of baseball card shows, Jim Kelly and Kevin Boden of Rochester, N.Y., have filed a lawsuit against Jose Canseco, the star outfielder for the Oakland Athletics, for skipping an autograph session in February.
The lawsuit claims Canseco breached a contract when he failed to show up in Rochester, where several hundred people paid to see him.


Repairing Beloved Old Typewriters
LEAD: IN less than a decade, the peck of typewriter keys and the ring of the carriage have been replaced by the glow of the computer terminal and the buzz of the printer.
Today the manual typewriter, with its steel body and sensual, rounded keys, is a relic of another era.
Indeed, even the electric typewriter seems an anachronism.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on May 10 about former New York City police officers who are now police administrators elsewhere misstated the position once held by Eugene (Bull) Connor in Birmingham, Ala.
He served as Commissioner of Public Safety, or police commissioner, an elected official, and not as chief of police.

New Chief for Space Station
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a former astronaut, Dr.
William B. Lenoir, to head the space station program.
Dr.
Lenoir, who flew a shuttle mission in 1982, is now a vice president of Booz-Allen &amp; Hamilton, a consulting company.
The space agency also announced that Richard Kohrs, the deputy manager of the space shuttle program at Johnson Space Center in Houston, will move to NASA's headquarters in Washington to be operational director for the space station, which is to be called Freedom.


Moving for a Cause or Just Because
LEAD: New York-as-melting pot is to be celebrated in two large ethnic-heritage parades this weekend -one in Manhattan and the other in Brooklyn.
Marchers will begin assembling for the seventh Turkish-American Parade at 1 P.M. tomorrow on the Avenue of the Americas at West 56th Street; at 2:30 P.M. 15,000 people are expected to begin following the parade route, which will go south on the Avenue of the Americas to 47th Street and east to the United Nations.


Money Fund Assets Soar
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 468 money-market mutual funds rose by $4.9 billion, to $311.95 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The 142 institutional funds jumped by $2.35 billion, to $79.14 billion.
The 231 general-purpose funds were up by $644 million, to $101.42 billion.

British Joblessness Falls
LEAD: The Government said today that unemployment had fallen sharply in March, by 60,200 workers, to 1,856,000.
That is the lowest level since 1980 and the 33d consecutive monthly decrease.
Average earnings increased at an annual rate of 9.25 percent in March for the second straight month, indicating a leveling off after a recent upward trend.


It's Rollins Vs. Marsalis In a Duel At Carnegie
LEAD: When Sonny Rollins, 59 years old, and Branford Marsalis, 28, two tenor saxophonists, step onstage tonight at Carnegie Hall, listeners might well sense a challenge.
Jazz history is full of tales, authenticated and apocryphal, about the nights in which reputations were made, new styles were forged and pretenders were deflated in the jazz equivalent of one-on-one basketball or a duel of honor - the jam session or ''cutting contest.

Toni Matt Dies at 69; Former Ski Champion
LEAD: Toni Matt, a pioneer in competitive and recreational skiing in the United States, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday in Pawling, N.Y.
He was 69 years old.
Mr.
Matt, who was born in St.
Anton, Austria, came to the United States in 1938 with a group of Austrian skiers.
On April 16, 1939, he skied down Tuckerman's Ravine on Mount Washington in New Hampshire in 6 minutes 29.4 seconds, reaching a speed of 85 miles an hour.

LEAD: The former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, is in very critical condition after undergoing an operation for kidney failure and may die at any time, a hospital spokesman said today.


Sullivan Rejoins Cast
LEAD: Danny Sullivan, the winner of the 1985 Indianapolis 500 who crashed in a practice run for this year's race last Thursday, returned to a race car yesterday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
Wearing a special protective brace for the right forearm he broke when his Penske PC18-Chevrolet crashed into the wall on the third turn, Sullivan hopped into a similar race car a few minutes after the beginning of a practice session at the Speedway.


Macy's Denies Sale Rumors
LEAD: Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy &amp; Company, denied yesterday that the retailer had arranged to sell an interest to another concern or that any of Macy's store divisions were for sale.


Hunger Strikers, Heart of China Protest
LEAD: Xie Wanjun is a gawky, 21-year-old agriculture student who is so disarmingly meek and boyish that it is not easy to imagine him as part of the brigade of young people who in the last few days have handed the Government a crushing humiliation.


Chrysler to Buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car
LEAD: In a move to cement a relationship with an important customer in the booming automobile rental market, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc., the nation's fifth-largest rental company, for $263 million.


House Ends Deadlock On Veteran Spending
LEAD: The House ended weeks of partisan stalemate today and approved $1.2 billion for this year's veterans' programs, and the Senate finished unusually early Congressional action on the $1.17 trillion Federal budget for 1990.


Students Told to Provide Free Service
LEAD: The University of Pennsylvania Law School yesterday became the first major law school in the United States to require its students to provide voluntary legal services.


Repairs to Older Planes Ordered; Move Will Affect 2,200 Airliners
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the first of a series of repairs to the nation's aging airliners that will eventually involve 2,200 airplanes and cost the airline industry hundreds of millions of dollars.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Renaissance Music
LEAD: Bart Folse will conduct I Cantori New York in a concert of Renaissance music at St.
Peter's Church, in the Citicorp Center, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8.
The program includes works by Andrea and Giovanni Gabrielli, Claudio Monteverdi, Don Carlo Gesualdo, Orlando di Lasso and Giovanni Palestrina.


Exxon Monitored Drinking by Captain
LEAD: The Exxon Shipping Company monitored the alcohol habit of Capt.
Joseph J. Hazelwood for four years before his tanker went aground in Prince William Sound on March 24, the company president testified today, but it found no evidence of a continuing drinking problem.


No More Ifs for Butz
LEAD: Dave Butz of the Redskins, who had been the oldest starting player in the National Football League, yesterday announced his retirement in Washington.
The decision of the 38-year-old defensive tackle to retire had been rumored for several months even though he had another year remaining on his two-year contract that would bring him $550,000 next season.


President's Job Is Filled At Figgie International
LEAD: Figgie International Inc., a com-pany led by its strong founder, Harry E. Figgie Jr., said yesterday that it had named Vincent A. Chiarucci president.
The post has been vacant since 1982.


Senate Panel Hears Manley Tell of Learning Disability
LEAD: Dexter Manley told a Senate panel today that he has finally overcome childhood rejection and has gained self-respect since seeking help three years ago to learn to read and write.

Prices in the New York Region Were Up 0.5% Last Month
LEAD: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area continued their rise, climbing one-half of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department's regional bureau reported yesterday.


Review/Film; One Against the Villains, in 'Road House'
LEAD: In ''Road House,'' Patrick Swayze has the most laughable role since Tom Cruise juggled a few liquor bottles and danced to ''The Hippy Hippy Shakes'' in ''Cocktail.'' ''Road House'' is also set in a bar, where Mr.
Swayze is a bouncer named Dalton.
He's so famous he needs only one name like Cher or Sting, so tough that when knifed he calmly stitches his own arm, so cool that he stays perfectly serene while knives, fists, feet and chairs come flying toward his face.


9 Enter Preakness; 8 Go, Rain or Shine
LEAD: A field of nine, including the first six finishers from the Kentucky Derby, was entered today for the 114th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.
Only eight horses, however, are likely to start.


Review/Film; English Despair, Betrayals and Violence
LEAD: From the British wave of angry new film makers, we have seen the bitterness of ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid'' and the sardonic comedy of ''High Hopes.'' But none of the recent anti-Thatcherite works is as bleak, intense or tough-minded as ''For Queen and Country.'' The story of a working-class black man who returns to his old neighborhood after eight years in the army is the flip side of ''High Hopes,'' for the England of this film is a dim, claustrophobic, utterly hopeless place.


Corrections
LEAD: The TV Notes column yesterday understated the size of the audience for the ABC mini-series ''The Winds of War'' in February 1983.
The program was watched by 53 percent of the viewing audience, not 43 percent.


Tokyo Gives Hints That Rate Rise Is Near
LEAD: Japanese officials today appeared to be inching toward an increase in the country's record-low discount rate, amid growing nervousness about the rise of the dollar and signs that inflation could be returning after an absence of many years.


Australia Raises Rates
LEAD: Australia's central bank raised interest rates today for the fourth straight week as its dollar fell below 76 cents in United States currency, its lowest level in more than a year.
The Reserve Bank raised its rediscount rate to 17.3 percent, from 17 percent - the highest in two years - the day after the bank's governor, Bob Johnston, called for restraint to cure Australia's ''state of self-indulgence.


Contract for Acting Chancellor Divides Board
LEAD: The Board of Education's deliberations on who should lead the New York City school system are focused on reservations voiced by the board's two minority-group members about a plan to offer an interim contract as schools chancellor to the acting chancellor.


Cornelia Marsh Templeton
LEAD: Cornelia Van Rensselaer King Marsh Templeton, a member of an old New York family, died of liver cancer Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
She was 78 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.


An MTV Comedy Channel Will Compete With HBO's
LEAD: MTV Networks announced plans yesterday to form a cable television comedy channel, the second all-comedy channel announced this week.

LEAD: Five months after fleeing the New York City area to avoid a prison sentence for the largest Medicaid fraud to date, Sheldon Weinberg was arrested yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz.

LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested Wednesday night and charged with second-degree murder after she stabbed another teen-age girl to death during a fight over a dog, the police said yesterday.
The victim, Pacquita Braswell, 18, of 375 Blake Avenue in the Brownsville section, was stabbed once in the chest outside her apartment building about 11 P.M.

LEAD: In hockey's playoffs, when goaltending is either a team's trump card or its Achilles heel, the two goaltenders who have survived to duel in the Stanley Cup championship are engaged in a self-deprecating cold war.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Gasoline prices posted their largest one-month increase on record in April, pushing the consumer inflation index up 0.7 percent.
Without the volatile energy component, the April increase was 0.2 percent, leaving the financial markets cheering.  [ Page A1. ]  Prices in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.5 percent.

LEAD: Despite a large effort to elect new members to New York City's local school boards, the great majority of incumbents who ran were re-elected.

Program-Trade Dip in April
LEAD: Program trading fell in April, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday.
It said program trading accounted for only 7.6 percent of the volume on the Big Board, the lowest level since the exchange began releasing figures last July.


Nominee's Role as Consultant Is Examined by Senate Panel
LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that it had opened an investigation of ties between President Bush's nominee as Ambassador to Luxembourg and a Federal housing program that Democratic lawmakers say was used by the Reagan Administration to benefit some prominent Republicans.


Low-Power Permit Given To Seabrook
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a license for low-power testing at the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire.


Bridge
LEAD: A New Jersey-Chicago squad was fast out of the blocks when the United States Bridge Championships began here Wednesday night.
The tournament will determine the national team that will go to the World Championships in Perth, Australia, in September.


Court Blocks Bid
LEAD: The Income Opportunity Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Emeryville, Calif., said a Federal court in California had issued a preliminary injunction against an offer from the DRF Acquisition Corporation and the Policemen and Firemen Retirement System and the General Retirement System, both of Detroit.


No Action on Taylor
LEAD: The N.F.L. said yesterday that it would take no action against Lawrence Taylor in the wake of his acquittal on drunken-driving charges.
Taylor, the Giants' celebrated outside linebacker, was found not guilty May 10 in Saddle Brook (N.J.) Municipal Court.
Taylor has been cited twice by the league for violating its substance-abuse policies.


Sunday New York Post To Be a Smaller Paper
LEAD: In an effort to stem losses of more than $300,000 a week on its Sunday issue, The New York Post will replace its multi-section Sunday newspaper with a version of its daily paper beginning next month, Valerie B. Salembier, the president of the New York Post Company, announced yesterday.

Tower noted with a smile this morning as he played host at what was billed as a ''power breakfast'' at Joe &amp; Mo's restaurant on Connecticut Avenue (starting at a presumably more civilized 8:30 A.M.).

James Campbell, 37, Human Rights Lawyer
LEAD: James M. Campbell, a lawyer for the New York City Commission on Human Rights, died of complications from AIDS Monday at his home in Brooklyn.
He was 37 years old.
Mr.
Campbell joined the commission in 1986 in the law-enforcement bureau and helped to redraft the Human Rights Law and rules of practice.

LEAD: J.R.
Reid of North Carolina and Nick Anderson of Illinois led the list of 14 early entry candidates for the National Basketball Association draft June 27.

Officer Held in Fatal Shooting
LEAD: A 24-year-old New York City police officer was charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide in the accidental shooting death of a correction officer.
The policeman, Raul Socia of the Bronx, who surrendered at the Bronx District Attorney's office, was charged in the shooting death on Feb. 7, 1988, of Lee Valdespino, 27, a correction officer, at his Bronx home while they were off duty, the police said.

Preakness Will Solve Puzzles of Top 2 Colts
LEAD: The 114th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday will be bet and watched as a two-horse showdown between Sunday Silence and Easy Goer.
While they are clearly the two best colts in the field of nine, they also are the two most puzzling.
The race is as much a test of the true ability of both colts as a match between them.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''You are our Army.
You are our brothers and sisters.
You are Chinese.
Our interests are the same as yours.
We believe you have a conscience.
You must not crush the movement.'' - Linda Liu, a businesswoman, as she went from truck to truck pleading with soldiers sent to end the sit-in in Tiananmen Square.

LEAD: The Government called troops into the capital this morning and imposed martial law in parts of the city to crack down on China's growing democracy movement.
But tens of thousands of people rushed out of their homes to block troops from reaching student demonstrators in the central square.

LEAD: Most senators earned speaking fees last year from industries and trade associations with interest in legislation, according to financial disclosure reports released today.

LEAD: On March 6, a mother in Oregon watched a public television report about British companies that were discouraging children from eating poisonous household products by lacing them with Bitrex, the world's bitterest flavoring agent.

LEAD: Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita succumbed to months of relentless political battering and resigned today, plunging the Government into a period of turmoil that some commentators said could last for weeks.


U.S. Charges Rep. Rose With Disclosure Lapses
LEAD: The Justice Department today filed a civil suit accusing Representative Charlie Rose of failing to report on his Federal financial disclosure statements $138,694 in loans obtained over six years.

He was 77 years old and had lived in Nyack, N.Y. until two years ago, when he moved to Vero Beach.

LEAD: ''Blame It on the Movies!,'' a musical tribute to film songs, closed after the Wednesday performance at the Criterion Center, Stage Left, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street.
The musical, conceived and written by Ron Able, Billy Barnes and David Galligan and directed by Mr.
Galligan, ran for 12 previews and three regular performances.

LEAD: Scott Barry, a spokesman and counselor for AIDS victims, died of complications of the disease on May 11.

Mr.
Silverman succeeds Roger L. Stevens, who has been named chairman of the executive committee of the organization, which annually sponsors awards to authors.

Silverman is senior editorial adviser to the Time Inc.

LEAD: The final playoff to determine the 1989 United States World Championship team will begin tonight, and it is highly probable that the contestants will be a Californian squad headed by Chip Martel of Davis and a New Jersey-Chicago squad led by David Berkowitz, Old Tappan, N.J.

LEAD: A 44-year-old Manhattan man was chased into a Harlem subway station and stabbed to death last evening by three youths in front of more than two dozen witnesses, the police said.

Panama Guards at U.S. Embassy Seized
LEAD: Stepping up harassment of United States officials and employees here, Panamanian security forces have arrested at least 15 employees of the company that provides security for the American Embassy, officials said today.
At least four security guards have taken refuge in the embassy.


Officer Kills Lover in Suicide
LEAD: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and killed his lover yesterday and then killed himself after a quarrel outside Police Headquarters, the police said.


3 U.S. Navy Warships Arrive In Shanghai on Courtesy Call
LEAD: Three American Navy ships steamed into Shanghai for a courtesy call today, one day after the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, visited the city.


Queens Symphony Director
LEAD: The Queens Symphony has appointed Arthur Fagen as its music director to replace the ensemble's founder, David Katz, who died in 1987.
Mr.
Fagen is 38 years old and lives in Hewlett, L.I.
He studied at Wesleyan University and with the conductor Max Rudolf at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve decided in March to stop pushing up interest rates to slow inflation, the minutes of the Fed's policy-making meeting of March 28 disclose.

LEAD: Knick Coach Rick Pitino grimaced when Michael Jordan went to the free throw line with four seconds remaining in the game.

Target: Gangs That Plague Housing
LEAD: For years, the rules of life for the residents of the Rockwell Gardens public housing project here were decreed by armed young men patrolling the corridors.
They decided who came and went.
Sometimes they charged a toll.
Sometimes they issued a curfew to residents so gang members could make drug deals without being disturbed.

LEAD: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov was criticized today as ''ecologically illiterate'' by a Soviet legislator who said his possible replacement will be debated when the new congress meets next week.

He was 82 years old.
Mr.
Uhlenhaut began his 41-year career with Mercedes-Benz in 1931 as a test engineer.
In 1936 he became head of the company's racing-car division and guided production of the Silver

LEAD: Hollis Weeks Titman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
John DeWitt Titman of Brooklyn, and Eric Holmes Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Robert S. Scott of Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the Swedenborgian Church in San Francisco.
The Rev.
