Sterling Adding Goodrich Plant
LEAD: Sterling Chemicals Inc., a highly successful petrochemical products manufacturer, said it had agreed to acquire a Calvert City, Ky., plant from The B.F.
Goodrich Company for an undisclosed price.
The factory manufactures more than one billion pounds of vinyl chloride monomer, the base of polyvinyl chloride, or PVC plastics, widely used in pipes and tubing.


Okamoto Makes a Run But King Takes Lead
LEAD: Ayako Okamoto has come close to winning a major American women's golf championship several times in recent years, but has not quite made it.
The 38-year-old Japanese golfer led the L.P.G.A.
Championship after three of four rounds twice, and did not hold on to win.
Each of the last three years she finished in a tie for third.





In the Air, Safety and the Blind
LEAD: With only two members dissenting, a Senate committee last week voted to bar airlines from refusing blind passengers seats in rows with emergency exits.
That substitutes misguided compassion for common sense.

LEAD: Until recently, Ahmed Kahlawi was best known among Egyptians as a singer of religious songs.
Then came the raid.


U.S. Offers to Talk On Battlefield Arms, But With Stiff Terms
LEAD: The United States is willing to hold negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, provided some stiff conditions are met, Western officials said today.

LEAD: Although rainfall is filling reservoirs and saturating the ground, now is the time to think realistically about watering the garden during the long, hot days of summer.

Patents; An Ultrasonic Drill For Advanced Ceramics
LEAD: Researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., have developed an ultrasonic drill capable of boring through tough, space-age ceramic materials.

Spike Lee Stirs Things Up at Cannes
It's the dawn of a day that's going to be the longest and hottest of the summer.
Mr.
Senor Love Daddy, Bedford-Stuyvesant's favorite disk jockey, starts his wake-up show at top volume, ''doing the nasty to your ears, playing the platters that matter.''
He also opens Spike Lee's third and most accomplished film to date, the anatomy of a vicious Brooklyn racial incident.
The movie, titled ''Do the Right Thing,'' has successfully shaken up the 42d Cannes International Film Festival and is suddenly a contender for the festival's top prize.

Rise in Sea Levels May Indicate Earth Is Warming
LEAD: The water in the world's oceans appears to have risen a tenth of an inch per year in the last century, a change that could indicate that the planet is indeed warming up, Canadian researchers reported Thursday.


TENNIS  Agassi Advances Twice
LEAD: Andre Agassi acored two straight-set victories in four hours yesterday and top-seeded Mats Wilander was upset by Jay Berger of the United States at the Italian Open men's tennis championships in Rome.
Agassi, seeded second, reached the semfinals and became the tournament favorite after Wilander was upset, 6-3, 6-4.


ALABAMIAN GUILTY IN KILLING OF BLACK
LEAD: An all-white jury has convicted a former Ku Klux Klansman of murder for providing a rope and a pistol that were used in fellow Klansmen's assault on a black teen-ager who was strangled and hanged from a tree.


Interest Rates Move Sharply Lower
LEAD: Interest rates tumbled yesterday as investors flocked to buy long-term Treasury and corporate bonds before yields decline further.


Tainted Mushrooms Recalled
LEAD: The Federal Food and Drug Administration is recalling institutional-sized cans of mushrooms from China because of three outbreaks of food poisoning in February and April, including one at the Peninsula Hospital Center cafeteria in Queens.
The 68-ounce cans carry the packer designations ''TM'' in the top line or ''T3'' or ''M2'' in the middle line of a three-line code.

LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would delay salary increases for its 73,500 employees in the United States to help control costs amid a general slowdown in the computer industry.

LEAD: The dollar's rally resumed yesterday despite efforts by central banks to curb it.


Job Cutbacks Minimized in Ernst Link
LEAD: Moving swiftly to allay fears that a merger of their firms would mean closing numerous offices and laying off hundreds of people, the chairmen of Ernst &amp; Whinney and Arthur Young &amp; Company said yesterday that they expected actually to increase staffing after the two huge accounting firms combined.

LEAD: An unusually large surge in April income tax payments helped produce a record budget surplus of $41.45 billion for the Government last month, the Treasury Department said today.

LEAD: With the death Dr.
Richard R. Green, the Chancellor of the New York City public schools, a new round of kingmaking has commenced, once again raising unreasonable hopes for a sudden improvement of a severely ill system, once again illustrating how little changing the executive at the top can accomplish the necessary rehabilitation below.


Samuel J. Moskowitz, Lawyer, 82
LEAD: Samuel J. Moskowitz, a Manhattan lawyer for nearly 60 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I.
He was 82 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.


Pressures Foil Airlines' Efforts to Raise Fares
LEAD: When Continental Airlines announced last month that it was raising its discount fares as much as 18 percent, it expected the other airlines to follow suit.
But some did not, and this week Continental had to retract its increases, bringing a halt to a steady escalation in the price of an airline ticket.


Sierra Acquired By Halliburton
LEAD: The Halliburton Company, the engineering and oilfield services company, said it had acquired Sierra Geophysics Inc., a privately held computer software company that designs programs used to develop maps for minerals and energy exploration, a technology with a rapidly growing market,industry analysts say.

Miniscribe Calls Data Not Reliable
LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation has advised stockholders that the financial statements issued in the 1986 and 1987 fiscal years and in the first three quarters of 1988 were not reliable.
Shortly after the announcement Thursday, the rating firm Standard &amp; Poor's suspended Miniscribe's B-rating on $98 million of subordinated debt, saying it would be impossible to judge the company's financial condition.

She was 68 years old.

LEAD: As American viewers watched live television coverage from China last night, Chinese officials ordered the networks to cease transmitting pictures and commentary from a portable station set up in Beijing.

LEAD: Poring over recent statistics, many economists have concluded that the economy is managing to walk the line between inflation and recession.
It is apparently growing enough to stave off a big rise in unemployment but not enough to push prices up sharply.

Review/Dance; How a Work Can Age, Both in Time and in Spirit
LEAD: American Ballet Theater's latest novelty for New York is not exactly a ballet or a modern-dance work. ''The Garden of Villandry'' is a minor piece of movement theater by Martha Clarke and two colleagues about a woman who has a relationship with two men - a situation she embodies by constantly sandwiching herself between them.


Chancellor-Hunt Given Deadline Falling After Election
LEAD: The New York City Board of Education yesterday set itself a deadline of Dec. 31 to have a new schools chancellor in place, insuring that its nationwide search will be concentrated during the coming mayoral campaign.


Fewer Savings Units
LEAD: A United States savings industry regulator predicts there will be 1,000 fewer savings and loan associations in 10 years.
Darrel Dochow, head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's Office of Regulatory Activities, said the number of savings institutions would be reduced to 2,000 from 3,000 in a decade.


Funeral Director Admits Guilt
LEAD: A former funeral director, Bobby Wilks, 53 years old, pleaded guilty Wednesday to two counts of grand larceny for burying bodies without coffins or vaults their families had purchased.
Mr.
Wilks could be sentenced up to six years on each count.
Investigators found Joseph Roath's body had been wrapped in cardboard and buried only three feet deep instead of without the coffin and vault his family ordered.

ROBERT WEBBER, ACTOR, DIES AT 64
LEAD: Robert Webber, a prolific character actor whose sleek appearance and clenched-jaw look made him believable as the elegant businessman of sleazy character he played in hundreds of films and television dramas, died of Lou Gehrig's disease yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif.
He was 64 years old.


Kentucky's Basketball Program And 2 Players Heavily Penalized
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed the University of Kentucky's basketball program on probation for three years for recruiting and academic violations, and took the unusual step of banning one Kentucky player, Eric Manuel, from further N.C.A.A. competition.
Another player, Chris Mills, was barred from playing at Kentucky.


Administration Makes Choice a Top School Priority
LEAD: Declaring that the nation can no longer ''just patch or just tinker'' to repair its educational system, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today that the Bush Administration would work to let parents choose the schools their children attend.


Transit Agency Makes It Harder To Beat the Fare
LEAD: New turnstiles and higher railings at a Manhattan subway station have reduced fare-beating by 80 percent, Transit Authority officials told the authority's board yesterday as they outlined plans to revise the entire fare-collecting system.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Breaking Away
LEAD: As temperatures rise, bicyclists by the thousands take to the streets and parks of the city and the back roads of the countryside.
Before you join them, it is a good idea to have your bicycle overhauled by a qualified mechanic.
A thorough job by a bikeshop can cost anywhere from $45 to $75 or more for a 12- or 18-speed.

LEAD: Electric motors and internal combustion engines have been around for more than a century, and the basic principles have changed little.
But in recent weeks two independent inventors have won patents for designs intended to make the machines simpler and longer lasting by doing away with some familiar components.

Holly Farms Corp.
LEAD: The unusual efforts by the board of the Holly Farms Corporation to end its auction for the company appear to have misfired, leaving it without any new offers to consider.
Tyson Foods Inc., the chicken processor based in Springdale, Ark., that has been trying to acquire Holly Farms since October, objected to the Holly board's revised terms, which were sprung on the company last Friday.

Woman, 70, Fatally Stabbed
LEAD: A 70-year-old woman was found brutally stabbed in her Upper East Side apartment yesterday.
The body of Rita Drummond was found in her residence at 33 East End Avenue at 1:10 P.M., said a police spokesman, Officer Ed Feeney.
She had been stabbed many times in the upper body.
Her apartment had not been ransacked, and there was no sign of forced entry, the officer said.

Your Money; Time to Consider Shifting Assets
LEAD: As long as the annual inflation rate hovered below 5 percent, investors could put their money into certificates of deposit or Treasury securities yielding 8 to 10 percent and get a real return.
But in April consumer prices rose at an 8.1 percent annual rate, the Government reported, and if that continued, it would be more difficult to stay ahead of inflation, particularly on an after-tax basis.

LEAD: ''Magicians of the Earth,'' which opened Thursday at the Pompidou Center and La Villette, brings together contemporary art from all over the world, juxtaposing artists from New Guinea and Italy, Australia and England, Tibet and the United States.
Every culture and countless artistic approaches have been appropriated in a spectacular post-Modern bazaar in which everything seems equally valid and available.

Putting Spaceship Earth on Course
LEAD: OIL, air and water do not readily mix, but problems related to them do.
Each one represents a growing ecological concern, a problem in themselves, but in combination a threat to our quality of life and standard of living.
As an evolving conservationist, I feel that our current problems can only grow worse if we choose to ignore them.

Even those who like a bit of sun are wise to its hazards.

LEAD: The plastic explosive that destroyed Pan Am's Flight 103 over Scotland last year was hidden in a portable radio.

He then made an executive decision: He bit off a piece of the cork and ate it.

Near Miss for an Astronaut
LEAD: For Navy Capt.
David M. Walker, the easy part was commanding the space shuttle Atlantis on a four-day flight around the earth earlier this month.
The more hazardous part was getting to Washington from Houston last week for a Presidential reception honoring the shuttle crew.
About 30 miles west of Washington, aviation officials said, a jet training plane piloted by Captain Walker came within 500 feet of a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet carrying 176 people and bound for Paris, prompting the Pan Am pilot to report a ''near midair collision.

WHAT, ME ANGRY?
LEAD: I believe that Maggie Scarf's concluding suggestion in ''What, Me Angry?'' (Hers column: April 23), that she deal with her anger by taking a Valium, was meant in jest; however, I feel the joke may be lost on many.
As a society, we tend to accept the idea of medicating our feelings - if not with Valium, then with alcohol.

DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
LEAD: To read your article, one would think the modern comic book is distinguished from its predecessors solely by today's explicit sex and violence.
You ignore the laudable differences: a variety of nonwhite heroes, strong female characters (one series, ''The X-Men,'' has for years offered a rare role model: a black woman as the leader of the group) and socially relevant issues, from the Arab-Israeli conflict to drug abuse.

'THE WORLD HAS CHANGED ON US'
LEAD: Cray Research Inc., the nation's biggest maker of supercomputers, announced last week that it would split into two companies.
After the announcement, its chairman, John A. Rollwagen, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times to discuss the future of supercomputing and how this development affects it.


Correction
LEAD: A chart in some copies last Sunday about the New York City subways gave incorrect figures for ridership.
The number of riders on an average weekday rose from 3.52 million in the first quarter of 1985 to 3.71 million in the same period this year.


Reviews/Music; Authentic Gershwin
LEAD: The Harmonie Ensemble celebrated its 10th anniversary on Tuesday evening with an Alice Tully Hall concert devoted mostly to music by George Gershwin.
The performances were offered in the spirit of authenticity, in the sense that several of the works typically heard in posthumous rescorings were performed here in their original versions.

LEAD: The Ladies Professional Golf Association has narrowed to three the number of sites it is considering for its new national headquarters.

Correction
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about school desegration in Little Rock, Ark., referred incorrectly to Central High School.
Central, where Federal troops were sent 32 years ago to protect nine black pupils, is now 58 percent black and 42 percent white.
It is not one of the schools with overwhelmingly black enrollment that would get increased funds for remedial programs as part of a current desegregation proposal.

LEAD: Ralph A. Corbin Jr., a New Jersey banker for the last quarter-century, died of kidney failure at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J., yesterday.

LEAD: An article on April 23 about Portland, Ore., misstated the addresses of two restaurants.

I booed, too.

I was booing Pitino's removal of Strickland from the game, not Jackson's entry into the game or his performance.

The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any.

How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

LEAD: With millions of dollars riding on big-time collegiate athletics, the N.C.A.A. has strict rules prohibiting colleges from paying players more than the value of their athletic scholarships.

Backpacking Along the Pacific Shore
LEAD: CIVILIZATION clings to the water, so shorelines number among our most domesticated landscapes.
It is a dismaying reality for the backpacker, who longs for the seaside but wants to escape humanity and its artifacts.
A happy exception is found in Washington's Olympic National Park, at the upper-left-hand corner of the map, where an unexpected wilderness stands as wild today as it was when 16th-century mariners worked their way up the West Coast in search of the elusive Northwest

The Annual Event: Family Cookout On Long Island
LEAD: THE YEARLY CLAMBAKE, ONE OF TWO annual McGuinness family reunions, began at dawn on a typically foggy late-July morning in Lloyd Harbor on the North Shore of Long Island.
By 6 A.M., with the mist settling on top of the trees, 6 of the 31 people who would ultimately cram into the McGuinness house on this day had set off to comb the beach at Cold Spring Harbor for mussels.

This Versatile Stereo Receiver Adapts to Changing Habitats

Primitive Dreams Are Hitting The Big Time
LEAD: ''The natives are extremely fond of painting,'' wrote Thomas Watling, an Australian convict, almost 200 years ago.
The aborigines, who have inhabited the Australian continent for an estimated 50,000 years, have been painting on sand, bark and their own bodies for the last 30,000.
Suddenly their fondness for painting, now in acrylics on canvas, is landing them squarely in the lap of the international art world, for which they are adapting their grand creation myths, maps of the land and ceremonial symbols to the West's easel- painting tradition.

How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

A Centennial Effort to Add Cancer Unit
LEAD: PORT CHESTER, February 1889.
Fourteen Port Chester matrons, concerned over the plight of the sick and infirm in the community, form the Ladies Hospital Association, ''to serve humanity, to save lives and to relieve suffering.'' During the next several months they hold cake sales, lawn fetes and entertainments until they raise enough money to rent space for a hospital.

Reviews/Music; Joan Osborne Sings Blues
LEAD: The blues-bar circuit doesn't exactly encourage subtlety or originality.

Joan Osborne, who sang Thursday night at Mondo Cane, doesn't pretend to be anything other than white and northern.


Now We Know: Home Is Where the Art Is
It's all a matter of perspective, of ratio.
To the New York-based observer, American movie making has looked pretty paltry this year, mostly big-budget mass-market comedies of no distinction and even less humor.
Three thousand miles away, the scene suddenly takes on a different, far more promising aspect.
On the basis of two films shown on the second and third days of this 42d Cannes International Film Festival, one might think that American films are in the midst of some kind of crazy renaissance.

POSTINGS: Jersey Farmland Development; Houses Amid Rolling Hills
LEAD: When James Pitney took title to his brother Jonathan's farm in 1771, the property was one of the most extensive in northern New Jersey.
It had been assembled by Pitneys since the first of them, also named James, settled in the area earlier in the century.
There was little more around then than gently rolling hills, woodlands and meadows, criss-crossed here and there by streams and by narrow, winding paths.

Nelson Liriano also had four hits.


Lotto Is Financed by the Poor and Won by the States
LEAD: THE happiest person in Pennsylvania last month may have been Alverta Handel, a housekeeper from the town of Portage who beat 9.6 million-to-one odds to win an $8.2 million share of the record-breaking $115 million lotto jackpot.
But the biggest winner by far in Pennsylvania's lottery is the state treasury, which last year netted $593 million from ticket sales.


DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
LEAD: To characterize an entire industry as ''determined to dispel any lingering notion that its products are for children'' is incorrect.
One need only glance at the comics issued by Archie Comic Publications (''Betty and Veronica,'' ''Jughead''), Father Tree Press (''Elfquest''), Another Rainbow/Gladstone (''Mickey Mouse'' and ''Donald Duck'') and the revival of Classics Illustrated by the Berkley Publishing Group, First Publishing and Classics Media Group.

LEAD: WOODEN windowsills suffer greatly from weather.

LEAD: Westchester recycling programs won't get very far until the county's system of paying for garbage disposal is overhauled.

Song of the Fat Lady
LEAD: FAT people of the world, unite.
A crisis is imminent.
Every magazine, newspaper, and television show you see screams the evils of fat and the beauty of ''thin.'' Unless we react to this crisis, we may have nothing to gain and everything to lose.
We must remain on guard.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one.
The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any.
Now the stoop is gradually turning green.
How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?


BEYOND THE QUARK
LEAD: It would be foolish and wasteful to spend $4.4 billion on the Superconducting Supercollider when newer and superior technology -plasma particle accelerators, as reported in the March issue of Scientific American - is being proposed.
The whole question of the S.S.C. deserves another look.
We should pursue the development of a machine that could prove to be much cheaper and produce more power (faster particles).

LEAD: A Federal district judge has temporarily blocked planned drug tests covering 30 employees in the executive office of the President and hundreds of workers in the General Services Administration.

WHAT, ME ANGRY?
LEAD: Maggie Scarf's article made me anxious and a little angry.
Outspoken feminists often are portrayed unjustly as angry women.
Yet, if our predecessors had not spoken up out of anger and indignation, women in America would not today have the rights these women argued for.
PAMELA J. SPAAN  Ithaca, N.Y.

A Scarcity of Beds For Amtrak Passengers
LEAD: WITH the growing popularity of overnight train travel in North America, passengers are finding it difficult to book sleeping accommodations on either Amtrak or Via Rail Canada.

Prospects; A Trade Law With Teeth
LEAD: By May 30, the trade representative, Carla Hills, must issue a list of countries that unfairly restrict United States imports.
According to section 301 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988, once a country is put on the list, the trade representative must begin negotiations to correct the unfair practices.

Reviews/Music; Renaissance Sounds
LEAD: The first half of Calliope's program Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall brought the familiar piping, buzzing, tinkling and droning sounds of a Renaissance consort playing works by Praetorius, Isaac, Des Prez and their less-known or unknown fellows.
It was pleasant and jolly in the usual way: the sounds of the old instruments have lost little of their piquant flavor; the actual music making is a little on the light side; the Calliope foursome's determinedly down-home vocal contributions create the right atmosphere.

LEAD: An article on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today about aboriginal artists misstates the commission that the John Weber Gallery receives for sales of their work.
It is 40 percent, not 10.

Greco: Makeup Artist
LEAD: After Greco has applied makeup to a woman's face, he sometimes has to resist the impulse to sign his name - in eyebrow pencil - on the chin, perhaps, or beside a dimple.
The 35-year-old makeup expert once studied art and now considers the face his canvas.
He refuses to work in artificial light, and has been known to wander from room to room in clients' homes in search of sun.

LEAD: The incidents began in the spring of 1986, when the University of Wisconsin's chapter of Kappa Sigma fraternity held a party featuring a ''Harlem room.'' Watermelon and fried chicken were served in the room, which had trash on the floor and graffiti on the walls.
Members wore Afro wigs and blackface makeup.

LEAD: LED by the giant state and city pension funds, institutional investors are challenging corporate executives in increasingly provocative ways during the current round of annual shareholder meetings.

WHO'S THAT MAN WITH MARILYN HORNE?

Fleeing Jackson Hole's Bustle of Jackson Hole
LEAD: JACKSON HOLE looks too good to be true.
The great, glaciered peaks of the Tetons, arguably the continent's most classically beautiful mountains, soar more than a mile into the air from the valley floor.
A half-dozen pristine alpine lakes puddle at the base of the range, and the braided channels of the Snake River meander through the valley's lush meadows, sagebrush flats and groves of willow, cottonwood and aspen.

Marvel Comics should also be given credit for casting light on such subjects as drugs and child abuse, through a series of free instructional comic books.

Correction
LEAD: A table last week showing the volume of weekly bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange included two errors.
The numbers shown for 1988 and 1989 should be reversed.
In addition, the year-to-date figure in terms of par value for 1988 was listed incorrectly.
It is $2,905,375,000.

A Wilderness Named for the Gods
LEAD: DEEP inside the Olympic rain forest on the far western edge of the continent, there is not a fingerprint of the 20th century, nor the 18th century for that matter.
The trees in this part of world were seedlings when Leif Ericson stumbled upon Greenland a thousand years ago; they were mature firs when Columbus landed in the Caribbean islands and towering giants when the Declaration of Independence was signed.


Reviews/Theater; Mark Medoff Tells of Softness in a Macho World
LEAD: One would have to search hard to find a playwright more obsessed with machismo, heroism and psychic emasculation than Mark Medoff.
In his first successful play, ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' a gun-toting drifter terrorizes the occupants of a roadside diner into confronting ''the truth'' about themselves.

A Camcorder Wins a Battle, But Can It Win the War?
LEAD: Now in its fifth year, the rivalry between camcorder formats seems endless, pointless and confusing.
But videophiles are willy-nilly forced to take sides.
They must choose one of the two contesting formats - VHS or 8-millimeter - when buying a camcorder, and naturally they'd like to pick the winner.

What Elements Do to a Windowsill
LEAD: WOODEN windowsills suffer greatly from weather.
Even though they are designed to shed moisture, snow and rain often accumulate on them and remain for long periods of time, fostering decay.


Elegant Ghosts Haunt 'Black and Blue'
LEAD: Seeking an evening of pure entertainment, I went back to ''Black and Blue'' and was bowled over by an evening of sheer artistry.
This return visit to the tap-studded revue at the Minskoff Theater for the first time since it began its run in January revealed how much more sharply the performances have been defined.


Danger: Keep Off the Grass
LEAD: MY neighbor has tiny green flags posted in a casual array on his perfectly manicured front lawn.
They stand, inconsequential and unimportant, close to the sidewalk as if a child had set out to play a harmless game whose purpose could only amaze and elude adults.

New-Wave Preserves
LEAD: SUMMER IS THE SEASON OF EXCESS, delivering its many fresh fruits and vegetables with surfeits first of one variety, then another.
To take advantage of this bounty, and to preserve its fragrance and flavor, I use my microwave oven to make jams and jellies, relishes and pickles.
Having a selection of colorful and tasty preserves on hand, ready to serve, is always convenient, especially when guests drop by.

Reviews/Music; Jamie Avins's Constructions
LEAD: Jamie Avins is an architectural choreographer.
That was evident from the clear-cut gestures of ''Center and Circumference,'' the program she presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.
It was even more apparent in the sets she designed for her productions.
The environments in which her dancers found themselves affected the ways in which they moved.

Burying the Dead Acknowledges a Life
LEAD: A 68-YEAR-OLD relative of mine has just been damned with faint praise by some family members for having finally purchased a burial site.
From my point of view, he wasn't fooling around.
It isn't one of these above-ground pink marble waterproof jobs.
It is a real, in the ground gravesite, in a cemetery where some of his ancesters he never met are buried.

Sex Education: Too Little, Too Late
LEAD: More than 85 percent of adult Americans say they favor sex education for school-age children.
But are those children learning enough to live in a country that has experienced a sexual revolution?
Their teachers say no.
According to a new report from the Alan Guttmacher Institute, sex education instructors are somewhat more apt to teach about AIDS and protection from other sexually transmitted diseases than they are about birth control.

Ballet School Gala Benefit Is a Farewell For Teacher
LEAD: The School of American Ballet will celebrate itself and its young dancers tonight in a gala benefit performance at the Juilliard Theater.
The Spring Workshop is an annual event, a rite of passage for the most advanced students at the school, which is affiliated with the New York City Ballet.

ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Heartburn for Fun And Profit: A Saga
LEAD: LAST week a North Carolina gastroenterologist, speaking at a medical meeting in Washington, told of his small research project that has found that runners sometimes suffer from heartburn as they run.
He described how administering a prescription drug that suppresses stomach acid secretion to about a dozen runners before a run appeared to prevent the heartburn in many of them.

LEAD: In the Belmont Stakes on June 10, Sunday Silence will try to become the first horse to win racing's Triple Crown since Affirmed in 1978, while Easy Goer will try to avoid becoming only the second horse ever to finish second in each leg of the series.
The first was his sire, Alydar, who was second to


Review/Theater; Theme and Variations On Mother and Daughter
LEAD: ''The Blessing,'' a new play by Clare Coss at the American Place Theater, is intended to be a penetrating drama about the complex relationship between an aging mother and her divorced daughter who is a lesbian.
Instead, it is an exceedingly tiresome visit with two self-serving and unlikable characters.


BRITONS EXPELLED FROM SOVIET UNION
LEAD: The Soviet Union has ordered eight British diplomats and three British journalists to leave the country in retaliation for an order by London expelling eight Soviet envoys and three Soviet reporters from Britain.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Tiananmen Square has become a holy spot for Chinese democracy.
If we stay here longer, we will contribute more to China's democratization, and increase our influence.
If we withdraw, we will let down the citizens who have defended us.
We will stay until our victory.''  - Wang Dan, a student leader in Beijing.

Afghanistan Lifted the Veil Decades Ago
LEAD: To the Editor:


Tax Watch; Corporate Burden At State Levels
LEAD: STATE and local taxes are an increasingly significant cost of doing business, growing in the last 20 years to almost 8 percent of corporate profits from just over 2 percent, the Arthur Andersen &amp; Company accounting firm reports.
But too often businesses fail to realize that this cost, like others, can be managed.

LEAD: The town of Huntington, already fined $350,000, must close its landfill in 60 days or face additional heavy fines, the Department of Environmental Conservation said yesterday.

LEAD: Susan Beth Goldstein and Andrew Martin Parower were married yesterday at the Biddle Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz.

LEAD: ''Welcome to the Jungle,'' declares the graffito at the entrance to Countryside Village, a multimillion-dollar housing renovation project that has enraged elderly residents, mystified local building inspectors and raised questions from town officials who ask how the Federal Government could spend so much to do so little.

Man Sought in Wife's Death
LEAD: The New York City police yesterday were seeking a Queens man who they said stabbed his estranged wife to death in a parking lot, went into a restaurant and told someone there to call the police and then fled.
The police said the man, John Dafnos, 44 years old, attacked his estranged wife, Sophie, shortly after she left work at the Astron Restaurant on 150th Street in Whitestone.

Australian Trade Deficit
LEAD: Despite a rise in exports, Australia had a trade deficit of 1.2 billion Australian dollars, or $924 million (United States), in April, the Government reported last week.
Although the current account deficit was lower than the gap of 1.63 billion Australian dollars in March, it was still more than double the deficit of 558 million Australian dollars a year earlier.

Reviews/Music; Two Philharmonic Programs for Soloists
LEAD: A major orchestra's music director inevitably auditions more aspiring young soloists than he can fit comfortably into a season's schedule, however impressed with them he may be.
Zubin Mehta's solution this season has been to split one of the New York Philharmonic's four-concert subscription blocks into two programs of concertos, featuring five soloists, most of them new to Philharmonic audiences.

Japan Wholesale Prices
LEAD: Wholsesale prices in Japan rose 2.5 percent in April, the Government said Friday.
The figure was lower than expected, and it reduces the chance that the Bank of Japan will raise its key discount rate.
Financial markets here had speculated that a 3 percent consumption tax on goods and services introduced April 1 would stimulate inflation and put pressure on the central bank to act.


Now, a Portable Court
LEAD: A new tennis teaching device allows you to practice strokes when you don't have access to a court.


Insurers Plan Ad Campaign To Fight Forced Rate Cuts
LEAD: Faced with growing political pressure because of skyrocketing automobile premiums, the insurance industry plans to begin an advertising campaign in June in an effort to dissuade states from imitating California and forcing insurance companies to cut rates, an industry spokesman said.

LEAD: The strawberry fields that cover the hillsides here are dotted with the bent backs of Mixtec Indians, descendants of a proud civilization of ancient Mexico who are moving in growing numbers to occupy the bottom of America's social pyramid as migrant farm laborers.


Yearnings of Youth: An Old Pattern
LEAD: When one of China's student hunger strikers said last week that his demand was for ''a beautiful, perfect system,'' he was not merely being naive.
He was reflecting in somewhat naive-sounding terms the yearning for restored national greatness that has led Chinese youth several times this century to take to the streets to demand change from what they saw as incompetent or dictatorial governments.

LEAD: Sophie Maroot's job begins at 7:30 A.M.

Almost all, vulnerable to common infections, require hourly rounds for medication.

Market Place; Program Trading Drives Up Stocks
LEAD: THE VOLATILITY brought on by program traders - or more accurately by those using the futures market to change their exposure to stocks rapidly - is back.
The sharp gains in stock prices last week bore all the earmarks of a futures-driven market, albeit of the sort that provokes no public outcry, since those who denounce program trading are more disturbed by falling prices than rising ones.


Bicycle Oldies Are Making Good
LEAD: NOSTALGIA for the wide-tire bicycles of the 1950's has returned cycling to a bygone era.
Updated versions of the old gear - bikes with upright handlebars and balloon tires - now come equipped with multiple gears, index shifting and improved braking systems.
The cycles are known by a variety of names: mountain bikes, all-terrain bikes, off-road bikes and city bikes.

The Drama Desk Awards
LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' was selected by the Drama Desk yesterday as the outstanding musical of the 1988-89 theater season.
Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles'' was named best new play and ''Our Town'' best revival.
The Drama Desk, formed in 1949, is an association of New York City critics, editors and reporters.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about legislation to help the savings and loan industry referred incorrectly to the liability of certain investors in a savings institution should that institution fail.

LEAD: The truth of what has happened in China is so startling that even now the world hardly takes it in.

LEAD: As the traditional opening of the summer season approaches, beach operators on Long Island are combing trash from the sand with huge mechanical rakes and catamarans in New York Harbor are skimming garbage with steel nets, all in an effort to prevent a repeat of last year's closings of polluted beaches.

LEAD: It was a classic American business story when a dissatisfied group of takeover experts at the First Boston Corporation suddenly quit last year and formed Wasserstein, Perella &amp; Company to do things their own way.
And the story could not have been more Japanese when Nomura Securities, which later acquired 20 percent of Wasserstein,


Chris-Craft Ends Fight On Warner
LEAD: Sweeping away what may be the last big obstacle in their $18 billion merger, Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. announced yesterday that they had settled their dispute with Chris-Craft Industries over the interpretation of a five-year-old hands-off agreement between Warner and Chris-Craft.

Only Radical Steps Can Save Wildlife In Kenya, Leakey Says
LEAD: WITH Kenya's wildlife facing relentless threats from tourists, poachers and a swelling population, Richard E. Leakey, the paleontologist who recently became the country's Wildlife Services director, is urging radical changes in a land where vast herds once roamed unfettered.

PATTERNS
LEAD:  An Eye on China


Burnett Moves To New Offices
LEAD: The Leo Burnett Company will set off on a long trek this weekend - carting 36,000 boxes of personal belongings and 2.5 million pounds of office equipment five blocks across town to its new headquarters building on West Wacker Drive in Chicago.


After 26 Seasons, Is John Out of Time?
LEAD: Tommy John turned 46 years old yesterday, but he hoped the day would pass quietly.
He was going to play golf in the morning, help his two older sons set up a pitching machine at the park in the afternoon and have dinner with his wife and friends in Manhattan in the evening.
It was going to be an easy, uneventful day, the kind any middle-aged man would enjoy on his birthday.


Reviews/Dance; City Ballet Students in Balanchine and Bournonville Pieces
LEAD: The School of American Ballet presented its 25th annual Spring Workshop program Saturday night at the Juilliard Theater.
The school, which is affiliated with the New York City Ballet, appears to be blessed with talent.


Bonn Had Informant in the Group Suspected in the Pan Am Bombing
LEAD: A Jordanian explosives expert who belonged to a terrorist group suspected of bombing a Pan Am jumbo jet last December worked for West German intelligence late last year, American officials said today.


For Fall, a Flirtatiousness Shapes Elegant Fur Designs
LEAD: The explosion of fashion in fur continued unabated through showings last week that started with the colors and patterned fabrics in Oscar de la Renta's presentation of styles for Wagner Furs and ended with the casual jackets shown with tights by Giorgio di Sant'Angelo for Robert Sidney.
There were plenty of styles for traditionalists who like their minks long and flowing, but there was a wide choice of casual shapes and furs by fashion designers who put individual stamps on their collections.


India Reports Successful Test of Mid-Range Missile
LEAD: India successfully fired its first medium-range surface-to-surface missile today, the Press Trust of India said in a report from the test site on the Bay of Bengal.

Flames, Canadiens Play Copycats
LEAD: The Flames are eager to be heading home to Calgary, a city that paints itself red at this time of year, where they intend to break the 2-2 Stanley Cup championship stalemate they earned with a 4-2 victory at Montreal on Sunday night.

LEAD: ''For Israel, now is the time to lay aside, once and for all, the unrealistic vision of a greater Israel.''  - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.  [ A1:2. ]


Blue Jays Talk to Piniella
LEAD: Officials of the Toronto Blue Jays interviewed Lou Piniella yesterday in their quest for a new manager.
Pat Gillick, the Blue Jays' general manager, called the two-hour meeting ''very preliminary,'' saying they exchanged ideas and philosophy.


Girl Dies in Fire-Escape Fall
LEAD: A 1 1/2-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed yesterday afternoon when she crawled on a fire escape and fell to her death in an alley five floors below, the police said.
The accident was at 5 P.M. at 930 Myrtle Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, said a police spokesman, Sgt.
Peter Berry, who added that her parents, Mr.


12 Striking Teachers Arrested
LEAD: Twelve teachers were arrested at a protest today as the strike by 23,000 teachers against the nation's second-largest school district entered its second week.
Those arrested were among 100 teachers who staged a sit-in at the school headquarters after union negotiators walked out of contract talks Sunday night.

Tennessee Williams in Russian
LEAD: Vitaly Solomin, a Soviet actor with a deep voice and a mesmerizing stare, broke off the dialogue and silently peered into the darkness beyond the rehearsal stage, looking for the rich abyss of Tennessee Williams's imagination.


G.M. Unit Contract
LEAD: Electronic Data Systems, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it had received a three-year, $100 million systems integration contract, with options for two one-year extensions, from Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services.
It said it would provide for the transfer, implementation and operation of an integrated data access system for recipients.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the 30th annual conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee:


Rig Count Falls Sharply
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States plunged by 34 last week, to a total of 737, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago, the count was 892.
The count - the widely watched industry index of drilling activity - reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

Supreme Court Roundup; New York Trials Allowed in Suits Over Cruise Ship Takeover
LEAD: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for damage suits from the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro to be tried in a Federal district court in New York rather than in Italian courts.


N.H.L. Gives Hextall 12-Game Suspension for Attack on Chelios
LEAD: Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyers' No. 1 goalie, was given a 12-game suspension by the National Hockey League today for his attack on Chris Chelios of the Montreal Canadiens in the sixth game of the teams' semifinal Stanley Cup playoff series.

Lawsuit Raises Issue of Color Bias Between Blacks
LEAD: When Tracy Lynn Morrow sued her employer two years ago, her complaint was a common one: She said she had been harassed and discriminated against by her supervisor because of the color of her skin.
What made her suit less common was that both she and her supervisor are black.


Secord Enters Plea of Not Guilty To Later Iran-Contra Indictment
LEAD: Richard V. Secord, the retired Air Force major general facing new charges in the Iran-contra affair, pleaded not guilty today to charges of covering up profits from selling arms to Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels.


Eastern Air Slots Issued
LEAD: America West Airlines Inc., a growing regional airline making a push into East Coast markets, was a big winner today in a Government lottery for airline slots vacated because of the Eastern Airlines strike.

Florida Court to Speed Abortion Consent Case
LEAD: The Florida Supreme Court said today that for now, minors are free to get abortions without an adult's consent, but it moved up a hearing on the validity of the law.


Grain and Soybeans Slump; Copper Prices Also Decline
LEAD: Prices of grain and soybean futures dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting investor reaction to forecasts of rain and the relentless rise in the dollar's value.


Indy's Master of Body Work
LEAD: A tractor and an Indy car don't invite many analogies.
But for Dr.
Terry Trammell, who has put people back behind the wheel of both, the Indiana farmer and the Indianapolis 500 driver are kindred souls.


Upheaval in China; Army May Be Trying to Avoid Crisis
LEAD: The active-duty leadership of China's army is a ''transitional generation'' that in recent years has stressed the goal of becoming a professional military force removed from politics, and it is anxious to avoid direct involvement in the Beijing democracy protests, several American experts said today.


Interco Sets Sale Of Ethan Allen
LEAD: Interco Inc., a diversified concern based in St.
Louis, said that it would sell its Ethan Allen Inc. furniture unit to a company formed by the subsidiary's management and a group of investors led by Castle Harlan Inc.
Interco put a value of $388 million on the deal, consisting of $357 million in cash, certain real estate assets and the assumption of debt.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Win Returns to Winners Circle: Win, the popular 9-year-old New York-bred who returned to racing last month after an absence of three and a half years, scored his first victory since November 1985 when he won yesterday's featured Slightly Dangerous Handicap at Belmont Park.
Win led all the way under Richard Migliore and held off Three Engines, the favorite, in a stretch duel to win by a head after a mile and a quarter on the grass in 2:027 2/5.

He succeeds E. Wayne Weeks, who retired.

A Glass Premiere to Open Serious Fun
LEAD: The New York premiere of Philip Glass's chamber opera ''The Fall of the House of Usher'' will kick off Lincoln Center's third annual Serious Fun festival on July 14 at Alice Tully Hall, Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, announced yesterday.


Moscow Imposes Cuts In Staffing for British
LEAD: The Soviet authorities announced today that the British Embassy and other British institutions in the Soviet Union would be required to cut their staffs.
The move came after a week in which London expelled 11 Soviet nationals on suspicion of espionage and Moscow responded in kind.


Ex-Aide Says Pierce Ruled on Who Got Big Housing Grants
LEAD: Samuel R. Pierce, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Reagan Administration, personally selected or promoted projects to receive housing subsidies under a program now being investigated as a source of funds that improperly benefited prominent Republicans, a former senior H.U.D. official says.


Fugitive in Court For Fraud Sentence
LEAD: A Brooklyn judge yesterday formally executed her jail sentence against Sheldon Weinberg, who was convicted of Medicaid fraud, and admonished him for his ''crime of violence.''

LEAD: As much as Americans rightly salute Beijing's rebellious students, they know that their protest cannot go on forever.
Sooner or later, the everyday bustle of Tiananmen Square will be restored.
The only question is whether this monumental uprising, watched by the world, will end in violence.
The answer depends on the outcome of a larger, invisible struggle - to decide who will succeed Deng Xiaoping as China's chief leader and shape

LEAD: Following a lead set by neighboring Kenya two weeks ago, Tanzania has called for a global ban on the ivory trade to try to stop the illing of elephants by poachers, officials said today.

LEAD: A group of 17 business leaders and educators yesterday announced the creation of the Business Enterprise Trust, a national organization intended to increase awareness of issues of corporate responsibility.

Lendl Seeded First
LEAD: Ivan Lendl, a three-time champion in Paris, tops the men's seedings for the $4.5 million French Open championships, officials announced yesterday.
The event, the second Grand Slam tournament of the year, will be played May 29-June 11 on the red-clay courts of Roland Garros Stadium.
Sixteen of the top 20 players in the world are entered.


2 Lines for Sale At Pillsbury
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate that earlier this year acquired the Pillsbury Company, said today that it would sell two of Pillsbury's product lines: Bumble Bee Seafoods and Van de Kamp's.


South, in One Volume: Myths and Moon Pies
LEAD: Weighing in at nearly 8 pounds and nearly 1,600 pages, the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture has been completed.
The chronicle, 10 years in the making, tries to define the South with scholarly treatments of the popular culture of pickups and mobile homes as well as the roles played by race, violence and religion in shaping the region's character.


Kean Remaining Neutral In Governorship Primary
LEAD: Gov.
Thomas H. Kean decided today not to endorse any candidate in the Republican primary for governor.

A.T.&amp;T. Union Backs a Strike
LEAD: Members of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's largest union have voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if a new contract is not reached by midnight Saturday, the union said today.


Margot Zemach, 57, Author, Dies; Also Illustrated Books for Children
LEAD: Margot Zemach, an award-winning children's book illustrator and author whose witty, lively works reinterpreted folk tales for younger readers, died of Lou Gehrig's disease Sunday at her home in Berkeley, Calif.
She was 57 years old.


Amerada Pays Big Price for Reserves
LEAD: The Amerada Hess Corporation agreed today to buy most of the energy reserves of Transco Exploration Partners for $911 million in cash, a value that analysts said was surprisingly high.

Pontiac Head Is Moved To Oldsmobile Division
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation yesterday transferred the head of Pontiac, its best-performing car divisions in recent years, to the helm of Oldsmobile, one of its most troubled.


Savings Unit Plea Rejected
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today rejected a bid by the Great Western Bank of Beverly Hills, Calif. to leave the savings and loan industry deposit insurance fund to join the bank insurance fund.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Sports World Specials column of SportsMonday this week about Diane Dixon's new job with the Yankees misidentified the event in which she won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympic Games.
She was a member of the 1,600-meter relay team, not in the individual 400-meter race.


HONG KONG MARKET FALLS OVER UNREST
LEAD: Hong Kong investors reacted swiftly and fearfully to the political crisis in China today, frantically selling shares and forcing the market's index down by almost 11 percent.
It was the greatest plunge in a single day here since the worldwide market collapse of 1987.

The Leaders, on Video
LEAD: Jack O'Dwyer, chronicler of the public relations business, has entered the video age - releasing a videocassette of interviews with 10 leading industry executives.
In the video, Mr.
O'Dwyer, who publishes a newsletter on the industry, quizzes the chief executives of the 10 largest agencies on current industry issues.


Washington Talk; Politics
LEAD: The political direct-mail specialists, who send out all those letters begging for money for this candidate or that cause, prefer their politics tough and personal.
They need heroes and devils and threats that Western civilization is about to end unless you send your $25, more if you can.


Review/Television; My Lai: Hard to Forget, Hard to Remember
LEAD: Of all the painful memories of Vietnam, none cut more deeply into America's vision of itself than the massacre at My Lai. ''Remember My Lai,'' tonight's quietly powerful ''Frontline'' documentary on Channel 13 at 10, brings back the terrible day of March 16, 1968, when American soldiers killed hundreds of


Albert B. Dick 3d, 71, Manufacturer, Is Dead
LEAD: Albert Blake Dick 3d, former president of the A. B. Dick Company, manufacturers of business machines, died Friday at Lake Forest Hospital in Illinois after a brief illness.
He was 71 years old and lived in Lake Forest.


Cat Stevens Gives Support To Call for Death of Rushdie
LEAD: The musician known as Cat Stevens said in a British television program to be broadcast next week that rather than go to a demonstration to burn an effigy of the author Salman Rushdie, ''I would have hoped that it'd be the real thing.''


Campaign Trail; Gifts for Giulianis: Lengthy List
LEAD: Among the many indignities suffered by candidates for mayor in New York City is the public dissemination of the smallest details of their private lives, from tax returns to stock holdings.
For Rudolph W. Giuliani, that includes the donors of wedding and baby gifts.


Police, Citing Parolee, Shun Clearwater Fair
LEAD: Westchester County police officers are refusing to volunteer to patrol next month's Clearwater Festival, and the County Executive has said Westchester will drop its sponsorship of the event, because Gary McGivern, the paroled murderer of a county deputy sheriff, is working for the Clearwater environmental group.


Schools Pinched by Cuts in Food Surplus
LEAD: The amount of surplus dry milk and other dairy products that the Government distributes to school lunch programs has declined so much that school officials are scrambling for substitutes and probably will have to increase lunch prices this fall.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Soar
LEAD: A sharp and unexpected run-up in the dollar caused prices of Treasury bonds and notes to explode yesterday, market participants said, and yields on some securities fell to their lowest levels in more than 14 months.


Upheaval In China; STANDOFF PERSISTS IN BEIJING; 7 TOP EX-COMMANDERS WARN ARMY 'MUST NOT ENTER CITY'
LEAD: In a major blow to the authority of Prime Minister Li Peng, seven senior military figures formally objected on Monday to the Government's plan to bring troops into the capital and suppress China's democracy movement.

Plessey Net Rises 14%
LEAD: The British electronics company Plessey P.L.C. said today that pretax profits rose 14 percent, to $:195.5 million ($309 million), in the year ended March 31.


Avon Stock Up On Speculation
LEAD: Amid speculation that the bidding for Avon Products Inc., the direct-selling cosmetics company based in New York, was not finished, Avon's share price rose $2.375 yesterday, to $34.625, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.


Thatcher the Issue in Vote on Europe
LEAD: With the rest of the British political spectrum undergoing the most significant shift in years, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her resistance to European political and economic union have suddenly become the most heated issue in the campaign for elections for the European Parliament next month.


Chess
LEAD: Those rare players who succeeded in getting advantageous positions against Bobby Fischer can remember the demonic energy that that eccentric genius could marshall to upset the course of the game.
The feeling of control that one has in a superior position would immediately be gone and one would be battling into the depths of a hurricane or diving into a seething sea of lava.


Stock Prices Mixed; Dow Inches Up 0.92
LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday after opening sharply higher in concert with a much stronger dollar.

LEAD: Rick Pitino and his wife, Joanne, arrived here this afternoon and spent the day touring the city and the University of Kentucky campus and meeting with city and University of Kentucky officials about the school's vacant head-coaching position.

LEAD: The AMR Corporation's American Eagle commuter subsidiary plans to order about $1 billion worth of turboprop airplanes from Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden, people in the industry said yesterday.

Firefighters Climb 48 Flights To Put Out Blaze in Cityspire
LEAD: Firefighters trudged up 48 flights of stairs in the 73-story Cityspire building yesterday to fight a suspicious blaze that started in a barrel filled with construction debris, fire officials said.


Upheaval in China; From Asian Neighbors, It's Silence and Anxiety
LEAD: Asian governments are largely keeping silent on the upheaval in China, waiting to see whether Beijing will move toward further democracy or repression.


Florida Investor Buys Celtics Stake
LEAD: A Florida investor has acquired a 5.1 percent nonvoting stake in the limited partnership that owns the Boston Celtics, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
David Rhodin Murphey 3d, president of the Tampa-based Murphey Capital Inc., disclosed that he had bought 326,100 units in Boston Celtics L.P.


Corrections
LEAD: The Company Index in Business Day on Thursday carried an erroneous listing for the Southern Pacific Railroad's parent company.
Referring to an article about the derailment of a freight train, the index should have shown Rio Grande Industries; the railroad is no longer owned by Santa Fe Southern Pacific, which is now the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation.

New Surge Is Worrying White House
LEAD: The White House said today that the dollar's rise could undermine progress in reducing the trade deficit, and it reasserted its commitment to coordinating economic policy with other countries to keep the dollar stable.


Arab Talks Expected to Focus on P.L.O. and Syria
LEAD: The Arab summit meeting that begins on Tuesday is expected to back a request by the Palestine Liberation Organization for an international conference to pave the way for a Palestinian state.
Some Arab diplomats from the Persian Gulf region said the nations meeting here were also expected to put pressure on Syria to reduce its military presence in Lebanon, where there are about 40,000


Guzman Out for Year
LEAD: Jose Guzman, who was second on the Texas Ranger staff last year in earned-run average, innings pitched and strikeouts, will miss the 1989 season because of a partial tear of his right rotator cuff muscle, the club said yesterday.
Guzman will be examined by Dr.
Frank Jobe next Monday in Los Angeles and is expected to undergo arthroscopic surgery.


Rift in Continent
LEAD: One of the most ambitious studies of a single geologic feature has found that the rift valley in midcontinent contains the deepest accumulation of volcanic material known in the world.


Reynolds Appointment Will Be a Homecoming
LEAD: James W. Johnston, in charge of Citibank's consumer banking operations in the Northeast, will become chairman and chief executive of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco USA on June 1.


Campus AIDS Survey Finds Threat Is Real But Not Yet Rampant
LEAD: The first national survey of AIDS virus infection among college students indicates the AIDS threat on campus is real but not yet rampant, researchers said today.


U.S. Savings Rules Tighter
LEAD: Federal regulators announced new regulations today requiring savings institutions to meet more stringent standards in documenting their securities activities, the latest in a series of steps to tighten supervision of the troubled industry.

2-Year Car Registry To Start in New York
LEAD: New York State's switch to a two-year automobile registration, a move intended to help close a potential state budget deficit, begins on June 16, state officials said yesterday.


Mojo Holders Approve Sale of 2 Units to HDM
LEAD: Shareholders of Mojo MDA, the Australian ad agency, yesterday approved the sale of two subsidiaries to HDM.
The units, Mattingly advertising agency and Marketing Communications Holdings will become part of a new company, called HDM Mattingly Group, which is controlled by HDM.

Soviet Bread Sets Off Capitalist Struggle
LEAD: Plans to import ''peace bread'' from Moscow have set off a cold war between Bloomingdale's and Zaro's Bread Basket, the New York bakery chain.


Leniency Asked For Ron Peters
LEAD: Federal prosecutors are asking leniency in the drug and tax evasion case involving Ron Peters, who, according to authorities, has reported taking perhaps more than $1 million in bets on behalf of Pete Rose.


Corrections
LEAD: The calendar of events in the Westchester Weekly on May 21 misstated the date of the performance of the Hudson Valley Singers at the Irvington Town Hall.
They will perform there on June 3, not this Saturday.


Chrysler Move on Plant
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would not add a second shift at its plant on Jefferson Avenue in Detroit next month as planned, because of slow sales of the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompact models built there.
About 1,600 workers will remain on indefinite layoff, possibly until Chrysler completes a new plant at the site in 1992.

What Does Pitino Really Want?
LEAD: Addressing the people of Kentucky as ''you'' sounds a bit distant from somebody being asked to save the commonwealth.

Anti-Radar Missile Succeeds In Second Test by Air Force
LEAD: A missile designed to zero in on and destroy enemy radar posts underwent its second successful test, the Air Force announced today.


2 Are Burned by Third Rail
LEAD: Two subway track workers were burned yesterday when a tool they were using touched an electrified third rail in the Bronx.
It was the second accident in a week involving the use of rubber safety mats to cover the third rail instead of turning off the power.
A track gang was working near 149th Street and the Grand Concourse when the tongs used to lift track accidentally touched the electrified rail at 4:16 A.M., transit officials said.

TENNIS
LEAD:  Ever Advances: Top-seeded ChrisEvert defeated a qualifier, Sabine Hack of West Germany, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the first round of the Geneva European Open women's tournament.
In the second round, Evert, the 1987 winner of the tournament, will meet the defending champion Barbara Paulus of Austria, who is unseeded.


Italy Gives Arab a Life Term In a 1982 Synagogue Attack
LEAD: An Italian court imposed a life sentence in absentia today on a Palestinian convicted in a 1982 attack on Rome's main synagogue in which a 2-year-old boy was killed and 37 other people were wounded.


Smith of Islanders Has Option to Coach
LEAD: Bill Torrey, the general manager of the Islanders, said yesterday that he and Billy Smith, the 38-year-old goaltender who has an option year left on a two-year contract, had discussed the possibility of Smith's retiring as a player to become a part-time goaltender coach next season.

Jessica E. Holland; Historian, 42
LEAD: Jessica E. Holland, an oral historian, died Monday when the bicycle she was riding was hit by a car in Nuit St.
Georges, France, where she was vacationing.
She was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Cameras Are Likely to Stay in Court
LEAD: New York State is set to extend for two years an experiment allowing news cameras in its courtrooms, but with changes that would effectively block the filming of arraignments, legislative officials said today.


Walter Deeley, 59, Ex-Intelligence Aide Who Battled Leaks
LEAD: Walter G. Deeley, a retired senior intelligence official who headed efforts to protect American communications from foreign eavesdropping, died of cancer Friday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
He was 59 years old and lived in Baltimore.

Metro Datelines; Medical Waste Is Found Near River
LEAD: Medical waste has washed ashore on two Delaware River beaches and authorities said yesterday they are trying to find out where it came from.


Slayer of Sons Gets Life Term
LEAD: Bartley James Dobben was sentenced today to life in prison without parole for murdering his two young sons in a 1,300-degree foundry ladle.
Mr.
Dobben, 28 years old, received the mandatory sentence from Judge James Graves Jr. of Muskegon County Circuit Court.
Mr.
Dobben was sentenced a week after a jury found him guilty but mentally ill on two counts of murder.

LEAD: Ron Hextall said yesterday he should not have picked a fight with Chris Chelios of Montreal, but the Philadelphia Flyers goaltender said he should not have been suspended for 12 games, either.

Justice in New York, Observed
LEAD: The idea that cameras in courtrooms can inform the public without endangering the right of the accused to a fair trial once was hotly debated, but experience has quieted most of the arguments.
The Supreme Court approved the concept eight years ago.
Most of the states now permit filmed and televised trials.

Pepper's Condition Is Stable
LEAD: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, remained in ''serious but stable'' condition at Walter Reed Army Hospital today, his press secretary said.
The aide, Rochelle Jones, said there had been no change in the condition of the 88-year-old lawmaker, who is suffering from a stomach ailment of undisclosed nature.

LEAD: High over the snow-capped mountains of the Hindu Kush, First Pilot Viktor D. Ignatov laid aside the Soviet newspaper account of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to China that he had been reading and began punching the red, green and yellow buttons to take his aircraft out of autopilot.

For Anti-Drug Boot Camps
LEAD: One solution to the drug scourge in our cities is readily available.
Military bases that are scheduled for closing or partial deactivation could be quickly and economically turned into ''boot camps'' to treat and discipline first-time drug offenders and to punish repeat offenders.

It seemed a typical college picnic.

Education; Panel Says Blacks Are Taught Poorly
LEAD: Blacks in public schools remain ''largely isolated'' and receive an inferior education, despite Federal and state efforts to provide equal opportunities in the 35 years since the Supreme Court ordered the end of segregated schools, a panel of prominent black scholars asserted in a report issued today.

LEAD: Phil Simms of the Giants wants to join 15 other National Football League quarterbacks with annual salaries of $1 million or more.
So he boycotted the opening day of the Giants' minicamp today, and his agent, David Fishof, said Simms would also stay away from training camp two months from now unless his contract was extended.

The Equipment: A Grill, a Basket and a Spatula
LEAD: COOKWARE shops and catalogues are showing specialized equipment for grilling seafood.
Among the newer items is the Griffo-grill, a perforated metal plate that sits directly on the grid of a barbecue and prevents small pieces of food from falling through the grill.
It also makes it easier to turn delicate fillets or cumbersome whole fish and reduces sticking.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
British Petroleum Co., London, has announced a public offering in the U.S. of eight million units of beneficial interest in the BP Prudhoe Bay Royalty Trust at $26 each through First Boston Corp.
The offering is part of an issue of 21.4 million trust units, 13.4 million of which were sold to institutional investors in a private placement for a total of $334 million.


Beretta U.S.A. Contract
LEAD: The Army said on Monday that Beretta U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Italian arms maker Fabbrica d'Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A., would continue suppling 9-millimeter handguns to the military.
Although the Beretta unit beat out seven competitiors in 1985 to replace the Army's old Colt .45 pistols, Congress in 1987 ordered a new competition to make sure American companies received a fair judgment.

LEAD: MANY of Alois Lageder's wine labels, like those of other winegrowers in Italy's northernmost region, Trentino-Alto Adige, are printed in two languages: Italian and German.
More importantly, Mr.
Lageder said last week, his whites made from classic international grapes - pinot grigio, pinot bianco, sauvignon, chardonnay - speak everyone's language, especially in warm weather.

LEAD: THE restaurant business in New York City is undergoing its worst setback in recent history, according to restaurateurs, restaurant consultants, food suppliers and others.

LEAD: On looks alone, the New York City Ballet's beautiful second-act production of ''Swan Lake'' is a triumph, with its glistening canopy of icicles and its distant rock and ice cliffs, their sheer slopes crowned forebodingly by what might be palaces.

Metro Datelines; 3 Arrested in Pelting Of Cars and Officer

The Urgent Search for a Chancellor
LEAD: Following the sudden death of Schools Chancellor Richard Green two weeks ago, New York City's Board of Education has wisely begun an immediate search for his successor.
Whatever the uncertainties created by the mayoral campaign, the need is urgent for strong leadership of the city's troubled school system.


Hong Kong Stocks Rebound
LEAD: Hong Kong's jittery stock market, reacting to rumors from Beijing that Prime Minister Li Peng might step down, rebounded today for its largest one-day gain since the exchange was reconstituted in 1986.
The market tumbled 339.06 points on Monday, a fall of 10.8 percent.
But the colony's Hang Seng index shot back today to gain 261.08 points, to 3,067.65, the largest single-day gain since the stock exchange was created from four smaller markets three years ago, brokers said.


Dollar Turns Mixed in U.S.; Pound at a 22-Month Low
LEAD: The soaring dollar turned mixed yesterday as dealers cashed in profits from its recent strength and speculated on what the United States and its trading partners might do next to stabilize currency rates.

LEAD: The Soviet Union moved substantially closer today to the Western position on cutting conventional arms in Europe, Western officials said.

LEAD: O. Rundle Gilbert, an auctioneer and appraiser, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Waitsfield, Vt.
He was 83 years old.


McEnroe Withdraws
LEAD: John McEnroe, who was seeded sixth in the $4.5 million French Open, the second Grand Slam event of 1989, has been forced to withdraw because of back pains.
McEnroe was injured recently in an exhibition in the Netherlands and withdrew from the Italian Open.
He has won tournaments this year in Lyon, France, and Dallas.(


Empty Theaters Bringing Concerts to Broadway
LEAD: Bemoaning a ''lack of product,'' and with six of its nine usable Broadway houses either dark or not presenting theatrical attractions, the Nederlander organization, the second largest theater owner on Broadway, is preparing a series of concerts to fill its huge 1,933-seat Gershwin Theater in the fall.

LEAD: At the New School for Social Research's 53d commencement yesterday there was an empty chair on the dais for Jiri Hajek, a former Czechoslovak Foreign Minister who school officials said was denied permission to leave Czechoslovakia to receive an honorary degree.

Final Countdown for a Basketball Hero
LEAD: Late spring is never the best season in Los Angeles.
Early morning and evening fogs often cloud the mood, leaving but a hole of sunshine in the middle.
This season is worse: it's Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's last with the Los Angeles Lakers.
Everybody here knows it and feels it, even those who aren't strictly fans or part of that Hollywood courtside coterie featuring the likes of Jack Nicholson and Dyan Cannon who have routinely graced the Lakers games with their glitz.

Review/Music; Familiar Sonatas, Intensely
LEAD: Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg is a performer who understands the importance of rhythmic energy and a sense of direction.
Her bristling intensity informed and carried each of the three familiar sonatas she played with Robert McDonald Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y. But there came a point rather early in each piece when one began to wish for some of the other possible virtues of music making (and of violin playing), and then it was a matter of long waits and meager rewards.

Seafood: Right at Home On the Barbecue
LEAD: WHEN backyard cooks fire up the grill for the first time this season, the sizzling steak is likely to be swordfish, not sirloin.
Since people are eating more fish these days, according to food-industry statistics, it is only natural that it will be on the menu for summer cookouts.
And once a dish has become popular in restaurants, as grilled fish has, it is bound to tempt the home cook, too.

Environment Is Security
LEAD: Students at Copenhagen University, like most young people across Western Europe, have written off the defense issue.
They want to get on with talk about the future.
Some put it as shifting from East-West to North-South problems.
Others, more appropriately, see it as facing the longer-term global threat to the environment as the threat of nuclear war seems to have receded.

Dance Equivalent to Shakespeare's Words
LEAD: The Montagues and the Capulets did battle once more, this time on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in the American Ballet Theater production of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's sumptuous ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Swords clanged, bodies flew and three rather innocent harlots worked the crowd.
And then there were the lovers, magnificently danced and acted by Alessandra Ferri and Ricardo Bustamante.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, won permission from a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday to acquire the Eastern Airlines shuttle for $365 million, culminating a deal he made with the airline last October before it was virtually grounded by a strike.

LEAD: At that singular time of morning when the moon and the rising sun share the sky, six people gathered in Central Park to count birds.

For the Windowsill, A Little Landscape
LEAD: THEY do not rank among the world's great landscapes, but window boxes do bring color to barren streets, spirit to lifeless buildings and pleasure to those who tend them.
All this in less than 30 inches - and they are not even a modern invention.
As long ago as first-century Rome, Pliny the Elder wrote of villas with blossom-filled windowsills where ''every day the eyes might feast on this copy of a garden as though it were a work of nature.

LEAD: THE latest McDonald's restaurants to open in Manhattan have a more sophisticated look than the roadside stands that have dotted the landscape for two decades.

LEAD: As West Germany marked its 40th anniversary today, it was assured by its President that it may not be a ''great power'' but that it would not be a plaything for anyone.

Inland said Mr.
Simmons sought permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department to buy more than $15 million worth of its stock.

LEAD: A father in Brooklyn was arrested Tuesday and charged with murder after his infant daughter died from skull fractures, the police said.

LEAD: Even though Congress feels burdened by the Federal deficit, it has been unwilling to cede the power of the purse to the President.

But there is a better way to cut spending.

LEAD: Two brothers in their 60's who kept police at bay for seven hours died early Tuesday in a fire that was apparently started by firebombs they were throwing out of their house at the officers, the authorities said.

LEAD: Amid shrieks of joy from members of the selection task force, Minneapolis today was named the host city and the Metrodome the site of Super Bowl XXVI in 1992.


Horton Journal; Seeing a Prison Project As Economic Freedom
LEAD: Not everybody wants a prison in his backyard, but people here are so eager for one that they have refused to take no for an answer.
When Horton lost out recently as a possible site for a new state penitentiary, the town decided to build a prison of its own.


Sirhan Denied Parole In Slaying of Kennedy
LEAD: Sirhan Sirhan, serving life in prison for assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has been denied parole for the 10th time despite his saying he felt ''very remorseful'' about the slaying.
