State Dept. Aide Accused of Misleading Panel
LEAD: The chairman of an influential House subcommittee today accused a State Department official of misleading the panel on whether the Reagan Administration made a secret deal with Honduras in 1985 to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.


Hudson Bass Survived Shoreline Expansions
LEAD: To the Editor:


Treasury Notes and Bonds Slip
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in advance of an auction of $8.75 billion worth of two-year Treasury notes.


Review/Opera; Alternate Principals For 'Atys'
LEAD: The star of Lully's ''Atys,'' the path-breaking Paris Opera production that has just visited the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is its conductor, William Christie, whose vision is responsible both for the restoration of Lully's reputation as a composer of worth and for the formation of the extraordinary Arts Florissants ensemble that has been able to demonstrate that worth.


SCIENTISTS DISPUTE FINDINGS ON FUSION
LEAD: Several teams of scientists said at a conference today that their experiments on low-temperature nuclear fusion had produced a few neutrons, suggesting that something curious was going on but nothing that would revolutionize the world's production of energy.


Company News; Vehicle Sales Rose by 2.7% In Mid-May
LEAD: Mid-May sales of domestic cars and light trucks were up 2.7 percent from the comparable period last year, but analysts said they were still weak enough to raise fears that the industry might have to cut its production plans.


Reviews/Music; New Violin Sonata in Recital
LEAD: The centerpiece of Maria Bachmann's violin recital Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall was the New York premiere of George Rochberg's Sonata (1988).
The Rochberg influence even went so far as to encompass the other long work of the night, the Brahms Sonata No. 1 in G (Op. 78), which Mr.
Rochberg selected to complement his own score.


Stopping the Killers
LEAD: If Americans can agree on anything in foreign policy, it is that the Khmer Rouge should never be allowed back into power in Cambodia.
When its fanatics ruled the country, from 1975 through 1978, they murdered about one million people, a seventh of the population.


Safety Board Assails Air Traffic Control South of Los Angeles
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board, in a report documenting serious lapses in the air traffic control system in Southern California, has criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for ''inadequate, ineffective and unresponsive'' management.


A Cipher for Civil Rights?
LEAD: The nomination of William Lucas as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights has split the civil rights movement in an odd way.
The disagreement isn't over his views; he hasn't compiled much of a record.
It's between those who are deeply offended by the choice of a civil rights nonentity and those who are willing to settle for one.


Fire Raging in Everglades
LEAD: Firefighters from as far away as California today battled a fire that has scorched more than 75,000 acres of the Everglades.
The smoke caused a haze over much of the Miami metropolitan area.
The fire is centered in Everglades National Park about 30 miles from downtown Miami.
Lightning started it May 16.


TRITIUM ESTIMATES CALLED OPTIMISTIC
LEAD: Congressional investigators told the House Armed Services Committee today that it will take longer than previously believed to build and operate two new plants to produce tritium, a vital component in nuclear weapons.


Talking Deals; Ross's Rich Pact At Time-Warner
LEAD: MUCH has been made of the estimated $120 million in salary, bonus and long-term compensation that Steven J. Ross, the flamboyant chief executive of Warner Communications Inc., stands to gain over the next 10 years after his company merges with Time Inc.
But it is only upon a closer reading of his 80-odd page employment contract that the full potency of his arrangement becomes clear.


Kennedy Assassination Relic Is Given to Exhibit in Dallas
LEAD: The movie theater seat in which Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested has been donated to an exhibit at the former Texas School Book Depository.

LEAD: Two leading figures in the contemporary crafts movement are showing their work at the Twining Gallery at 568 Broadway, near Prince Street.


Bill Offered to Restrict Raises for Legislators
LEAD: The Legislature's ability to vote on its pay raises after re-election but before a new term would be prohibited under a bill introduced today.

LEAD: The Nassau County police are cracking down on stores that sell laughing gas to minors, County Executive Thomas Gulotta said today.

LEAD: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Foundation has announced that it will move its offices and studio facilities to new headquarters at 211 West 61st Street in the fall.
Mr.
Ailey estimated a cost of $1.5 million to relocate from the company's home of 10 years, the Minskoff Building at 1515 Broadway, which did not renew the Ailey lease.

LEAD: William J. Hampton, a longtime aide to the late Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and a housing developer, died of cancer of the colon and liver Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 70 years old and lived in Corona, Queens.

LEAD: Spurred by still more takeover rumors, Time Inc. stock jumped $5.50 a share yesterday, closing at a record $130.75, as 1.2 million shares changed hands.
One big factor prompting the increase was a rumor that Allen &amp; Company, the investment banker that represents the Coca-Cola Company, had put Time Inc.


Market Place; Behind Pessimism Over 'Junk Bonds'
LEAD: WHILE the stock market looks for an economic soft landing, recession fears seem to be lingering in the ''junk bond'' market, where yields remain stubbornly high.
That is leading some junk bond managers to grow more bullish, hoping that junk bond prices will rise as investors get more optimistic about the economy.


What East-West Policy?
LEAD: President Bush yesterday delivered his fourth, final, flat and flimsy speech on East-West relations.
What explains the chasm between this vacuity and the substantial ability and experience of Mr.
Bush and his senior advisers?


Robert E. Heathcote, Manufacturer, 72
LEAD: Robert E. Heathcote, a retired manufacturer, died Monday at his home in Sebastian, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 72 years old.


Solidarity Says Warsaw Is Playing Campaign Tricks
LEAD: Solidarity accused the Communist authorities today of using dirty tricks to upset its election campaign and of seeking to drive a wedge between the newly legalized union and its most ardent supporters.


China Again Cuts Off TV News Transmission
LEAD: In their second reversal in as many days, Chinese officials yesterday abruptly halted the transmission of foreign television news reports from Beijing.
They also barred foreign broadcasters from recording and transmitting news reports by China's state-run network.


'Ubu' Is Postponed
LEAD: The Lincoln Center Theater production of ''Ubu,'' which was to have begun preview performances on Tuesday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, has been postponed to next Tuesday.
A spokesman for the theater said the delay was caused by difficulty in smoothing out the show's 34 scene changes.
The official opening has been postponed from June 15 to June 25.


MOSCOW SUPPORTS U.S. ON TROOP CUTS
LEAD: Moscow has embraced the basic framework of the Western position for cutting conventional arms in Europe even as the two sides remain far apart on the separate issue of short-range nuclear missiles, Administration officials said today.


A Judge Delays Suffolk's Limits On Plastic Use
LEAD: A Suffolk County law banning plastic grocery bags and many plastic containers cannot take effect until Suffolk officials conduct a thorough environmental impact study, a State Supreme Court justice ruled today The law, which was to take effect July 1, would prohibit fast-food restaurants and other retail establishments from using plastic-foam coffee cups, plastic utensils and the foam ''clamshells'' used to package hamburgers.


Pretoria and U.N. in New Dispute Over Namibia
LEAD: A new dispute has erupted between the United Nations and South Africa over the organization's troubled Namibian independence plan.

LEAD: To the Editor:


MILITARY GAS USED IN SOVIET GEORGIA
LEAD: A toxic tear gas used as a chemical weapon in World War I was used on demonstrators in Soviet Georgia last month, according to a report by three American doctors who just returned from a visit to the republic.
The Soviet military has never acknowledged using the gas, chloropicrin.

The 'Smoke-Free Class of 2000' Is Off to a Fast Start


New Polish Devaluation
LEAD: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, by 6.25 percent Monday, the seventh devaluation this year, according to rates published by the Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu.
The new official rate, which applies to tourists and foreign trade dealings, was quoted as 800 zloties to the dollar, compared with 750 on Friday.


Former Union Chief Assails Giamatti Inquiry
LEAD: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti's investigation of Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, drew verbal fire yesterday from Marvin Miller, the retired executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, who believes that one of his foremost accomplishments was setting up a grievance procedure for players.

LEAD: As an intense power struggle continued behind the walled compound that houses the Communist Party headquarters, there were signs that the hard-line faction of Prime Minister Li Peng may have gained army support and consolidated control over the news media.


Aetna Resumes California Role
LEAD: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which had stopped writing new property and casualty insurance policies in California to protest restrictions on insurance rates, said today that it would resume accepting new business in the state.

Sniper Suspect Ruled Mentally Competent
LEAD: A man who believes he is a Rambo-like commando is mentally competent to stand trial for the Long Island sniper shootings that killed one man and injured three others, a judge ruled yesterday.


Finance/New Issues; Northern Telecom
LEAD: Northern Telecom Ltd. offered $200 million of five-year notes through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, will mature on June 2, 1994.
It carries a 9 1/4 percent coupon and was priced at $100, or 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.


Libraries Reach the Youngest Audience
LEAD: SANDRA TORRES, who just turned 2 years old, went to her local public library the other morning.

Upheaval in China; 7 on New York Chinese Newspaper Quit in Protest
LEAD: Half the editorial staff of a New York-based Chinese newspaper quit in anger yesterday after the publisher demanded that they print a commentary he wrote urging China's leaders to call in troops to keep order in Beijing.


Finance/New Isues; First Nationwide
LEAD: First Nationwide Bank priced a $100 million offering of three-year notes.
The notes, which will mature June 1, 1992, carry a 9 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at $100, or 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting.

LEAD: THE four cars were scattered around the huge room in Stouffer's Westchester Hotel, each in a shade of maroon, each from a different manufacturer.
People opened and shut doors, climbed in, peered at this, touched that.
They checked head room and driving position.
They marked their clipboards.

LEAD: In a case that may lead to challenges in hundreds of criminal cases around the nation, expert witnesses for a defendant accused of murder in the Bronx have contested the validity of sophisticated genetic testing used to identify suspects.

OPEC Shift Is Urged
LEAD: The president of OPEC said in an interview published today that an increase in the organization's output is needed if members want a price of about $18 a barrel through 1989.
In an interview published in the Saudi Arabian weekly magazine Al Yamamah, Rilwanu Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, said that OPEC should have a ''moving ceiling'' on production that it can raise or lower to maintain price levels.

LEAD: After a year of study, the University of California at Berkeley announced plans yesterday to substantially change the university's overall admissions policies.

LEAD: The Nepalese Government, digging in for a long siege in a trade war with India that is being seen here as a test of Nepalese sovereignty, has introduced austerity measures and started reordering its development plans, officials here say.

Policxe in Brazil Recover 10 Stolen Paintings
LEAD: Ten paintings stolen from the small Chacara do Ceu museum here on May 3, including works by Dali and Matlisse, have been recovered, the police have said.

LEAD: ''All the students in my year face the same problem.
Our main task as students is to study, and we know that when we leave the university, we must earn a living based on what we have learned here.

Company News; ITT to Cut Rates
LEAD: International telephone rates to 27 countries will drop by as much as 9 percent on June 1, ITT Communications Services Inc. said.
The reductions will apply to the first minute of calls during the standard daytime period, which covers the hours of business for the country being called.
Calls from the continental United States will fall 9 percent for the first minute to some nations, while those to other countries will drop 8 percent, 7 percent or 6 percent.

Company News; Prime Computer Jumps on Listing
LEAD: The price of Prime Computer Inc.'s stock jumped $1 a share yesterday, to $16.375, after Wall Street sources said the company had been added to the restricted list of Oppenheimer &amp; Company, suggesting that the investment banking firm might have found a buyer for the company.
An addition means Oppenheimer's sales representatives cannot solicit orders in a company's stock and employees are not allowed to buy it.

Lithuania Declares A Moscow Tax Law To Be Non-Binding
LEAD: Lithuania has became the first Soviet republic to defy Moscow's taxing authority, announcing today in official newspapers that Lithuanians will not be obliged to pay a new nationwide highway tax.


Bat Thrower Suspended
LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds suspended the reliever Rob Dibble for two days yesterday for throwing a bat against the home-plate screen after yielding a run-scoring single to Terry Pendleton of the Cardinals Tuesday.
Dibble, 25 years old, was ejected from the game and faces a minimum fine of $200 from the National League.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Book That Supports Case for Brand Loyalty
LEAD: Browsing through an advertising library two years ago, David N. Martin came across a rare book listing the dominant brand names in 1923.
Most of the names had a familiar ring -Ivory, Gold Medal, Kellogg's Cornflakes, Heinz and Del Monte among them.
Mr.
Martin, an advertising executive, realized that a roster of dominant brand names today would virtually duplicate the 66-year-old list.

LEAD: The former football star O. J. Simpson must pay $700, perform 120 hours of community service and continue psychiatric counseling following his plea of no contest to a charge that he beat his wife, Nicole, a municipal judge in Los Angeles ruled yesterday.

Eugene T. Ferraro, 76, Ex-Air Force Official
LEAD: Eugene T. Ferraro, an educator, executive and a former deputy undersecretary of the Air Force, died Sunday at the Boulevard Manor Nursing Home in Boynton Beach, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 76 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.


Company News; Revised Plan For Hillhaven
LEAD: National Medical Enterprises Inc. said today that it had revised its plan to spin off the Hillhaven Corporation, a long-term care unit.
Under the revamped arrangement, the company will retain ownership in 50 percent of the nursing homes owned by Hillhaven, rather than divesting itself of all of them.


Personal Health
LEAD: Some people, like the singers Johnny Cash and Rod Stewart, make millions on their scratchy or gravelly voices.
For others, like basketball coaches, political campaigners and cheerleaders, hoarseness is an occupational hazard that might be taken as a sign of a job well done.


Company News; Nestle Unit Stake In Culinary Brands
LEAD: Nestle Enterprises Inc. has bought a minority stake in Culinary Brands Inc., a small company based in Sausalito, Calif., that makes gourmet meals packed in vacuum pouches.
Carl H. Randall, the president of the private Culinary Brands, said the investment totaled about $20 million.


Poland Acknowledges Soviet-Nazi Pact on Its Fate
LEAD: Poland took a further step toward candor in its treatment of Polish-Soviet history today when the Communist Party daily published an official report contending that the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany split Poland between themselves in 1939 under the terms of a secret agreement.


Results Plus
LEAD:  TENNIS  Loss Cools Evert to French Open: Chris Evert said yesterday that she may forgo the French Open next week and not finish the circuit this year after an unseeded opponent beat her in the second round of the Geneva European Open. ''I'm not in the right frame of mind for Paris,'' the top-seeded Evert said after losing, 6-4, 6-1, to Barbara Paulus of Austria.


Money Fund Yields Down
LEAD: Yields for money market mutual funds eased in the week ended yesterday, mirroring the general trend in interest rates, with yields on longer certificates of deposits falling to the lowest levels since February 1988.

Georgi Tovstonogov, 75, a Soviet Producer
LEAD: Georgi Tovstonogov, one of the best-known theatrical producers in the Soviet Union, died Wednesday in Leningrad, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.
He was 75 years old.
Leningrad television said he died in a car accident.
Mr.
Tovstonogov was chief producer at the Maxim Gorky Bolshoi Drama Theater in Leningrad.

LEAD: Zubin Mehta will lead the New York Philharmonic in ''Ein Heldenleben'' by Richard Strauss and Wagner's ''Rienzi'' Overture and the Act I Prelude and ''Good Friday Spell'' from his ''Parsifal,'' tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall.
The program is to be repeated tomorrow evening at 8.
Tickets are $40 to $7.50.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  FLORAL ART  The main branch of the New York Public Library is always a garden of delights, but during the next three months the venerable institution will be abloom with more than 150 historic botanical illustrations.
The show, ''Nature's Mirror,'' includes watercolors, drawings and illustrated books by such botanical artists of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries as Pierre-Joseph Redoute and Robert Thornton.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $126.50 million, to $312.07 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 142 institutional funds increased by $273.40 million, to $79.41 billion.
The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were down by $192.60 million, to $101.23 billion.

California Court Widens Limit on Employee Suits
LEAD: In another California court victory for employers, the state's Supreme Court today made retroactive an earlier decision that restricts the right of people dismissed from jobs to sue their former employers for damages.

LEAD: Navy officials are investigating two cracks in the outer steel hull of a nuclear submarine under construction at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn., officials said today.

A. A. Schechter, 81, And Wife Die in Crash
LEAD: A. A. (Abe) Schechter, the first news director for NBC-TV and the first executive producer of the ''Today'' show, and his wife, Fritzi, died Wednesday in a car accident.
He was 81 years old, and she was 82.
They were residents of Palm Beach, Fla., and Westhampton, L.I.


Milan Wins Soccer Cup
LEAD: A. C. Milan's 4-0 victory over Steaua Bucharest in the European Champions' Cup soccer final Wednesday night was nearly as lopsided on the field as the Italian vocal victory in the stands.


Youth Symphony
LEAD: Samuel Wong will lead the New York Youth Symphony in its final concert of the season - Mr.
Wong's first as the orchestra's music director - at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.
The program includes Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' Overture; the world premiere of Mark Gustavson's ''Waves,'' a work commissioned by the orchestra; Richard Strauss's ''Death and Transfiguration,'' and the Prokofiev Violin Concerto No.

LEAD: The Bastille Opera opened its doors today for the first time to permit Pierre Berge, the czar of all the capital's opera houses, to introduce his bold choice as its music director: a non-French-speaking, 35-year-old South Korean-born American.

LEAD: By many standards, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of Yale University, should be collecting high praise these days.
He skillfully captained the university's finances through troubled times.
He negotiated two major labor accords without strikes.
He improved relations with New Haven.

Leonard Horton, 83; Led a Securities Firm
LEAD: Leonard M. Horton, a former president and chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston &amp; Company, a dealer in Treasury securities, died on Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement.

Kwangju Journal; A Splash in the Dark, Then a Martyr
LEAD: A late-night police chase in the woods outside town.
A splash in the dark heard by some, but not others, at a nearby reservoir.
A body washed up days later with a wad of cash.


Eastwood As a Tracker In 'Pink Cadillac'
When it's time to look back on the strange sweep of Clint Eastwood's career, from his ambitious direction of ''Bird'' to his coarse, classic Dirty Harry character, ''Pink Cadillac'' will probably settle comfortably near the bottom of the list.
It is the laziest sort of action comedy, with lumbering chase scenes, a dull-witted script and the charmless pairing of Mr.
Eastwood and Bernadette Peters.
Ms.
Peters plays Lou Ann, the innocent wife of an ex-convict who belongs to a well-armed white supremacist group called the Birthright.
When the group's cache of counterfeit money is found in her trailer, Lou Ann is arrested.
Leaving her baby daughter with her sister, she gets in her husband's old pink Cadillac - which happens to be so full of hidden money that bills eventually fly out onto the highway - and jumps bail.


Beverly O'Malley, 48, Advertising Executive
LEAD: Beverly Black O'Malley, a senior vice president of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Advertising, died of liver cancer Wednesday at her home in Darien, Conn.
She was 48 years old.


Charge Dropped In Case of Baby Left in Restroom
LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday dropped charges against the teen-age mother who left her 2-year-old daughter in a hospital restroom last week with a note saying she could no longer ''handle the pressure'' of raising the child.

Lin Broadcasting Plans TV Spinoff
LEAD: Fast-growing cellular telephone properties have become so valuable that they have begun to overshadow the other businesses of the media companies that own them.
So, Lin Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it would split into two independent companies so it could concentrate on its cellular phone business.

Reviews/Art; Collages That Seek to Fuse Beauty and Feminism
LEAD: Nancy Spero's exhibition at the New Museum of Contemporary Art is not as extensive as this artist deserves, but for the time being it will do quite well.
The show originated at the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse and is now making the final stop on a six-museum tour.
It looks good at the New Museum - no mean feat considering the tall, narrow galleries - and a second phase, opening June 14, will rotate in additional works.


Review/Art; Elegant Bad Boy of France's Establishment
LEAD: From the moment he took up art at the relatively advanced age of 42, Jean Dubuffet was among the most articulate and tireless opponents of the art establishment and of everything for which it stood.
In place of experience he favored forgetfulness; in place of the studied and elegant, he favored the wild and brutish.


NIEMAN'S CURATOR LEAVING PROGRAM
LEAD: Howard Simons stepped down yesterday as curator of the Nieman Foundation, which since 1938 has brought journalists in midcareer to Harvard University for a year of study and reflection.

U.S. CITES JAPAN, INDIA AND BRAZIL AS UNFAIR TRADERS
LEAD: Taking strong action on an issue that has divided his Cabinet and threatens new trade friction, President Bush today named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to special negotiations and possible sanctions if their import barriers are not lowered.
The decision incensed the foreign governments.

LEAD: For fans of live music, a long holiday weekend means one thing: Sunday night becomes Saturday Night II, when enjoying a late set doesn't mean a bleary work day.

Review/Theater; Shakespearean Comedy, From the Acting Company
LEAD: In Paul Giovanni's production for the Acting Company, ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' that most literate of Shakespearean comedies, has been turned into a tedious exercise in artifice.
The poetry is sacrificed along with the impetuousness of the romance, which should proceed magically, four by four - the King of Navarre and the Princess of France, each accompanied by a trio of followers who conveniently fall in love with one another.


Familiarity May Decide New Jersey Vote

Bethlehem Steel Accord
LEAD: Officials of the United Steelworkers of America said today that union employees of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had voted to ratify a new contract with the company.
A union spokesman said its Bethlehem members voted 11,386 to 3,009 to ratify the 50-month pact, which will take effect June 1.
The agreement restores wages immediately to their 1982 level and includes wage increases starting in 1991.


CUNY Graduate School
LEAD: Three weeks after protesting students chained shut its only building, the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York celebrated its 25th commencement yesterday at Town Hall in midtown Manhattan.

Anti-Mob Panel Established
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo issued an executive order today meant to help state agencies avoid doing business with contractors linked to organized crime.
The order establishes a Council of Contracting Agencies, which will serve as a clearinghouse for information about contractors.
The order comes after reports that in the last four years, the state paid $12.5 million to 22 companies with ties to organized-crime figures.

The Law: At the Bar; A pioneer in personal-injury advertising still finds himself on the cutting edge.
LEAD: In the first, heady days of legalized advertising by lawyers, Philip Damashek was the king of the New York classifieds - and the crown prince and regent, too.
While others hesitated to hawk themselves a decade ago, whether out of taste or timidity or frugality, Mr.
Damashek went unabashedly ahead.


G.N.P. Rate Cut to 4.3% In Quarter
LEAD: The economy grew in the first quarter at a pace considerably slower than initially estimated, the Commerce Department said today.
But the Administration and economists alike viewed the slower growth rate as generally encouraging.


Pippen, Walker Fined
LEAD: Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls was fined $3,000 and Kenny Walker of the Knicks $1,500 for their parts in a fight during the sixth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series on May 19 in Chicago.
The fight occurred late in the third quarter of the Bulls' 113-111 victory, which eliminated the Knicks.

An Arena of Stars Burns
LEAD: Fire has destroyed the Pan Pacific Auditorium, the streamlined Art Deco arena where Elvis Presley made his West Coast debut in the 1950's and Sonja Henie skated in the 1930's.
The fire broke out Wednesday evening.
The building was abandoned and had been sealed, the authorities said.
The building was featured in the film ''Miracle Mile.

LEAD: In a decision that will fundamentally alter the structure of the nation's options markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to allow options on exchange-listed securities to be traded on more than one exchange.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a protest at a New York-based Chinese newspaper, The Center Daily, referred incorrectly to the publisher's daughter, Candace Fu.
Although she has an office at the newspaper's building in Long Island City, she says she does not work for the paper.
In some copies, the article and a caption incompletely described the status of some of those involved in the protest.


Post Editor May Leave
LEAD: Jane Amsterdam is on the verge of leaving her job as editor of The New York Post, people at the newspaper said yesterday.
Ms.
Amsterdam and Peter S. Kalikow, owner and publisher of The Post, discussed ''an imminent parting of the ways'' in a meeting late yesterday, said a person close to the situation who asked not to be identified.


Moscow Offers To Narrow Gap On Troop Cuts
LEAD: Moscow made another proposal today in the Vienna talks on cutting conventional forces in Europe that further narrows the differences between the West and the Soviet bloc, Western officials said.


From Spain, in Martha Graham's Footsteps
LEAD: There will be dancing this weekend at Casa de Espana, the handsome, intimate cultural center run by the Spanish Government at 314 East 39th Street (689-4232).
But there won't be a castenet or zapateado in sight.
Instead, seven modern-dance choreographers from Spain will show their work in free programs tonight and tomorrow at 8:30.

He was 83 years old and lived in Clifton, N.J.

Behind the Surge Of the Dollar
LEAD: THE strength of the dollar has surprised economists and raised fears that the United States trade deficit will worsen this year and next.
And it may breed protectionism, inflation abroad and a global slump.


Anti-Takeover Law Is Upheld
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the constitutionality of Wisconsin's anti-takeover law, providing a victory for the Universal Foods Corporation in its fight against a hostile acquisition bid.
Lawyers were notified


Topics of The Times; Family Values
LEAD: New York City's Family Court grapples with some of society's toughest social issues: child abuse, domestic violence, juvenile delinquency and foster care placements.
Yet its dilapidated courthouses hardly inspire confidence.
A new study by the Fund for Modern Courts, a watchdog group, documents the sorry state of Family Court facilities in each of the five boroughs.

LEAD: ''Pattes Blanches,'' a stormy romantic melodrama filmed in 1949 by the French director Jean Gremillon, takes its title from the contemptuous nickname - translated as ''white spats'' but meaning, literally, ''white paws'' - that the children in a Breton village fling at a local, down-at-the-heels aristocrat named Keriadec.

LEAD: Top business economists predicted today that the United States economy is headed for a ''soft landing'' this year in which growth slows enough to tame inflation and interest rates without toppling the country into a recession.

Petro-Canada Issue
LEAD: Petro-Canada offered $200 million of 30-year debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The issue has a ''put'' on the bonds during the 15th year at par, or $100.
The debentures carry a coupon of 8.8 percent and were priced at par, 13 basis points over the prevailing yield on 10-year Treasury securities at the time of pricing.

Dutch Anti-Pollution Plan
LEAD: The Government made public an ambitious plan today to clean up the Dutch environment by the year 2010, but it said 80 percent of the nation's forests may die even if the measures are put into effect.
The anti-pollution measures are likely to be a major issue in elections scheduled for September.
Controversy surrounding them brought down the Government headed by Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers.

Reviews/Art; Stabiles by Calder, Architect of Fun, at Pace
LEAD: Alexander Calder was in many ways an ideal mix of homo faber and homo ludens.
As homo faber - builder, engineer, master of stress and strain - he carried on as if he could have built the Brooklyn Bridge single-handed, had he been around at the time.
As homo ludens - humorist, prankster and inventor of strange creatures - he was in a class of his own.

Review/Film; An Homage to a Film Maker, Made in His Own Medium
LEAD: ''Directed by Andrei Tarkovsky'' is a loving memoir about the making of the Soviet expatriate director's last film, ''The Sacrifice.'' It will be shown with ''The Sacrifice'' at the Public Theater beginning today.
The documentary may be unintelligible to anyone who has not seen ''The Sacrifice'' and unilluminating to anyone who has, but it provides a wonderful excuse to see Tarkovsky's eloquent, lyrical, magnificent final film once more.

LEAD: The United States trade deficit improved sharply in the first three months of the year, narrowing to $27.6 billion, the smallest quarterly imbalance in four years.

LEAD: President Mengistu Haile Mariam has named new armed forces commanders to replace those killed last week in an abortive coup, the Government radio announced.

Salads can be stretched by adding diced vegetables, cucumbers, celery, peppers and tomatoes.

LEAD: The students in Beijing appear to have lost to the aging Deng Xiaoping and his colorless, hard-line protege, Prime Minister Li Peng.

Deng departs and a new leadership emerges.


Brazil Cites Large Debt In Its Defense on Trade
LEAD: Responding to American accusations of unfair trade practices, Brazilian officials said today that import barriers allowed the nation to build up a surplus that in turn helped it to make payments on its large foreign debt.

LEAD: Following a script as stylized and deliberate as Noh drama, the Administration has accused Japan of unfairly restricting imports of three major American products - and cited Brazil and India for three other offenses.

LEAD: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday discussed lawyers' use of advertising, legalized 10 years ago.
Describing the use of newspaper ads by some kinds of law firms, it said: ''One will never see Sullivan &amp; Cromwell alongside the bartending schools or high school equivalency courses.
Most are personal-injury firms, whose names, like Longi &amp; Loscalzo or Gersowitz &amp; Libo, seem lifted from the log at Ellis Island rather than the pages of Martindale-Hubbell.

Dollar In Rebound After Drop
LEAD: The dollar rebounded yesterday to close around Thursday's levels after dropping sharply in the morning in the face of a concerted round of central bank intervention.


India Tractor Wreck Kills 13
LEAD: A farm tractor pulling a wagon loaded with wedding guests fell into a canal today, killing 13 people, a news report said.
About 30 people were riding on the tractor or in the wagon near West Godavari, about 825 miles southeast of New Delhi, the United News of India said.
Among the dead were three children.


Substances Can Mask Steroids, Doctor Says
LEAD: Ben Johnson's personal physician today named eight substances that athletes are using routinely to hide the presence of anabolic steroids in their systems.
A leading American expert in sports medicine said that current technology may not be sophisticated enough for laboratories to detect two of them.

LEAD: Peter S. Kalikow, owner and publisher of The New York Post, dismissed his top editor, Jane Amsterdam, in a meeting late Thursday afternoon, persons close to each of them, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday.

LEAD: Jon Peters, who set the national high school record of 51 consecutive victories last month, lost his first game as a scholastic pitcher Thursday night when West Orange-Stark of Texas beat Brenham, 3-0, on a no-hitter.


Big Cable Merger
LEAD: Stockholders and directors of United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation approved the merger of the two companies to form the United Artists Entertainment Company.
The merger makes United Artists Entertainment the nation's third-largest operator of cable television systems and the largest motion-picture theater operator.


BUSH IS EXPECTED TO END SANCTIONS AGAINST MOSCOW
LEAD: In a gesture both to American allies and to Moscow, President Bush is expected to act next week to remove the remaining economic sanctions imposed on the Soviet Union after its military intervention in Afghanistan 10 years ago, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Kazuko Takatsukasa, the elder sister of Emperor Akihito, died of heart failure at a Tokyo hospital early today, Imperial Palace officials said.
She was 59 years old.
Mrs.
Takatsukasa was the third daughter of the late Emperor Hirohito, Japan's longest-reigning monarch, who died on Jan. 7.

LEAD: Clearing the way to create the world's largest media company, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved the $18 billion merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.
It was the final regulatory hurdle to the transaction.

LEAD: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun to reassign the extra border patrol agents who were sent to Brownsville, Tex., in February to stem a surge of illegal aliens.

LEAD: A mother who abandoned her newborn daughter in a jetliner's restroom before a cross-country flight has pleaded no contest to charges of child endangerment.

LEAD: As the Philippines awaits the death of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the nation is consumed with what some are calling ''necropolitics,'' a morbid mixture of squabbling and expiation so intricate that it needs a psychoanalyst or a priest to unravel.

LEAD: The people at Farberware Inc. have taken a hard look at the cup of coffee, and say they have discovered a better way to brew it.


New Ford Cut On Escort Cars
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would idle its Wayne, Mich., assembly plant for one week to trim the number of unsold Ford Escort subcompact cars.


Bonn Reported Split on NATO Arms
LEAD: West German politicians said today that the governing coalition was torn by a bitter struggle over its stand on short-range nuclear weapons.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl emerged so politically isolated, they said, that a compromise with Washington at the NATO summit meeting was no longer considered feasible.


Woman Raped in Park On First Day of a Visit
LEAD: A woman was raped at gunpoint in Central Park early yesterday, less than two hours after she had arrived in New York on a bus from North Carolina, the police said.

LEAD: Ever since an eclectic religious colony settled on the edge of Yellowstone Park in 1981 and began developing a scenic valley into a thriving community, its members have found themselves at odds with neighboring park officials, environmentalists and townspeople.


Cash for Alfa Ruled Illegal
LEAD: The European Commission's competition chief has decided that an injection of state cash to the car maker Alfa Romeo before it was sold to Fiat in 1987 was illegal and must be repaid, commission sources said today.


Finks Among Finalists
LEAD: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, said yesterday that he had reluctantly given permission for the National Football League search committee to talk to Jim Finks, the general manager of the Saints.
The action confirms that Finks is on the final list of candidates to replace Pete Rozelle as league commissioner.


Your Money; Planning Ahead To Retire Early
LEAD: The majority of Americans would like to retire early, but few have done the serious retirement planning that would enable them to do so comfortably, a survey by Merrill Lynch &amp; Company shows.

LEAD: Carl Capasso, companion of Bess Myerson, left the Allenwood Federal prison in Pennsylvania yesterday for a halfway house on West 43d Street in Manhattan to finish serving his sentence for tax evasion.
Mr.
Capasso, 47 years old, owner of a sewer-construction company, is due for release June 26 after completing two years of a three-year sentence.

LEAD: A few hours before President Bush arrived tonight for a two-day visit, Italian leaders took tentative steps to put their crumbled Government back together again.

LEAD: A 57-year-old police inspector was promoted to deputy chief yesterday, making him the highest-ranking Hispanic officer in the New York City Police Department and the first person of Puerto Rican descent ever named a chief.


Man Is Saved by Plugging of Holes in Heart
LEAD: A surgeon saved a gunshot victim's life Thursday by plugging the bullet holes in his heart with her fingers and massaging the heart to keep it beating in a 14-minute helicopter ride to a trauma center.

LEAD: Researchers at the Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., have patented a new method of preventing jaundice in newborn babies.


A Triple Crown Tuneup
LEAD: Sunday Silence, who will try to become the first Triple Crown winner in 11 years when he runs in the Belmont Stakes on June 10, worked three furlongs in 37 2/5 seconds at Belmont Park this morning.
It was the colt's first workout since winning the Preakness Stakes last Saturday.
Sunday Silence is expected to face between 5 and 10 opponents in the Belmont, led by Easy Goer, the Derby and Preakness runner-up.

LEAD: ''I love elections,'' a former Irish Prime Minister, Garret FitzGerald, confessed this morning as he hurried into the Georgian parliament building, where he is a member of the opposition. ''It's the dull parts in between I can't stand.''

Admission is free.

LEAD: Journalists and technicians at the British Broadcasting Corporation today staged the fourth in a series of 24-hour strikes over wages, disrupting radio and television programs.

The Takeover of American Industry
LEAD: Last summer, just after the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan bought the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, it said it would invest $1.5 billion in its new American property, raising spending for everything from research to plant modernization.
To executives in Firestone's Chicago headquarters, who had watched the company steadily decline and shrink in the past decade, the purchase signaled a much-needed renaissance.

BEIRUT DIARY
LEAD: APRIL 17, 1989: Sporadic shelling this morning.
I drive home from my office at midday with a 25-liter canister of gasoline for my electric generator.
Just moments after I pass the state-run Lebanese University, a mortar shell strikes the campus.
The blast causes my car to wobble, but I make it home to my apartment building on the rue Bachir al-Kassar, in West Beirut.

Question Of the Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
LEAD: The 1989 Indianapolis 500 starting grid of 33 cars had qualifying runs between Rick Mears, on the pole, at 223.885 m.p.h., and Bernard Jourdain at 213.105 m.p.h.
This is the fastest field ever assembled.
Only a few years ago, a qualifying speed of 212 m.p.h. won the pole; now such a speed will not make the field.

LEAD: Playful slippers are stepping out of folklore.
Whether authentic or interpreted by designers, they add a festive note to the simplest summer clothing.
Toes are extended, pointed and even turned up.
Embellishments include sequins, mirrors, trading beads, coins, glass marbles, charms, jewels, tiny bells, silken tassels and even calligraphy.

A Gotti Is Convicted
LEAD: Gene Gotti, the 42-year-old brother of John Gotti, was convicted of running a multimillion-dollar heroin ring, but it wasn't easy.
The case began in 1983, resulted in two mistrials and became one of the oldest unresolved matters on the Federal docket.
A third mistrial was narrowly averted in Brooklyn when one of the 12 jurors whose identities were supposedly secret said that two men had threatened him in his driveway.

Queenan is an editor at Forbes, a magazine that extolls the pursuit of empty materialism and the virtues of greed, featuring such stalwarts as Ivan Boesky and Michael Milken.

I'd rather my child's heroes be characters with a sense of honor and a willingness to take responsibilty for the consequences of their actions, like Wolverine and Batman, than Oliver (Just Following Orders) North or Jimmy (God Forgave Me, Why Can't You?) Swaggart.

Reviews/Dance; Additional Segments Of Kei Takei's 'Light'
LEAD: Kei Takei has done it again.
On Tuesday night at the La Mama Annex the Japanese minimalist deposited a group of performers in another of her barren landscapes and provided them with another of her stark and mystic rituals.
Once again she bored at least one viewer nearly to death.
And once again she has created a theater-dance piece of undeniable and unforgettable power, this time in ''The Last Rice Field,'' a new work that is Part 27 of her 20-year ''Light'' series.

Burma
LEAD: To the Editor: Steven Erlanger glossed over the truly splendid and unusual things to see in Burma.

Louisville
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9).
The J. B. Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's . . .
Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years.

LEAD: A man was struck and killed by a subway train yesterday as he tried to cross the tracks of an IRT Seventh Avenue express in Manhattan, the transit police said.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on May 14 about new uses for the antibiotic tetracycline misstated its effect on the tissue-destroying enzyme collagenase.
Collagenase is believed to be a factor causing rheumatoid arthritis.
Tetracycline reduces the enzyme's activity by 67 percent, not 6 to 7 percent.

LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Relishing the Nautical Life in Croton-on-Hudson
LEAD: An hour's drive from the heart of New York City can take sailing enthusiasts to a world of their own.
Here on Senasqua Bay, where the Hudson River is at its widest, you can learn to sail, brush up on boating skills or charter a boat for a day cruise.


U.S. Toughens Its Trade Stance
LEAD: Three nations were accused of unfair trading by President Bush.
The action means that Japan, India and Brazil are subject to special negotiations with the United States and could face trade sanctions if they do not lower barriers to American imports within 18 months.
Japan was cited for trading practices involving satellites, supercomputers and forest products; Brazil for general import licensing requirements and India for restrictions on foreign investments and on foreign insurance companies.


Cynthia D. Jeck Bride Of Jeffrey Blaine Davis
LEAD: Cynthia Denise Jeck, a doctoral candidate in pharmacology at Columbia University, and Jeffrey Blaine Davis, who is studying for an M.B.A. at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, N.J.
The Rev.
Dr.
George Chorba officiated.


AFTER HIROHITO: WHAT REMAINS SACRED
LEAD: IN ACCORDANCE WITH AN OLD TRADITION, THE GRAND shrine at Ise, in central Japan, is pulled down every twenty years and built up again in exactly the same form, that of an ancient wooden hut for storing rice.
There, sometime in the seventh century, a princess of the imperial court decided the sun goddess Amaterasu was to be worshipped.


Lingering Effects of a Virus
LEAD: The computer virus spread like wildfire last November, copying itself into as many as 6,000 computers connected by networks at universities, private corportions and military installations.
It took several days to clear the virus from the computers, but it has taken longer to take care of the rest of the matter.


COMIC-BOOK COLLECTORS
LEAD: I am 14 and have been drawing comics very seriously for five or six years.
I also collect comic books.


Samaranch Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, left today with a clean bill of health after a checkup during a two-day stay.


Is the Use of Latin 'Pro Bono'?
LEAD: During the Presidential campaign and many times since we have heard President Bush say, ''Read my lips,'' and this we have been doing.


HUMAN RIGHTS IN CHINA
LEAD: I would like to add to your report on human rights in China that, no matter how badly intellectuals and activists are treated, it cannot compare with Chinese brutality in Tibet.
I was expelled from Lhasa on March 9, with approximately 100 other tourists, for one reason - so that there would be no witnesses to the army's actions against Tibetan demonstrators.


Charles P. Lykes, 72, Grower and Cattleman
LEAD: Charles Parkhill Lykes, chairman of a cattle, citrus and meatpacking empire and patriarch of one of the state's most prominent families, died Thursday.
He was 72 years old.


Julie Stern to Wed in Fall
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Burton Stern of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Julie Ann Stern and Michael Alan Dorfman, a son of Shirley Dorfman and the late Harry Dorfman of Commack, L.I.
Miss Stern is the director of youth services at the Samuel Field Y.M./Y.W.H.A. in Little Neck, Queens.


Homer for Parrish
LEAD: Larry Parrish, a former major leaguer, hit his 17th home run, a bases-empty shot, as the Yakult Swallows edged the Yokohama Taiyo Whales, 2-1, in Japanese baseball today.


A Tabloid Titan
LEAD: To the Editor:


Storm Causes Power Failures
LEAD: Thousands of homes were without power in Putnam and Dutchess counties after lightning struck a power station in Fishkill during a rainstorm.
More than 22,000 homes lost their electricity Friday at about 9:15 P.M.


200,000 at Hong Kong Rally Pledge to Continue Struggle
LEAD: About 200,000 young people attended a daylong open-air pop concert in Hong Kong today to raise money for the pro-democratic demonstrations in China.


The Changes Go Deep
LEAD: The drama of the news these days has induced vertigo, intoxication with the idea that if some things can change so fast and so unexpectedly, everything can and must be changed overnight.


School Vote: It's Bigger in Cleveland
LEAD: The 6 percent turnout for the recent school board elections in New York City was far below the participation in school elections in many other cities, officials elsewhere say.


SPA LIFE
LEAD: I eagerly read Linda Wells's article ''Spa Life'' (May 7), hoping to find some spas in the United States like the ones I enjoyed so much during the three years I lived in Hungary.
I was disappointed to see that the spas you mention are more like modern resorts, with fitness facilities.
These resorts may be pleasant places to spend some time; however, they are not built around mineral springs, as are European spas.

Not a Fan Of Darling
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Fund Investors, Know Thy Manager
LEAD: When choosing a mutual fund, it is as important to consider the fund manager as the fund itself, for without a capable captain to plot the fund's course, a fund can be lost in the market's often murky sea.


A Community Welcomes Back Its Bridge to Business
LEAD: IN February 1986 the State Department of Transportation began what was supposed to be 14 months of repair to a bridge on Route 12 at the southern edge of Jewett City.
But the job went on for almost 40 months, and businesses watched as not only traffic from nearby Interstate 395 dwindled, but also their profits.

LEAD: Phineas Newborn Jr., a leading jazz pianist, died at his home in Memphis, Tenn., Friday.
He was 57 years old.

HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
LEAD:  CLASSICAL  Bach: ''Magnificat'' (S. 243); Vivaldi: ''Gloria'' (R. 589)  Dawn Upshaw, Penelope Jensen, Marietta Simpson, David Gordon, William Stone and the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chamber Chorus conducted by Robert Shaw.
Telarc CD-80194, CD only.
The unsurpassed smoothness of these performances may surprise listeners accustomed to the lean, accented style of presenting Baroque music currently in favor.


Laying Bricks With Sand
LEAD: LAYING bricks with sand instead of mortar is an easy way to create walkways, patios and even driveways.


STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; A Mystery Monogram and a Building Out of Sync
LEAD: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes.


Coelho's Deftness as a Deal Maker Fails to Extend to His Personal Finances
LEAD: The deft touch for raising political contributions that helped propel Tony Coelho into the Democratic leadership in the House never extended to his personal finances, leaving the California Congressmen financially insecure for much of his political career.


Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse
LEAD: FOR at least one Rutgers senior, the road to graduation may have been unorthodox, but it represented a victory that was almost unthinkable a few years ago.


A Crucible of Cultures in Andalusia
LEAD: SEVILLE is not just a great city of the past.
It is the vibrant modern center of western Andalusia, as the traffic and the crowds make plain.
Situated in one of the most fertile provinces of Spain, the Guadalquivir River that flows through it was navigable until the last century.
The university thrives, as it has done for centuries, and during the school year students throng the city center and fill the bars with noise as the young have done since the days when Muslims ruled, when the students, merchants and tourists of those days first crowded the avenues.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My bathroom ceiling was wallpapered and now I want to paint the ceiling.
I have removed most of the wallpaper, but some cementlike paste remains in several areas.
I am tired of trying to smooth this ceiling further.
Can I paint with a sand-textured paint and are there any disadvantages to this?

FICTION
LEAD:  EMILY L. By Marguerite Duras.
Translated by Barbara Bray. (Pantheon, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras, the Goncourt Prize-winning author of many novels, including ''The Lover,'' again combines her gifts for the literary and visual arts in this arresting novella.
In a French quayside cafe in late summer, the French narrator, accompanied by the man with whom she's been having an affair that is ''taking forever to die,'' grows absorbed by a British couple sitting nearby.


Enough 'Reality'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Israelis Report Killing Armed Arab Infiltrator
LEAD: An Arab who tried to infiltrate Israel from Jordan opened fire and slightly wounded two Israeli soldiers this morning before he was shot and killed, the Israeli Army said.
An army spokeswoman said that around 6:30 A.M., an army patrol was fired on from near the border fence opposite Kibbutz Hamadya, 12 miles south of the Sea of Galilee.


Food Chains Sued Over Bottle Redemption Policies
LEAD: A class-action suit has charged seven New York City supermarket chains with widespread violations of state law by limiting the numbers of bottles and cans that homeless people can redeem for their deposits.


Some Recipes That Keep Baby in Mind
LEAD: AS an infant in a highchair, I was encouraged to stamp on pieces of boiled potato with my fist (the result is known as ''smashed'' potato), to squeeze bananas through my fingers, and later to eat spaghetti by sucking it up strand by strand.
My grandmother called it ''experimenting with textures.''


O'Connor Arrives in Lebanon To See Both Sides of Civil War
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, arrived in Lebanon today, his first visit to the war-torn country in three years.

LEAD: WITH a sparkle not far removed from the diamonds and Burmese rubies spread before him, Arthur Groom's eyes radiate excitement when he talks about business.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: There is perhaps someone somewhere who has never wished to get even about something.

Court Rules Schools Must Take All Disabled
LEAD: Public schools must provide education for all handicapped children, no matter how severe the disability or how little they might benefit, a Federal appeals court panel has ruled.


Crack; A Disaster of Historic Dimension, Still Growing
LEAD: The little pellets first appeared on the West Coast in the early 1980's, the product of brilliant marketing.
Someone figured out how to boil down powdered cocaine into crystals that could be smoked rather than snorted.
Inhaling this ''crack'' gives a brief, intense high - followed by a crash that leaves the user desperate for more.


CHINESE STUDENTS URGE END TO SIEGE OF BEIJING SQUARE
LEAD: China's student leaders today called for an end to their two-week occupation of Tiananmen Square, in the center of the capital, but said that they would continue to hold large-scale demonstrations to press for greater democracy and the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng.


Two Can't Go . . .
LEAD: A federal judge in San Francisco has denied a request by a former Olympic athlete and a coach to lift suspensions barring them from amateur competition because they participated in a South African sports event despite an international boycott to protest apartheid.


'My Name Is Steven' No. 2 Mini-Series
LEAD: ''I Know My Name is Steven,'' which was broadcast by NBC on Monday and Tuesday nights, was the second-highest-rated mini-series of the season, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company.
The four-hour program had an average rating of 24.5 and was seen by 39 percent of the viewing audience.

Forget HDTV, It's Already Outmoded
LEAD: The world is on the verge of a technological transformation that will make current televison as obsolete as the hot-air dirigible.
This new technology will also radically enhance the competitiveness of American technology and the richness and variety of video programming.
This new development is not high definition television, which offers only a fourfold increase in picture quality over existing television.

LEAD: ''Atwater and his fraternity brothers,'' we are told, ''used to rent black-and-white pornographic movies and charge 50 cents to see them. '' 'You can bet nobody asked for their damn money back on those flicks,' he volunteers, sitting with his wife and parents  [ emphasis mine ]  in the family living room.


Yucatan
LEAD: To the Editor: I read, with fondness and approval (Travel, Feb. 26), Budd Schulberg's evocative article about the beautiful Yucatan coast away from the bright lights and crowded beaches of Cancun.


Grade Inflation: Widespread Travesty
LEAD: Teachers are notorious for inflating grades (''Schools Say Inflated Grades Cut Grants,'' May 7).
Nowadays, in most schools the ''good'' students are almost always given A's, the ''mediocre'' students B's and the ''poor'' students almost never less than C's, despite their dubious achievements.

Mini Field for Maxi-Race
LEAD: Ireland's first entry in the Whitbread round-the-world race, a massive white and green maxi-yacht, was being wheeled out of a repair shed in Portsmouth, R.I., last week.
The yacht's crewmen had a race to think about, but it wasn't around the world.
It was to be across the Atlantic Ocean, a mere sprint by Whitbread standards.


Is the Pap Test Valid?
LEAD: REPORTS IN RECENT MONTHS about the high rate of ''false negatives'' for Pap smears were frightening to women.
A false negative, in medical lingo, is a screening test that says ''no cancer'' when all the while a cancer is, in fact, growing undetected.
Pap smears, which can detect cancer of the cervix, are now said to have a false negative rate of 20 to 40 percent.


PASTIMES: Gardening; An Alert for Some Insect Nuisances
LEAD: A home gardener is in charge and can choose a way to get rid of pests that is least harmful to the environment.
Too often when chemical weapons are used for complete eradication, the good is destroyed with the bad.

That is one reason this is a great place to live.
Now economists have uncovered the outline of an industry underlying that vitality.
It is a growth industry, but one vulnerable to the special sources of its capital.


The Auvergne's Well-Bred Beef
LEAD: THE natives of Cantal - in the rugged south-central Auvergne region of France - love to report that their department has 150,000 inhabitants and 450,000 cows.
And a good number of those cows are the Salers breed, raised for their golden rich milk as well as their tender, finely muscled, reddish-brown, delicately marbled beef.

Arts Dollars: Pinched As Never Before

LEAD:  SORT OF RICH  By James Wilcox.  278 pp. New York:  Harper &amp; Row. $17.95.


POSTINGS: North of Princeton's Campus; From Timber to Town Houses in Three Short
LEAD: The tract of forest and meadow in central New Jersey near Princeton first attracted the attention of eagle-eyed London speculators, John Lord Berkeley and Sir George Carteret, in the 1650's; they acquired it from the Crown.
Later, it was owned by William Penn, the Quaker leader, and, at the time of the Revolutionary War, it was the property of Richard Stockton, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.


A Lesson in Citizenship
LEAD: WHAT happened last summer on our beaches and in our skies made us more aware of the vulnerability of our environment as no other event since the bombing of Hiroshima.
Media exposure and the visibility of the dangers caused our reac tions to be more immediate and widespread.
My own experience, in a small way, bears witness to its impact.

CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
LEAD: Your article on John Silber is aptly titled, but what is he crusading for?
Excellence, he says, and he frankly embraces elitism.
But people who are truly wise (Einstein, Dostoyevsky, Rembrandt, for example) are compassionate.
As the Greeks understood, there is no wisdom (sophia) without compassion (aidos).

Time on Her Hands
LEAD: Getting away from it all was taken to new heights, or depths, by Stefania Follini, who last week completed 130 days without human contact in a sealed cave in Carlsbad, N.M.

Museum Toy Exhibit
LEAD: The Museum of the City of New York, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, is exhibiting ''Family Treasures: Toys and Their Tales'' through April 1990.
Reflecting the social history of New York, the toys include expensive European imports, modest domestic inventions of the 19th and early 20th centuries, and dolls commemorating such events of local importance as the Seventh Regiment Armory Fair of 1879.

Cordoba's Hymn to Islam
LEAD: HE was standing in the courtyard of the Great Mosque of Cordoba in southern Spain when I saw him, gargling water from the ritual fountain there.
Three times he took a mouthful and spat it out; three times he sniffed water up his nostrils and snorted; three times he washed his face and ears and then his hands and forearms as far as the elbow, to purify all five senses.

A Funny Thing Happened to Soviet Architecture Photo of ''Ascencion to the Peak, Glass Monument for 2001,'' by V. Saitsev and L. Vatalov (Karin Hill)
LEAD: Among all the arts exported from the Soviet Union since the 1950's, architecture has been conspicuous by its absence.
The reason is simple.
While Stalin favored inflated, wedding-cake-style architecture to express the state's authority, Khrushchev wanted quantity - especially mass-produced housing, roughly built with large prefabricated panels.

LEAD: Anyone new to the experience of owning a lawn, as I am, soon figures out that there is more at stake here than a patch of grass.

Mowing the lawn, I realized the first time I gazed into my neighbor's yard and imagined him gazing back into mine, is a civic responsibility.

PLAYING HARDBALL
LEAD: Amnesia has reached a new high.
When George Bush was Republican Party chairman during the Watergate days, he could not recall any Nixon wrongdoing.
Now he cannot remember having been ''in the loop'' of the Iran-contra affair.
The current G.O.P. national chairman, Lee Atwater, can't recall any of his past racist or anti-Semitic smears.


Maglev Transit: Out of Place on L.I.
LEAD: The Maglev thing seems to be out of place on Long Island.
No doubt someone could build one, but what need would it serve?
Manhattan to Riverhead?
How many people make the trip between those two points?
Many to the North Fork or to the Hamptons, but just to Riverhead?
When you get off the Maglev there, how do you get to Aquebogue or Mattituck or Shelter Island or Montauk?

Storm Kills 52 in Vietnam
LEAD: A tropical storm last week in central Vietnam killed 52 people, injured at least 37 and left 100,000 homeless, radio reports said today.

Mortgage Rates Down
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.5 percent this week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That was down from a rate of 10.69 percent last week.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 9.18 percent this week, down from 9.28 percent the week before, Freddie Mac said.

McDowell Balks And Loses in 12th
LEAD: It took 4 hours 7 minutes on the clock and 12 innings on the field, but the Mets found a new and absolutely maddening way to lose a game today.
With runners on second and third base, nobody out and the Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers tied at 3-3, a balk was called against Roger McDowell and the winning run was waved home by the umpire.

Soviet Wheat Purchase
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought another 300,000 metric tons of American wheat using subsidies offered by the United States Government, the Agriculture Department announced Friday.
The wheat purchase was the latest under a 1.5-million-metric-ton subsidy offer President Bush extended to Moscow on May 2.

New Competition in Spain's Media
LEAD: In a country where only 15 years ago most newspapers and all television stations were still owned by the state, the media picture is being rapidly transformed.
Powerful local and foreign investors are now warring to control Spain's lucrative market.
The latest battlefield is television, where Rupert Murdoch and Silvio Berlusconi are among international communications investors bidding for licenses to run the country's first three commercial stations.

No More Wet Feet on Deck
LEAD: Timberland, a company based in Hampton, N.H., recently introduced a boat shoe that comes with its own drainage system.
The Hydro-Tech looks at first like a running shoe.
Its leather, mesh and rubber exterior disguises six interior vents that funnel water into two drain cups embedded in the plastic midsole.

LEAD: A new strategy for helping the more than two million refugees and others driven from their homes by decades of civil strife in Central America is expected to be endorsed by an international conference starting here on Monday.

LEAD: The Federal Executive Institute, established by Presidential order in 1968 and based in Charlottesville, Va., prides itself on being a civil servant's equivalent of a war college.

LEAD: A slow-moving freight train slammed into about 30 parked railroad cars early today, killing the brakeman and the conductor and injuring two other crewmen.

Review/Music; Japanese Ensemble in Its New York Debut
LEAD: The Senzoku Tokyo Ensemble, a group formed last year by faculty members at Senzoku Gakuen College near Tokyo, gave its first New York performance Saturday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall.
The program presented eight members in two cornerstones of the German chamber-music literature, giving readings that were creditable and sometimes expert if not always stirringly expressive.

Portugal Customs Strike
LEAD: Portuguese customs workers staged a one-day strike Friday, stopping goods from entering the country and causing long lines of trucks at border points, a union spokesman said.
Travelers at airports and border crossings were not affected by the stoppage by the 3,000 customs employees, who are demanding wage increases.

Jeff Duncan, 59, Choreographer And Dance Workshop Founder
LEAD: Jeff Duncan, a choreographer and dancer who founded Dance Theater Workshop, a leading showcase for modern dance in New York City, died of complications resulting from AIDS on Friday in Baltimore at the Don Miller House, which offers care to AIDS patients.
He was 59 years old.

Reporter's Notebook; Incumbents and Unions Did Well in School Vote
LEAD: Several trends emerged in the slow tallying of the May 2 New York City school board vote, which finished last week and awaits certification this week.
Most incumbents were re-elected.
Parents scored some gains but will be in the minority on every board.
Union-backed candidates also generally did well.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Becker Leads West Germany: Boris Becker led West Germany to a 2-1 victory over Argentina yesterday in the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf.
Becker gave West Germany the lead after defeating Guillermo Perez-Roldan, 6-0, 2-6, 6-2, in the first singles match.
But Martin Jaite of Argentina rallied and defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 6-3, in the second singles match.

East-West Friction: The NATO Years
LEAD:  March 1946 Winston Churchill, the leader of Britain's Conservative opposition, warns of Soviet expansionism in his Iron Curtain speech at Fulton, Mo.
With President Truman present, he calls for the United States and Britain to unite as guardians of the peace.
March 1947 The Truman Doctrine begins with economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey, initiating the policy of containment.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines; In Mirabella's First Issue, Things New and Not So New
LEAD: THERE seems to be as much need for a new fashion magazine as there is for a new Italian restaurant.
Still, Elle magazine, which aims at a swingy young crowd, established what looks like a secure place for itself three years ago.
And it was followed last year by Lear's, beamed at the more mature woman.


Meek and Mumblers Learn Ways of Getting a Word In
LEAD: For years, Americans have been doing everything from jogging to meditating as part of a sweeping self-improvement movement.
Now, unaccustomed as they are to public speaking, more and more people are devoting the same kind of discipline and dollars to overcoming stage fright and sharpening their delivery.

LEAD: From poor women, whose suffering rarely makes headlines, to bankers on the fast track, to little girls in pigtails, vulnerability to rape is shared by all women and girls, experts say.


Menil Collection Seeks $35 Million
LEAD: Faced with financial problems two years after its opening, the prestigious Menil Collection in Houston is out to raise $35 million in endowment money.
The need, quite frankly acknowledged by the museum's founder and chief patron, Dominique de Menil, comes as a surprise to many in the art world who had assumed that the future of the institution was assured.

Memorial Day
LEAD:  NEW YORK  Parade: Begins at noon at Broadway and 72d Street, travels north to 86th Street, then west to the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument at 90th Street and Riverside Drive.
Parking: Sunday rules.
Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning.
Government offices: Closed.

LEAD: Phineas Newborn Jr., a leading jazz pianist, died Friday at his home in Memphis.
He was 57 years old.


Argentine Films
LEAD: ''Argentina: The 50's and the 60's,'' a series highlighting Argentine film making after the fall of Juan Peron, will run at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, through June 8.
Screenings are included in the museum admission, which is $6; $3.50 for students and $3 for the elderly.
Museum hours are Fridays through Tuesdays 11 A.M.

LEAD: A group of Turks stoned and broke the windows of the Bulgarian Consulate today to protest Bulgaria's treatment of its ethnic Turkish minority, the Anatolia news agency said.

LEAD: Accidents that would be mere inconveniences in other countries become disasters in Zambia, underscoring the fragility of an economy that totters on the brink of ruin in the best of times.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a memorial service for Frances Steloff, founder of the Gotham Book Mart, incorrectly described lectures given in her name at Skidmore College.
The lectures, given annually by people in the arts, were endowed by Miss Steloff; they were not about her.

LEAD: For the first time in more than a year, rockets were fired into northern Israel, exploding in the town of Metulla early today, an army spokesman said.

Review/Television; The Series for These Ambiguous Times
LEAD: ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' which has just finished its second season, could very well be the prototypical television series for the 1990's.
The Reagan years gave us ''Dynasty,'' a fantasy of money, power and glamour.
They also left us with profound questions about morals and ethics, questions being distilled in today's headlines concerning politicians and stockbrokers, not to mention obviously troubled teen-agers and growing contingents of the homeless.


Obituary; Bob Waters, 50; Active as a Coach Despite Long Illness
LEAD: Bob Waters, who had continued as head football coach at Western Carolina University for five seasons while suffering from the degenerative nerve-cell disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, died this morning at his home.
He was 50 years old.


Chinese Students, in About-Face, Will Continue Occupying Square
LEAD: Reversing their earlier position, thousands of university students resolved on Monday to maintain pressure on the Government by continuing their round-the-clock occupation of Tiananmen Square for at least three more weeks.


Review/Theater; Is It Love? Or Is It Hate? Or Just Self-Absorption?
LEAD: In the advanced state of self-absorption in which modern life exists, it is sometimes hard to determine with any degree of accuracy whether the emotion one feels toward another person is love or hate.
It is even difficult to remember whether one is alive or dead.

A Wrap? A Stole? The Fling's a Hit
LEAD: They are calling it the fling.
It goes by other names as well, including stole, shawl, poncho, ruana, rebozo or just plain scarf.
But fling is what it does, whether it is a long rectangle, perfect square or a series of undulating curves that arch around the neck and dip in front and back.
It wraps cozily around the body, offering warmth, color and a graceful look to day and evening clothes.


Sahara Yields Hints About Evolution of Man
LEAD: DIGGING into valleys detected by space shuttle radar under the Sahara's sands has shown that during three separate periods up to 212,000 years ago they were vegetated and densely inhabited by makers of stone axes.

LEAD: After further examination of Willie Wilson's right shoulder yesterday, doctors said the Kansas City Royals center fielder would probably go on the disabled list for a couple of weeks.
The 11-year veteran was diagnosed as having tendinitis of the right rotator cuff.

Blood Test Found to Predict Risk of Heart Attack

LEAD: To the Editor:


Gucci Rehires Ex-Chairman
LEAD: Guccio Gucci S.p.A., the Italian leather goods and fashion chain, has reappointed Maurizio Gucci as its chairman after a weekend shareholders' meeting here.


Philippine Workers on Strike
LEAD: Thousands of workers nationwide went on strike for higher pay today, defying an appeal by President Corazon C. Aquino, who said labor unrest would discourage needed foreign investment.
The Government said the general strike affected 169 companies employing more than 137,000 workers.
Unions said half a million workers on central Luzon island alone stayed home.


Nestle Reversal On Offering
LEAD: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A., in a turnabout from a position it took last week, said today that a planned securities offering to raise nearly 800 million Swiss francs, or about $460 million, would go ahead despite initial objections from a group of stockholders.


From Sales to Credit, Letters to Do Business
LEAD: THERE are many men and women, otherwise capable and canny, who quail at the thought of writing a business letter.
Perhaps they are less than confident of their command of grammar, syntax or spelling, or maybe they think a business letter requires the formal, stuffy style of the era of the steel nib and inkwell.

LEAD: Japanese officials are hoping to use a gathering of the industrial world's economic and finance ministers here Wednesday to rally European countries against United States trade policies.

LEAD: Rick Pitino, the Knicks' coach, has informally agreed to become the University of Kentucky's head basketball coach, according to reports.

LEAD: Under President Matina S. Horner, Radcliffe College attained for its women undergraduates what had long been the school's dream: all the rights and privileges of the men of Harvard College.


Physicians Rate Patient Welfare Above Truth
LEAD: Many doctors say they would withhold information or mislead a patient's family to protect the patient, a new survey shows.
